{{distinguish|Anathoth|Astaroth|Ashtoreth|Ataroth|Azeroth (disambiguation)|Azarath}} {{about|a [[List of deities in fiction|deity in fiction]]|the short story named after it|Azathoth (short story)|other uses}} {{refimprove|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox character | name = Azathoth | series = [[Cthulhu Mythos]] | image = Azathoth.jpg | caption = Artist's depiction of Azathoth | first = "[[Azathoth (short story)|Azathoth]]" | last = | creator = [[H. P. Lovecraft]] | portrayer = | voice = | lbl1 = | data1 = | lbl2 = | data2 = | nickname = | alias = | species = [[Outer Gods|Outer God]] | gender = | occupation = | title = Nuclear Chaos
Daemon Sultan
Blind Idiot God | family = | spouse = | significantother = | children = [[Nyarlathotep]] (son)
[[Cthulhu Mythos deities#The Nameless Mist|Nameless Mist]] (offspring)
[[Cthulhu Mythos deities#Darkness|Darkness]] (offspring) | relatives = [[Yog-Sothoth]] (grandson)
[[Shub-Niggurath]] (granddaughter)
[[List of Great Old Ones#Nug and Yeb|Nug]] (great-grandchild)
[[List of Great Old Ones#Nug and Yeb|Yeb]] (great-grandchild)
[[The Dunwich Horror#Wilbur Whateley|Wilbur Whateley]] (great-grandson)
[[Cthulhu]] (great-great-grandson)
[[Tsathoggua]] (great-great-grandson) | religion = | nationality = }} '''Azathoth''' is a deity in the [[Cthulhu Mythos]] and [[Dream Cycle]] stories of writer [[H. P. Lovecraft]] and other authors. He is the ruler of the [[Outer God]]s. ==H. P. Lovecraft== ===Inspiration=== The first recorded mention of Azathoth was in a note Lovecraft wrote to himself in 1919 that read simply, "AZATHOTH—hideous name". Mythos editor [[Robert M. Price]] argues that Lovecraft could have combined the biblical names [[Anathoth]] ([[Jeremiah]]'s home town) and [[Azazel]]—mentioned by Lovecraft in "[[The Dunwich Horror]]".H. P. Lovecraft, [https://archive.is/20090108052810/http://www.mythostomes.com/content/view/63/70/ "The Dunwich Horror"], ''The Dunwich Horror and Others'', p. 158. Price also points to the [[alchemy|alchemical]] term "[[Azoth]]", which was used in the title of a book by [[Arthur Edward Waite]], the model for the wizard Ephraim Waite in Lovecraft's "[[The Thing on the Doorstep]]".Robert M. Price, ''The Azathoth Cycle'', pp. v-vi. Another note Lovecraft made to himself later in 1919 refers to an idea for a story: "A terrible pilgrimage to seek the nighted throne of the far daemon-sultan Azathoth."cited in Price, ''The Azathoth Cycle'', p. vi. In a letter to [[Frank Belknap Long]], Lovecraft ties this plot germ to ''[[Vathek]]'', a novel by [[William Thomas Beckford|William Beckford]] about a supernatural [[caliph]].Letter to Frank Belknap Long, June 9, 1922; cited in Price, ''The Azathoth Cycle'', p. vi. Lovecraft's attempts to work this idea into a novel floundered (a 500-word fragment survives, first published under the title "[[Azathoth (short story)|Azathoth]]"[http://mythostomes.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=34&Itemid=70 "H. P. Lovecraft's original fragment, 'Azathoth'"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814112342/http://mythostomes.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=34&Itemid=70 |date=2007-08-14 }} in the journal ''Leaves'' in 1938),[http://www.hplovecraft.com/writings/fiction/az.asp "Publication History for H. P. Lovecraft's 'Azathoth'"], The H. P. Lovecraft Archive. although Lovecraftian scholar Will Murray suggests that Lovecraft recycled the idea into his [[Dream Cycle]] novella ''[[The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath]]'', written in 1926.Price, ''The Azathoth Cycle'', p. vii. Price sees another inspiration for Azathoth in [[Lord Dunsany]]'s [[Mana-Yood-Sushai]], from ''[[The Gods of Pegana]]'', a creator deity "who made the gods and thereafter rested." In Dunsany's conception, MANA-YOOD-SUSHAI sleeps eternally, lulled by the music of a lesser deity who must drum forever, "for if he cease for an instant then MANA-YOOD-SUSHAI will start awake, and there will be worlds nor gods no more." This oblivious creator god accompanied by supernatural musicians is a clear prototype for Azathoth, Price argues.Price, ''The Azathoth Cycle'', pp. viii-ix. ===Fiction=== Aside from the title of the novel fragment, ''[[The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath]]'' was the first fiction by Lovecraft to mention Azathoth: {{bquote|[O]utside the ordered universe [is] that amorphous blight of nethermost confusion which blasphemes and bubbles at the center of all infinity—the boundless daemon sultan Azathoth, whose name no lips dare speak aloud, and who gnaws hungrily in inconceivable, unlighted chambers beyond time and space amidst the muffled, maddening beating of vile drums and the thin monotonous whine of accursed flutes.H. P. Lovecraft, ''The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath'', in ''At The Mountains of Madness'', p. 308.}} Lovecraft referred to Azathoth again in "[[The Whisperer in Darkness]]" (1931), where the narrator relates that he "started with loathing when told of the monstrous nuclear [[wikt:chaos|chaos]] beyond angled space which the ''[[Necronomicon]]'' had mercifully cloaked under the name of Azathoth".H. P. Lovecraft, "The Whisperer in Darkness", ''The Dunwich Horror and Others'', p. 256. Here "nuclear" most likely refers to Azathoth's central location at the nucleus of the cosmos and not to [[Nuclear physics|nuclear energy]], which did not truly come of age until after Lovecraft's death. In "[[The Dreams in the Witch House]]" (1932), the protagonist Walter Gilman dreams that he is told by the witch Keziah Mason that "He must meet the [[Nyarlathotep|Black Man]], and go with them all to the throne of Azathoth at the centre of ultimate Chaos.... He must sign in his own blood the book of Azathoth and take a new secret name.... What kept him from going with her...to the throne of Chaos where the thin flutes pipe mindlessly was the fact that he had seen the name 'Azathoth' in the ''Necronomicon'', and knew it stood for a primal horror too horrible for description."H. P. Lovecraft, "The Dreams in the Witch House", ''At the Mountains of Madness'', pp. 272–273. Gilman wakes from another dream remembering "the thin, monotonous piping of an unseen flute", and decides that "he had picked up that last conception from what he had read in the ''Necronomicon'' about the mindless entity Azathoth, which rules all time and space from a curiously environed black throne at the centre of Chaos".Lovecraft, "The Dreams in the Witch House", p. 282. He later fears finding himself "in the spiral black vortices of that ultimate void of Chaos wherein reigns the mindless daemon-sultan Azathoth".Lovecraft, "The Dreams in the Witch House", p. 293. The poet Edward Pickman Derby, the protagonist of Lovecraft's "[[The Thing on the Doorstep]]", is a poet whose collection of "nightmare lyrics" is called ''Azathoth and Other Horrors''.H. P. Lovecraft, "The Thing on the Doorstep", ''The Dunwich Horror and Others'', p. 277. The last major reference in Lovecraft's fiction to Azathoth was in 1935's "[[The Haunter of the Dark]]", which tells of "the ancient legends of Ultimate Chaos, at whose center sprawls the blind idiot god Azathoth, Lord of All Things, encircled by his flopping horde of mindless and amorphous dancers, and lulled by the thin monotonous piping of a demonic flute held in nameless paws".H. P. Lovecraft, "The Haunter of the Dark", ''The Dunwich Horror and Others'', p. 110. In a letter to a friend who jokingly claimed descent from Jupiter, Lovecraft drew up a detailed genealogy charting his and fellow novelist Clark Ashton Smith's shared descent from Azathoth, through Lovecraft's creation [[Nyarlathotep]] and Clark-Smith's [[Tsathoggua]], respectively. As nowhere stated in Lovecraft's published work, primordial Azathoth here is made ancestor, through his children Nyarlathotep, "The Nameless Mist," and "Darkness," of [[Yog-Sothoth]], [[Shub-Niggurath]], [[Nug and Yeb]], [[Cthulhu]], [[Tsathoggua]], several deities and monsters unmentioned outside the letter, and a few of Lovecraft's and Ashton-Smith's fancifully-posited human forbears.{{cite book |title=[[Selected Letters of H. P. Lovecraft IV (1932–1934)]] |last=Lovecraft |first=H. P. |authorlink=H. P. Lovecraft |year=1967 |publisher=[[Arkham House]] |location=[[Sauk City, Wisconsin]] |isbn=0-87054-035-1 |nopp=y |at=Letter 617 }} ==Other writers== ===August Derleth=== Many other Mythos writers have referred to Azathoth in their stories. [[August Derleth]], in his novel ''[[The Lurker at the Threshold]]'', depicts the entity as a leader in a cosmic upheaval akin to [[Lucifer]]'s rebellion in [[Christian mythology]]. In a passage attributed to the ''[[Necronomicon]]'' of [[Abdul Alhazred]], Derleth writes: {{bquote|(T)hose daring to oppose the [[Elder God (Cthulhu Mythos)|Elder Gods]] who ruled from Betelgueze, the [[Great Old Ones]] who fought against the Elder Gods...were instructed by Azathoth, who is the blind idiot god, and by [[Yog-Sothoth]]....August Derleth, ''The Lurker at the Threshold'', in ''The Watchers Out of Time'', p. 133.}} In another passage, Derleth quotes a prophecy: {{bquote|(Y)e blind idiot, ye noxious Azathoth shal arise from ye middle of ye World where all is Chaos & Destruction where He hath bubbl'd and blasphem'd at Ye centre which is of All Things, which is to say Infinity....}} The Elder Gods punished Azathoth by rendering him mindless and blind, according to Derleth. ===Ramsey Campbell=== In "[[The Insects from Shaggai]]", [[Ramsey Campbell]] describes the extraterrestrial creatures of the title as worshippers of "the hideous god Azathoth", practicing "obscene rites" that involved "atrocities practiced on still-living victims" in Azathoth's conical temple. After fleeing from the destruction of their home planet of [[Shaggai]], the [[Insects from Shaggai|insects]] teleported the temple across the universe, eventually ending up in a forest near Campbell's fictional town of [[Goatswood]].Ramsey Campbell, "The Insects from Shaggai", ''The Azathoth Cycle'', pp. 86-87. Ronald Shea, the narrator of Campbell's story, enters the temple after visiting the forest and discovers a twenty-foot idol that "represented the god Azathoth—Azathoth as he had been before his exile Outside": {{bquote|[I]t consisted of a [[bivalve|bivalvular]] shell supported on many pairs of flexible legs. From the half-open shell rose several jointed cylinders, tipped with [[polyp]]ous appendages; and in the darkness inside the shell I thought I saw a horrible bestial, mouthless face, with deep-sunk eyes and covered with glistening black hair.Campbell, "The Insects from Shaggai", pp. 89, 91.}} At the story's climax, Shea catches a glimpse of "what the idiot god might ''now'' resemble": {{bquote|I saw something ooze into the corridor—a pale grey shape, expanding and crinkling, which glistened and shook gelatinously as still-moving particles dropped free; but it was only a glimpse, and after that it is only in nightmares that I imagine I see the complete shape of Azathoth.Campbell, "The Insects from Shaggai", pp. 91-92.}} In "[[The Mine on Yuggoth]]", Edward Taylor had found Azathoth's other name, N______ (not given in full) in the [[Revelations of Glaaki]]. If one is confronted by a mythos being, the name, if spoken, will scare it away. Edward Taylor fails to use it. ===Gary Myers=== [[Gary Myers (writer)|Gary Myers]] makes frequent mention of Azathoth in his stories, both those set in the Lovecraftian [[Dreamlands]] and those set in the waking world. In "The Snout in the Alcove" (1977), the dreamer protagonist is distressed to find himself in the Dreamlands to which he had vowed never to return. He had made his vow because of a prophecy which said that: {{bquote|[P]resently the benign Elder Ones would be deposed by infinity’s Other Gods, who would drag the world down a black spiral vortex to the central void where the demon sultan Azathoth gnaws hungrily in the dark....Gary Myers, "The Snout in the Alcove", ''The Year's Best Fantasy Stories 3'', pp. 205-206.}} In "The Last Night of Earth" (1995), the Dreamlands sorcerer Han briefly ponders: {{bquote|[T]he allegorical figure of Azathoth, the primal monster who had given birth to the stars at the beginning of time, and who, according to an obscure tradition, would devour them at its end.Myers, "The Last Night of Earth", ''The Azathoth Cycle'', p. 132.}} In "The Web" (2003), the two teen protagonists read this passage from an internet version of the ''Necronomicon'': {{bquote|Azathoth is the Greatest God, who rules all infinity from his throne at the center of chaos. His body is composed of all the bright stars of the visible universe, but his face is veiled in darkness.Myers, "The Web", ''The Disciples of Cthulhu II'', p. 54.}} ===Thomas Ligotti=== [[Thomas Ligotti]]'s [[short story]] "The Sect of the Idiot" ([[1988 in literature|1988]]) mentions a circle of non-human worshippers composed of wizened, hideous creatures. The story's [[epigram]]—a "quotation" from the ''Necronomicon''—reads "The primal chaos, Lord of all... the blind idiot god—Azathoth," suggesting that it is that entity whom the creatures worship.Thomas Ligotti, "The Sect of the Idiot" (1988), ''The Azathoth Cycle'', 93–102. Ligotti has stated that many of his short stories make allusions to Lovecraft's Azathoth, although rarely by that name. An example of this is the story "Nethescurial", which portrays an omnipresent, malevolent, creator deity once worshipped by the inhabitants of a small island. This being slowly infiltrates the life of the story's narrator, first via a manuscript describing its cult. ===Nick Mamatas=== [[Nick Mamatas]]'s [[2004 in literature|2004]] novel ''[[Move Under Ground]]'', set in a world where [[Cthulhu]] has taken power and only the [[Beat generation|Beats]] oppose him, the power of the Great Old Ones twists the [[constellation]]s into new shapes, using them as vessels for his surrogates; among them, [[Jack Kerouac]] observes the "red stars of Azathoth". [[Neal Cassady]] later becomes a chosen one of Azathoth, gaining immense powers to be used against Cthulhu in the process.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===''Call of Cthulhu'' role-playing game=== In the [[Call of Cthulhu (role-playing game)|''Call of Cthulhu'' RPG]], Azathoth is categorized as an [[Outer God]] together with Nyarlathotep, Yog-Sothoth, and others.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ==''The Azathoth Cycle''== In 1995, [[Chaosium]] published ''The Azathoth Cycle'', a [[Cthulhu Mythos anthology]] focusing on works referring to or inspired by the entity Azathoth. Edited by Lovecraft scholar [[Robert M. Price]], the book includes an introduction by Price tracing the roots and development of the Blind Idiot God. The contents include: *"Azathoth" by [[The Thing on the Doorstep#Edward Pickman Derby|Edward Pickman Derby]] *"Azathoth in Arkham" by [[Peter Cannon]] *"The Revenge of Azathoth" by Peter Cannon *"The Pit of the Shoggoths" by Stephen M. Rainey *"Hydra" by [[Henry Kuttner]] *"The Madness Out of Time" by [[Lin Carter]] *"The Insects from Shaggai" by Ramsey Campbell *"The Sect of the Idiot" by Thomas Ligotti *"The Throne of Achamoth" by [[Richard L. Tierney]] & Robert M. Price *"The Last Night of Earth" by Gary Myers *"The Daemon-Sultan" by Donald R. Burleson *"Idiot Savant" by C. J. Henderson *"The Space of Madness" by Stephen Studach *"The Nameless Tower" by [[John Glasby]] *"The Plague Jar" by Allen Mackey *"The Old Ones’ Promise of Eternal Life" by Robert M. Price ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|last=Harms|first=Daniel|title=The Encyclopedia Cthulhiana|edition=2nd|year=1998|location=Oakland, CA|publisher=Chaosium|isbn=1-56882-119-0}} *{{cite book|last=Petersen|first=Sandy|authorlink=Sandy Petersen|title=Call of Cthulhu|edition=5th|year=|location=Oakland, CA|publisher=Chaosium|isbn=1-56882-148-4}} *{{cite book|author=Price, Robert M. (ed.)|authorlink=Robert M. Price|title=The Azathoth Cycle|year=1995|edition=1st|location=Oakland, CA|publisher=Chaosium|isbn=1-56882-040-2}} ==External links== * {{librivox book | title=The Dunwich Horror | author=H. P. LOVECRAFT}} * {{librivox book | title=The Gods of Pegāna | author=Lord DUNSANY}} * {{librivox book | title=Vathek | author=William BECKFORD}} {{H. P. Lovecraft}} [[Category:Cthulhu Mythos deities]] [[Category:Fictional amorphous creatures]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1943]] [[Category:God in fiction]] [[Category:Fictional extraterrestrial characters]] [[Category:Fictional deities]] [[Category:Literary villains]]

revision.text:
{{for|the American football linebacker|Billy Andrews}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Billy Andrews | image = | caption = | fullname = William Andrews | birth_date = 1886 | birth_place = [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], USA | death_date = | death_place = [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland | height = | position = [[Wing half|Right half]] | years1 = 1904–1906 | clubs1 = [[Lisburn Distillery F.C.|Distillery]] | caps1 = ? | goals1 = ? | years2 = 1906–1908 | clubs2 = [[Glentoran F.C.|Glentoran]] | caps2 = 53 | goals2 = 23 | years3 = 1908–1909 | clubs3 = [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] | caps3 = 9 | goals3 = 3 | years4 = 1909–1910 | clubs4 = [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] | caps4 = 13 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 1910–1912 | clubs5 = [[Glentoran F.C.|Glentoran]] | caps5 = 59 | goals5 = 9 | years6 = 1912–1915 | clubs6 = [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]] | caps6 = 105 | goals6 = 2 | years7 = 1915–1916 | clubs7 = [[Lisburn Distillery F.C.|Distillery]] | caps7 = ? | goals7 = ? | years8 = 1916–1919 | clubs8 = [[Belfast United F.C.|Belfast United]] | caps8 = ? | goals8 = ? | years9 = 1919–1920 | clubs9 = [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] | caps9 = ? | goals9 = ? | years10 = 1920–1922 | clubs10 = [[Leadgate Park F.C.|Leadgate Park]] | caps10 = ? | goals10 = ? | years11 = 1920–1923 | clubs11 = [[Belfast Bohemians F.C.|Belfast Bohemians]] | caps11 = ? | goals11 = ? | totalcaps = 239 | totalgoals = 37 | nationalyears1 = 1908–1913 | nationalteam1 = [[Ireland national football team (1882–1950)|Ireland]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 0 }} '''William Andrews''', known as '''Billy Andrews''' or '''Willie Andrews''' (born 1886) was an Irish international [[association football|footballer]] who played professionally in Ireland and England as a [[Wing half|right half]].
==Career== Andrews was born in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], USA and was raised in Ireland. He played club football in both Ireland and England, for [[Lisburn Distillery F.C.|Distillery]], [[Glentoran F.C.|Glentoran]], [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]], [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]], [[Grimsby Town F.C.|Grimsby Town]], [[Belfast United F.C.|Belfast United]], [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]], [[Leadgate Park F.C.|Leadgate Park]] and [[Belfast Bohemians F.C.|Belfast Bohemians]].
Andrews also earned three caps for [[Ireland national football team (1882–1950)|Ireland]] between 1908 and 1913.
==References== *[http://nifootball.blogspot.com/2006/07/billy-andrews.html NIFG profile]
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
Physiotherapists treating patients following uncomplicated coronary artery bypass surgery (also called coronary artery bypass graft surgery, or CABG) surgery continue to use interventions such as deep breathing exercises that are not supported by best available evidence. Standardised guidelines may be required to better match clinical practice with current literature.<ref>Inverarity, Laura; Grossman, K (28 November 2007). "Types of Physical Therapy". About.com. The New York Times Company. Retrieved 29 May 2008</ref>
== Diseases and conditions treated ==
=== Cystic Fibrosis === [[Cystic fibrosis]] (CF), also known as mucoviscidosis, is a [[genetic disorder]] that affects mostly the lungs, but also the [[pancreas]], [[liver]], [[kidneys]], and [[intestines]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = O'Sullivan | first1 = BP | last2 = Freedman | first2 = SD | year = 2009 | title = Cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = Lancet | volume = 373 | issue = 9678| pages = 1891–904 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(09)60327-5 | pmid = 19403164 }}</ref> Major advances over the past few years in the management of cystic fibrosis (CF) have resulted in dramatic improvements in longevity and [[Quality of life (healthcare)|quality of life]] for many patients. However, [[Respiratory system|respiratory]] dysfunction remains responsible for much of the [[morbidity]] and mortality associated with the disorder. Physiotherapy has long played an important role in the respiratory management of the disease, and has had to adapt to the changes in disease pattern from infancy to adulthood. The role of the physiotherapist is not limited to airway clearance, but also includes encouragement and advice regarding exercise, [[Neutral spine|posture]] and mobility, inhalation therapy and, in the later stages of the disease process, non-invasive respiratory support. It is generally felt that the use of [[chest physiotherapy]] in CF has lacked good scientific basis, and the current call for [[evidence-based medicine]] requires physiotherapists to scrutinize their practice closely.<ref>{{cite journal | pmc = 1305881 | pmid=10911816 | volume=93 Suppl 38 | title=Physiotherapy in cystic fibrosis | year=2000 | journal=J R Soc Med | pages=27–36 | last1 = Prasad | first1 = SA | last2 = Tannenbaum | first2 = EL | last3 = Mikelsons | first3 = C}}</ref>
=== Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disorder (COPD) === [[Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] (COPD), also known as chronic obstructive lung disease (COLD), and chronic obstructive airway disease (COAD), among others, is a type of obstructive lung disease characterized by chronically poor airflow. It typically worsens over time. The main symptoms include [[dyspnea|shortness of breath]], cough, and excess [[sputum]] production.<ref>Vestbo, Jørgen (2013). "Definition and Overview". Global Strategy for the Diagnosis, Management, and Prevention of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease. Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease. pp. 1–7.</ref> As COPD gets worse, subject may be short of breath even when one does simple things like get dressed or fix a meal. It gets harder to eat or exercise, and breathing takes much more energy. People often lose weight and get weaker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.webmd.com/lung/copd/tc/chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease-copd-overview|title=COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)-Topic Overview|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT) === [[Deep vein thrombosis]], or deep venous thrombosis (DVT), is the formation of a blood clot (thrombus) within a deep vein, most commonly the legs.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Scarvelis | first1 = D | last2 = Wells | first2 = P | year = 2006 | title = Diagnosis and treatment of deep-vein thrombosis | journal = CMAJ | volume = 175 | issue = 9| pages = 1087–92 | doi = 10.1503/cmaj.060366 | pmid = 17060659 | pmc=1609160}}</ref> Nonspecific signs may include pain, swelling, redness, warmness, and engorged superficial veins. Pulmonary embolism, a potentially life-threatening complication, is caused by the detachment (embolization) of a clot that travels to the lungs. Together, DVT and pulmonary embolism constitute a single disease process known as [[venous thromboembolism]].
== Techniques ==
=== Chest physiotherapy:Postural drainage ===
=== Active cycle of breathing techniques === The ''active cycle of breathing techniques'' (ACBT) is a flexible regimen comprising breathing control, [[thoracic]] expansion exercises and the FET, frequently combined with gravity-assisted positioning. Increasing [[lung volumes]] during thoracic expansion allows air to get behind distal secretions via collateral ventilatory channels. During a [[forced expiratory volume|forced expiratory]] manoeuvre, compression and narrowing occurs within the airways at a point dependent on lung volume (the equal pressure point). This is shifted distally as a forced expiration is continued to low lung volume, thereby mobilizing peripheral secretions.
This technique has been reported to be an effective and efficient means of airway clearance<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pryor | first1 = JA | last2 = Webber | first2 = BA | year = 1979 | title = Evaluation of the forced expiration technique as an adjunct to postural drainage in treatment of cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = BMJ | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 417–18 | doi=10.1136/bmj.2.6187.417}}</ref><ref name="auto">Wilson GE, Baldwin AL, Walshaw MJ. "A comparison of traditional chest physiotherapy with the active cycle of breathing in patients with chronic supperative lung disease. ''Eur Respir J'' 1985; 8(S19):S171</ref> with documented improvements in lung function<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Webber | first1 = BA | last2 = Hofmeyr | first2 = JL | last3 = Morgan | first3 = MDL | last4 = Hodson | first4 = ME | year = 1986 | title = Effects of postural drainage, incorporating the forced expiratory technique, on pulmonary function in cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = Br J Dis Chest | volume = 80 | issue = | pages = 353–9 | doi=10.1016/0007-0971(86)90088-4}}</ref> and no detrimental effect on [[oxygen saturation]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pryor | first1 = JA | last2 = Webber | first2 = B | last3 = Hodson | first3 = ME | year = 1990 | title = Effect of chest physiotherapy on oxygen saturation in patients with cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = Thorax | volume = 45 | issue = | page = 77 | doi=10.1136/thx.45.1.77| pmc = 475668 }}</ref> In comparative studies the ACBT has been found to be advantageous when compared with CCPT,<ref name="auto"/> Flutter,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lyons | first1 = E | last2 = Chatham | first2 = K | last3 = Campbell | first3 = IA | last4 = Prescott | first4 = RJ | year = 1993 | title = Evaluation of the flutter VRP1 device in young adults with cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = Med Sci Res | volume = 21 | issue = | pages = 101–2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pryor | first1 = JA | last2 = Webber | first2 = BA | last3 = Hodson | first3 = ME | last4 = Warner | first4 = JO | year = 1994 | title = The flutter VRP1 as an adjunct to chest physiotherapy in cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = Respir Med | volume = 88 | issue = | pages = 677–81 | doi=10.1016/s0954-6111(05)80066-6}}</ref> and PEP.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hofmeyer | first1 = JL | last2 = Webber | first2 = BA | last3 = Hodson | first3 = ME | year = 1986 | title = Evaluation of positive expiratory pressure as an adjunct of chest physiotherapy in the treatment of cystic fibrosis | pmid = 3296295 | doi = 10.1136/thx.41.12.951 | journal = Thorax | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 951–4 | pmc=460551}}</ref> When compared with the technique of autogenic drainage (AD) Miller et al., reported no differences in efficacy, although ACBT was associated with oxygen desaturation in some cases.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Miller | first1 = S | last2 = Hall | first2 = DO | last3 = Clayton | first3 = CB | last4 = Nelson | first4 = R | year = 1995 | title = Chest physiotherapy in cystic fibrosis; a comparative study of autogenic drainage and the active cycle of breathing techniques with postural drainage | url = | journal = Thorax | volume = 50 | issue = | pages = 165–9 | doi=10.1136/thx.50.2.165| pmc = 473916 }}</ref> There was, however, no significant overall difference in saturation between the two techniques. A more recent comparison of the Flutter and forced expiration with the ACBT reported no significant differences between the treatments for sputum weight, [[pulmonary function test|lung function tests]] or oxygen saturation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pike | first1 = SE | last2 = Machin | first2 = AC | last3 = Dix | first3 = KJ | last4 = Pryor | first4 = JA | last5 = Hodson | first5 = ME | year = 1999 | title = Comparison of flutter VRP1 and forced expirations with active cycle of breathing techniques in subjects with cystic fibrosis | url = | journal = Netherlands J Med | volume = 54 | issue = | page = A125 }}</ref>
== Assessment Tests ==
=== 6 Minute Walk Test (6MWT) === [[Pulmonary rehabilitation]] is an evidence-based intervention for the management of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). In clinical practice, the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) is commonly used to assess changes in functional exercise capacity in COPD patients following pulmonary rehabilitation with the primary outcome reported being the distance walked during the test (i.e. 6MWD). The 6MWD has demonstrated [[internal validity|validity]] and [[Reliability (research methods)|reliability]] after one familiarisation test and the capacity to detect changes following pulmonary rehabilitation. In addition to assessing the outcomes of pulmonary rehabilitation, 6MWD may be used to quantify the magnitude of a patient's disability, prescribe a walking programme, identify patients likely to benefit from a rollator and to identify the presence of exercise-induced [[hypoxemia]].
== Current concepts == [[Randomized trial]]s have demonstrated that pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) can improve [[dyspnea]], exercise tolerance, and health-related quality of life. Rehabilitation has traditionally been provided in [[Health care#Secondary care|secondary care]] to patients with moderate to severe disease. However, current concepts are recommending that it should be delivered in a primary and community care setting for patients with milder disease.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frozen Shoulder|url=https://www.local-physio.co.uk/articles/shoulder-pain/frozen-shoulder|publisher=www.local-physio.co.uk}}</ref>
There are several opportunities for spreading the word for PR in primary care. One of these is to improve access to PR for all those disabled by their disease by the increase of community schemes. One such scheme being utilised in [[Health care in Canada|Canada]] is reviewed. The essential components of PR include behavior change, patient self-management and prescriptive exercise. In the last decade new strategies have been developed to enhance the effects of exercise training. An overview of these new approaches being an adjunct to exercise training is reviewed. Although the role of exercise training is well established, we are only just beginning to appreciate the importance of behavior change and patient self-management in contributing to improved health and diminished healthcare resource utilisation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ambrosino | first1 = N | last2 = Casaburi | first2 = R | last3 = Ford | first3 = G | last4 = Goldstein | first4 = R | last5 = Morgan | first5 = MD | last6 = Rudolf | first6 = M | last7 = Singh | first7 = S | date = Jun 2008 | title = Developing concepts in the pulmonary rehabilitation of COPD. " Wijkstra PJ | url = | journal = Respir Med. | volume = 102 | issue = Suppl 1| pages = S17–26 | doi = 10.1016/S0954-6111(08)70004-0 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cardiovascular and pulmonary physiotherapy}} [[Category:Physical therapy]] [[Category:Quality of life]]

revision.comment: uc
/* Early life and military service */ Added metric equivalent height.
revision.text:
{{Infobox animal | name = Chief | image = | image_upright = | caption = | othername = | species = Horse | breed = | gender = [[Gelding]] | birth_name = | birth_date = 1932 | birth_place = | death_date = May 24, {{Death year and age|1968|1932}} | death_place = | resting_place = [[Fort Riley, Kansas]], United States | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | occupation = [[Horses in warfare|Cavalry horse]] | employer = [[United States Army]] | role = | years_active = | known_for = Last operational cavalry mount of the U.S. Army | tricks = | title = Advanced Cavalry Charger | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = | residence = | parents = | mate = | children = | weight = | height = 15.25 hands | appearance = [[Bay (color)|Bay]] | namedafter = | awards = }} '''Chief''' (1932–1968) was a horse owned by the [[United States Army]]. He has been credited as the Army's last living operational [[Horses in warfare|cavalry mount]]. Mustered into service in 1940 in [[Nebraska]], Chief was posted to [[Fort Riley]] and served with the [[9th Cavalry Regiment|9th]] and [[10th Cavalry Regiment]]s before being sent to the U.S. Army Cavalry School. In 1949–1950, he was put out to pasture and eventually died in 1968.
==Early life and military service== Chief was foaled in 1932 and added to the cavalry muster roll in 1940 at [[Fort Robinson]], having been purchased that year from LA Robinson of [[Scottsbluff, Nebraska]], for $163.<ref name="neb">{{cite web |title = Chief, 1932–1968 |url = https://history.nebraska.gov/collections/chief-1932-1968-rg4261am |website = History Nebraska |publisher = Nebraska History Museum |access-date = June 2, 2018 }}</ref> He was [[bay (color)|bay]] with white markings, standing 15.25 hands (15.49 dm) high and weighing {{convert|1,030|lbs|adj=off}}.<ref>{{cite news |last1 = Shuford |first1 = E.L. |title = Death of 'Chief' Ended Cavalry Era |url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/21965709/death_of_chief_ended_cavalry_era/ |access-date = July 18, 2018 |work = Asheville Citizen-Times |via = [[Newspapers.com]] |date = March 8, 1970 |page = 6C }} {{free access}}</ref> Chief was described as an "all around good cavalry horse" who was especially skilled at jumping and was popular and well-liked among cavalry troopers.<ref name="lansing">{{cite news |last1 = Carter |first1 = Joseph |title = Last U.S. Cavalry Horse Still Prances Like a Colt |url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/21965726/last_us_cavalry_horse_still_prances/ |access-date = July 18, 2018 |work = [[Lansing State Journal|The State Journal]] |location = Lansing, MI |agency = [[United Press International]] |via = Newspapers.com |date = November 25, 1962 |page = D20}} {{free access}}</ref> [[File:Old_Trooper_statue.jpg|thumb|right|Chief is buried at the foot of the ''Old Trooper'' statue at Fort Riley.]] [[File:Pass in review.jpg|thumb|right|Though the U.S. Army continues to field equestrian units for ceremonial purposes, Chief was the last combat cavalry charger.]] In 1941 Chief was posted to [[Fort Riley]] and assigned to the [[10th Cavalry Regiment]], though was later transferred to the [[9th Cavalry Regiment]].<ref name="neb"/> In June 1942 he was transferred, again, to the U.S. Army Cavalry School and promoted to Advanced Cavalry Charger.<ref name="neb"/>
==Retirement== At the conclusion of [[World War II]], the United States Army terminated its main equestrian training program; between 1949 and 1950, horses under age 16 were sold at auction while older horses, numbering around 100 and including Chief, were put to pasture.<ref name="neb"/><ref>{{cite news |last1 = Carter |first1 = Joseph |title = Last Cavalry Mount Lives a Life of (Fort) Riley |url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/21965740/last_cavalry_mount_lives_a_life_of/ |access-date = July 18, 2018 |work = The Courier-Journal |location = Louisville, KY |agency = United Press International |via = Newspapers.com |date = December 9, 1962 |at = §5, p. 7 }} {{free access}}</ref> Chief lived the rest of his life at the Fort Riley Riding Club where he was given a double box stall and private corral.<ref name="neb"/><ref>{{cite news |title = Possible Companion for Chief |url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/21965809/possible_companion_for_chief/ |access-date = July 18, 2018 |work = [[Albuquerque Journal]] |agency = [[Associated Press]] |via = Newspapers.com |date = July 17, 1964 |page = C1 }} {{free access}}</ref>
Chief achieved an advanced age, outliving all of the Army's other surplus cavalry chargers; he was preceded in death by [[Joe Louis (horse)|Joe Louis]] and Gambler.<ref name="jet">{{cite news |title = Cavalry Horse, Joe Louis, Dies in Kansas |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=UbcDAAAAMBAJ |work = [[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |date = December 19, 1957 |page = 50 |access-date = July 18, 2018 |via = [[Google News]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title = Old Soldier of the Cavalry Passes On |url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/21965837/old_soldier_of_the_cavalry_passes_on/ |access-date = July 18, 2018 |work = [[Manhattan Mercury]] |date = December 8, 1957 |page = 9 |via = Newspapers.com }} {{free access}}</ref> By 1962, planning had begun for his eventual funeral, though his keeper, [[Sergeant First Class]] Robert Parker, reported that year that the horse remained athletic and that many visitors guessed he was significantly younger than his actual age.<ref name="lansing"/>
==Death and funeral== Chief died on May 24, 1968 and was interred in an upright position at the base of Fort Riley's ''Old Trooper'' statue.<ref name="ap">{{cite news |title = Army Buries 'Chief', Last Cavalry Horse |url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/21965861/army_buries_chief_last_cavalry_horse/ |access-date = July 18, 2018 |work = The Racine Journal-Times Sunday Bulletin |agency = Associated Press |via = Newspapers.com |date = June 2, 1968 |page = 3A }} {{free access}}</ref> The following week, on June 1, he was given a [[military funeral]] with full honors, the ceremony attended by approximately 500 mourners.<ref name="ap"/> He is one of four horses in [[United States]] history to be buried with military honors, the others being [[Black Jack (horse)|Black Jack]], [[Sergeant Reckless|Reckless]] and [[Comanche (horse)|Comanche]].<ref>{{cite journal |last = Belcher |first = Nancy Hoyt |url = http://www.aaa.com/aaa/006/EnCompass/2004/jun/jun_GuardingHistory.html |title = Guarding History and Tradition |journal = EnCompass |volume = 78 |number = 4 |date = July–August 2004 }}</ref>
==Legacy== Chief has been credited as the last living operational cavalry mount owned by the U.S. Army.<ref name="neb"/><ref>{{cite web |last1 = Tanner |first1 = Beccy |title = Battles, Spooky Teddy Bear Help Tell Fort Riley's Storied History |url = http://www.kansascity.com/living/travel/article163604348.html |access-date = June 2, 2018 |work = [[Kansas City Star]] |date = July 25, 2017 }}</ref>
Since Chief's death, the United States Army has continued to field horse mounted units for non-combat, ceremonial purposes.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://old.qmfound.com/last_cavalry_horse_is_historic_symbol.htm |title = Last Cavalry Horse Is Historic Symbol |access-date = June 2, 2018 |via = Army Quartermaster Foundation |work = Pentagram News |location = Washington D.C. |date = March 24, 1966 }}</ref> However, the [[United States Air Force]]'s "Task Force Dagger" has engaged in horse mounted combat and the [[U.S. Marine Corps]] resumed equestrian combat training in the 2010s.<ref>{{cite news |last1 = Michaels |first1 = Jim |title = New Horsepower for War Zones: Special Forces Saddle Up |url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/06/22/horses-marines-afghanistan/10744395/ |access-date = June 2, 2018 |work = [[USA Today]] |date = June 22, 2014 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[United States Cavalry]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.kansasmemory.org/item/301/page/1 Undated photo of Chief] {{US Warhorses navbox}}

revision.comment: added [[Category:17th-century Swedish women]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Christiana Juliana Oxenstierna''' (23 September 1661 – 27 February 1701) was a Swedish [[nobility|noble]]. She was the center of a great social [[scandal]] when she married a non-noble against her family’s consent. Her case caused a debate about the law for marriage between nobles and non-nobles. == Biography == She was the daughter of statesman and marshal [[Count]] Gabriel Gabrielsson Oxenstierna (d. 1673) and Countess Maria Christiana von Löwenstein und Scharfeneck (d. 1672; in turn she was the only surviving daughter of [[Elisabet Juliana Banér|Countess Elisabeth Juliana of Erbach]] –later wife of the Swedish [[Field Marshal]] [[Johan Banér]]– in her first marriage) and sister of Count Gustaf Adolf Oxenstierna. As an [[orphan]], she was taken care of by her paternal aunt, Countess Anna af Dohna. The vicar (since 1687) of the French Lutheran church in [[Stockholm]], Nikolaus Bergius, was lodged in the [[palace]] of Dohna. Bergius suffered from severe [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and Dohna asked her niece to comfort him. Oxenstierna and Bergius fell in love and Bergius proposed, but Oxenstierna declined, as she knew she would be an outcast from her family and the nobility if she consented. Her family found out and banned every plans of a marriage. Bergius was separated from her in 1688–89. Their relationship was eventually taken up again. After a priest had agreed to conduct the ceremony, Oxenstierna and Bergius were married in 1691. The marriage was kept a secret, and she remained with her unknowing family. In 1692, she became pregnant; she moved to her spouse, and everything was made public. It became a great scandal. Her family contested the legality of the marriage, and her brother, the count, reported them to [[Hovrätt]]en, to the [[Swedish House of Lords]] and presented the [[Charles XI of Sweden|monarch]] with an appeal to bring the couple to court for committing a criminal act by breaking:
"common law, guardian law, noble privileges, the law of the church as well as Your Majesty’s law of illegal marriages", by: "having dared to harm the rank of nobility by such a illegal act, in the Kingdom as well as abroad, and damaging its privileges, of such a degree that, if it is not made an example of, would unavoidably have the scandalous effect to break the public order, that a noblewoman, regardless of what kind, should be liberated."
He also suggested that the law should be enforced against marriages between nobles and non-nobles (1693). Christiana Oxenstierna replied to her brother:
"If You wish Your hatred and persecution to last as long as our lives, so it will; You will with no doubt be spared the burden soon enough and harm Yourself as much as others; I will not loose a thing thereby. If You will be as a Christian, it will be as dear to me as the wish that you will give your children treasures which rust and moths can not alter, and that we will one day meet were a Count and a master Bergius will weigh as much."
The court of the Swedish House of Lords made the verdict that a serious crime had been committed, but as the King had commented that the matter was but a private affair, the case was not pursued further. She broke off her contact with her family and the nobility and spent the rest of her life with her spouse, spending her time as a teacher for poor children. In 1701, she died in childbirth, giving her spouse all her assets in her will, because their four children (three sons and a daughter) all died in infancy.[https://www.adelsvapen.com/genealogi/Oxenstierna_af_Korsholm_och_Wasa_nr_8 ''Grevliga ätten Oxenstierna af Korsholm och Wasa'' in: adelsvapen.com] (in Swedish) [retrieved 16 February 2016]. Her family demanded she be buried discreetly, and denied her a place in her father's [[crypt]], but as she was the only person to have repaired and taken care of the crypt, her right to be buried there could not be denied. At her funeral, "Two Countesses Oxenstierna and one Miss Banér as well as other noblewomen prepared her corpse and lifter her with their own hands in to the coffin". == In culture == In 1704, as a reply to the debate and slander which were still very much alive about her controversial person, her former spouse published her biography: ''Kort Beskrifning af then Högwälborna Frus, Fru Christina Juliana Oxenstiernas Lefwernes Lopp'' (A description of the life of the honorable lady, lady Christina Juliana Oxenstierna) (1704). It was reprinted by Pehr Adolph Sondén as: ''Minne af Christiana Juliana Oxenstjerna'' (Memory of Christina Juliana Oxenstierna) (1836). == See also == * [[Marie Grubbe]] * [[Margareta Brahe]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == References == * [http://runeberg.org/sqvinnor/0327.html] Wilhelmina Stålberg: Anteqningar om Svenska kvinnor (Notes on Swedish women) (Swedish) * [http://runeberg.org/nfbb/0776.html Nordisk familjebok / Uggleupplagan. 2. Armatoler - Bergsund] * [http://www.biblioteket.stockholm.se/default.asp?id=8227&extras=558244%2FID Minne af Christiana Juliana Oxenstjerna. Pehr Adolph Sondén (Bok) 1836] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oxenstierna, Christiana}} [[Category:1661 births]] [[Category:1701 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century Swedish people]] [[Category:Deaths in childbirth]] [[Category:Swedish countesses]] [[Category:Oxenstierna family]] [[Category:People of the Swedish Empire]] [[Category:17th-century Swedish women]]

page.title: Cleopatra Testing Poisons on Condemned Prisoners

revision.text:
{{Expand French|Cléopâtre essayant des poisons sur des condamnés à mort|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox artwork | title= Cleopatra Testing Poisons on Condemned Prisoners | image_file= Alexandre Cabanel - Cléopatre essayant des poisons sur des condamnés à mort.jpg | image_size=325px | alt= Cleopatra Testing Poisons on Condemned Prisoners | artist= [[Alexandre Cabanel]] | year= 1887 | medium= oil on canvas | height_metric= 87.6 | width_metric= 148 | museum= [[Royal Museum of Fine Arts, Antwerp|Royal Museum of Fine Arts]] | city= [[Antwerp]] }} [[File:Alexandre cabanel - cléopatre (étude).jpeg|thumb|left|Study for the painting]] '''''Cleopatra Testing Poisons on Condemned Prisoners''''' (''Cléopâtre essayant des poisons sur des condamnés à mort'') is an 1887 painting by the French artist [[Alexandre Cabanel]]. It is now in the [[Royal Museum of Fine Arts, Antwerp]]. It shows [[Cleopatra VII]] sitting at a banquet observing the effects of poisons on prisoners condemned to death.
Cabanel had always had a taste for historical and [[orientalism|orientalist]] themes and when the painting was first seen by the Parisian public he was feted by the critics and showered with honours. Several international collectors attempted to buy the painting.
[[Category:1887 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Royal Museum of Fine Arts, Antwerp]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Cleopatra]] [[Category:Deaths by poisoning]] [[Category:Paintings by Alexandre Cabanel]]

revision.comment: added maiden name
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox news event |title = |titlestyle = |image = |image_name = |image_size = |caption = |date = {{start date|df=yes|2003|10|22}} |time = 11:27 a.m. ([[Time in Australia|AEST]]; [[UTC+10:00]]) |place = [[SS Yongala|''Yongala'' wreck]]
[[Great Barrier Reef]]
[[Townsville]], [[Queensland]]
[[Australia]] |coordinates = {{coord|19|18|27|S|147|37|31|E|type:landmark_region:AU|display=inline,title}} |also known as = |cause = |participants = Tina Watson and Gabe Watson |outcome = Death by drowning |reported death(s) = Tina Watson |burial = Southern Heritage Cemetery, [[Pelham, Alabama|Pelham]], [[Alabama]], [[United States|U.S.]] |inquest = Townsville |coroner = David Robert Glasgow |suspects = Gabe Watson |charges = Murder |verdict = |convictions = [[Manslaughter]] (Australia) }} '''Tina Watson''' was a 26-year-old [[United States|American]] woman from [[Helena, Alabama|Helena]], [[Alabama]], who died while [[Recreational diving|scuba diving]] in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]], on 22 October 2003. Tina had been on her [[honeymoon]] with her new husband, fellow American Gabe Watson, who was initially charged by Queensland authorities with his wife's murder. Watson pleaded guilty to [[manslaughter]] and was sentenced to a term of imprisonment. Evidence presented at the trial included Watson's differing accounts of what had happened on that day, of the couple's diving experience (or lack thereof), and of Tina's [[life insurance]]. While Watson was serving his term in Australia, authorities in Alabama flagged an intention to charge him with murder at a later date. After his release, he was [[deportation|deported]] to Alabama on the condition that he would not be [[capital punishment|sentenced to death]] if found guilty of murder. Watson was then put on trial, but on 23 February 2012, Judge Tommy Nail dismissed the murder case due to lack of evidence. ==Background== Christina Mae "Tina" Watson (nee Thomas) was born in [[West Germany]] on 13 February 1977,{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/27816953/christina-mae-watson|title=Christina Mae “Tina” Thomas Watson (1977-2003) -...|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2018-03-03}} before relocating to the [[United States|U.S.]] while still a baby.{{Cite news|url=http://casefilepodcast.com/case-51-tina-watson/|title=Case 51: Tina Watson - Casefile: True Crime Podcast|date=2017-04-23|work=Casefile: True Crime Podcast|access-date=2018-03-02|language=en-US}} On 24 January 1980, she was legally [[adoption|adopted]] by Tommy and Cindy Thomas. They lived in [[Walker County, Alabama|Walker County]], [[Alabama]], with her younger sister before moving to [[Louisiana]] then [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]]. David Gabriel "Gabe" Watson met Tina while they were students at the [[University of Alabama at Birmingham]],{{cite news|last=Flynn|first=Asher|last2=Fitz-Gibbon|first2=Kate|title=New book A Second Chance for Justice asks new questions about the case of the "honeymoon killer" Gabe Watson|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/new-book-says-tight-justice-system-let-honeymoon-killer-gabe-watson-off-the-hook/story-fnat7jnn-1226585289574|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[Herald Sun]]|date=25 February 2013}} and they began dating in January 2001. Despite an earlier diagnosis of [[paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia]] (PSVT), Tina took beginning diving lessons in January 2003, and earned her certification just before her wedding to Gabe on 11 October 2003. Watson was a purportedly qualified certified rescue diver,{{cite news|title=Sinister twist to death on the reef|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/sinister-twist-to-death-on-the-reef/story-e6frg6nf-1111113413940|accessdate=8 November 2013|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=26 April 2007}} with experience in the lake at [[Oak Mountain State Park]]. Watson had completed 55 dives by the time of their marriage, and Tina 5. The couple had planned a scuba trip in the [[Great Barrier Reef]] for their [[honeymoon]],{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Tuck|title=Gabe Watson 'hung out and asked for hugs' on other dive boat as others tried to save Tina's life|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/gabe-watson-hung-out-and-asked-for-hugs-on-other-dive-boat-as-others-tried-to-save-tinas-life/story-e6freoof-1226272315822|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Courier-Mail|date=16 February 2012}} and flew to [[Sydney]] for a week before heading to [[Townsville]]. They chose to dive the popular yet difficult wreck of [[SS Yongala|SS ''Yongala'']], a passenger ship that sank in 1911, even though Watson had limited open ocean experience and Tina had never dived in the ocean or below 9 metres. The dive company had also offered an orientation and guided dive with a dive master, which the couple had refused. ==Incident== [[File:SS Yongala wreck.jpg|thumb|180px|A buoy marks the site of the SS ''Yongala'']] At around 10:30 am on 22 October, during an excursion from the dive boat ''Spoilsport'' to the site of ''Yongala'', Tina lost consciousness and sank to the bottom, {{convert|30|m|ft}} below the water's surface within two minutes of beginning the dive.{{cite news|last=Hewitt|first=Bill|title=Honeymoon Death Dive|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20214220,00.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=7 July 2008}} Watson claimed the currents were stronger than they expected and that he responded to a signal from Tina to return to the dive rope, where he noted a look of worry on her face before she accidentally knocked his mask and air regulator loose. When Watson recovered his sight, Tina was sinking too quickly for him to retrieve her and he quickly surfaced to get help. He also stated that an ear problem prevented him from diving deeper to help her and that there was nothing in his training as a rescue diver "about how to get somebody" in trouble to the surface.{{cite web|title=Gabe Watson's police interview |url=http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/article/2008/01/23/10038_hpnews.html |website=[[Townsville Bulletin]] |accessdate=21 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012044115/http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/article/2008/01/23/10038_hpnews.html |archivedate=12 October 2009 |date=23 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Other divers nearby at the time, including Dr. Stanley Stutz, saw Watson engaged in an underwater "[[bear hug]]" with his "flailing" wife, after which he headed for the surface while Tina fell to the ocean floor. One diver, Gary Stempler, photographed Tina by chance while taking a picture of his own wife that showed Tina in the background. The photo showed her lying face-up on the ocean floor, something that did not come to light until a couple of weeks later when the pictures were developed.{{cite news|last=Shears|first=Richard|title=Diver's dying moments captured by tourist|url=http://www.news.com.au/national-news-2/divers-dying-moments-captured-by-tourist/story-e6frfkvr-1111114932560|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[News.com.au]]|date=22 November 2007}} Watson climbed aboard the ''Spoilsport'' and alerted dive instructor Wade Singleton, who brought Tina to the surface after ten minutes underwater. She was taken aboard the adjacent dive boat ''Jazz II'', where a doctor tried to resuscitate her for 40 minutes while Watson remained on the ''Spoilsport''.''[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]'' "By the time Gabe stood trial, prosecutors noted he'd given 16 different versions of what happened", pg. 42-47, 5 September 2010 ==Investigation== The day following the death, Tina's [[autopsy]] was performed by Professor David Williams, consultant [[forensic pathologist]] to the Queensland Coroner. Williams found florid evidence of [[air embolism]], but no degenerative disease. He gave the cause of death as [[drowning]]. Due to the unexpected nature of Tina's death and the implausible and conflicting statements given by Watson, the death was investigated by the State Coroner's office. A [[coroner's inquest|coronial inquiry]] was held, as is the usual practice in Australia. Watson declined to return to Australia, so did not testify during the inquest but gave evidence through his lawyers to the inquest and to the [[Queensland Police]]. During the inquest, prosecutors submitted evidence that Watson's story contradicted the record of his actions stored by his [[dive computer]]. They suggested the possibility that he turned off Tina's regulator and held her until she was unconscious, then turned the air back on and let her sink before surfacing himself. As evidence, they described the many painstaking re-enactments of various scenarios conducted by police divers. Tina's father claimed that Watson had asked Tina, shortly before their wedding, to increase her [[life insurance]] and make him the sole beneficiary.{{cite news|last=Shears|first=Richard|title=Horrific picture of drowned diver captured in underwater tourist snap - but was it murder?|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-495274/Horrific-picture-drowned-diver-captured-underwater-tourist-snap--murder.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[Mail Online]]|date=21 November 2007}}{{cite news|last=Butler|first=Nicole|title=American charged over Barrier Reef diving death|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2008/s2281404.htm|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|PM]]|date=20 June 2008}} ===Civil action commenced in Alabama=== In March 2005, Watson launched legal action in Alabama's [[Jefferson County, Alabama|Jefferson County]] [[circuit court|Circuit Court]] to recoup the cost of the couple's trip after the travel insurance company refused a payout. He was seeking $45,000 for the accidental death plus compensation for trip interruption, medical expenses, phone calls, taxi fares, fees for extra credit card statements and unspecified punitive damages for mental and emotional anguish. The action was dismissed in May 2008 at Watson's request on the grounds the Australian investigation into his wife's death caused him "to reasonably apprehend that he risks self-incrimination in this case". His Australian legal team believed "it was not in his best interest" to pursue the damages claim and his U.S.-based lawyer, Bob Austin, added that his client would not be voluntarily "going back to Australia."{{cite news|last=Balogh|first=Stefanie|title=Gabe Watson drops action, fearing 'self-incrimination'|url=http://www.news.com.au/newstest2/archive-old-assets/scuba-husband-drops-honeymoon-claim/story-e6frfkyi-1111116394050|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=News.com.au|date=21 May 2008}} ==Indictment== On 19 June 2008, the Coroner laid the following charge:
That on the 22nd day of October 2003 at the site of the historical shipwreck ''Yongala'' forty-eight nautical miles south east from the port of Townsville in the state of Queensland, David Gabriel Watson murdered Christina Mae Watson.
It was reported that the Coroner found "[it was likely ] that Watson [had] killed his 26-year-old wife by turning off her air supply and holding her in an 'underwater bear hug' until she was dead";{{Cite news|url=http://www.thewest.com.au/aapstory.aspx?StoryName=524905|title=US diver accused of killing wife in Qld|date=24 October 2008|work=thewest.com.au|accessdate=21 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029032838/http://www.thewest.com.au/aapstory.aspx?StoryName=524905|archivedate=29 October 2008|df=dmy-all}} however, the coroner had made no such finding.{{cite web|title=Inquest into the death of Christina Mae WATSON known as Tina WATSON|url=http://www.courts.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/86727/cif-watson-cm-20080424.pdf|work=[[Coroners Court of Queensland]]|publisher=Queensland Courts|date=20 June 2008|accessdate=3 November 2013|location=Townsville|format=PDF}} ==Trial and sentence in Australia== {{Infobox criminal | name = Gabe Watson | image_name = | image_size = | image_caption = | birth_name = David Gabriel Watson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1977|3|5}} | alias = | motive = | charge = [[Murder]] | conviction = [[Manslaughter]] | conviction_penalty = 4.5 years, to be suspended after 1.5 years | conviction_status = Released and deported | occupation = Salesman | spouse = Tina Thomas (2003 [11 days]); her death
Kim Lewis (2008-present) | parents = David and Glenda Watson}} After resisting [[extradition]] for six months, Watson travelled voluntarily from the U.S. to Australia in May 2009 to face trial. At the trial on 5 June 2009, he pleaded not guilty to murder and guilty to, and was convicted of, [[manslaughter]]. [[Crown prosecutor]] Brendan Campbell pointed out that over time Watson had given police sixteen different versions of what had happened to Tina and that none of those versions matched what the only eyewitness had seen. When Tina was brought to the surface, her regulator was still in her mouth, her tank still had air, and tests indicated no faults with her equipment. Campbell described Watson as an experienced diver trained in rescuing panicked divers, who had allowed his wife to sink to the ocean floor without making any serious attempt to retrieve her. Watson did not inflate Tina's [[buoyancy control device]] (BCD) or remove her [[weight belt]], and had failed to fulfill his obligations as her "dive buddy" by not sharing his alternative air source. Watson was sentenced to four and a half years in prison, to be suspended after serving only twelve months. ===Reaction to the sentence=== Tina's family stated that Watson's twelve-month term was an embarrassment to Australia.{{cite news|last=Bentley|first=Amelia|title=Honeymoon scuba killer's 12-month sentence 'ludicrous'|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/honeymoon-scuba-killers-12month-sentence-ludicrous-20090605-bxsh.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[The Age]]|date=5 June 2009}} The day following the trial, [[Attorney General of Alabama|Alabama Attorney General]] [[Troy King]] lodged an [[appeal]] with the [[Queensland Supreme Court]] and also wrote to [[Queensland Attorney-General]] [[Cameron Dick]]. [[Fairfax Media]] reported that the letter was leaked to them and published part of it in their newspapers.{{cite news|last=Duff|first=Eamonn|last2=Bachelard|first2=Michael|title=US challenges killer husband wrist-slap|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/us-challenges-killer-husband-wristslap-20090606-bz7r.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Age|date=7 June 2009}} The Queensland [[Director of Public Prosecutions]], Tony Moynihan SC, issued a statement, which said: "The decision to accept Mr Watson's plea of guilty to manslaughter was made after a careful and thorough examination of the admissible evidence, and was not taken lightly. Given the complex circumstantial nature of the case, Mr Watson's admission that he breached his duty to render assistance to his wife ultimately meant there was no reasonable prospect of proving, beyond a reasonable doubt, that he was guilty of murder."{{cite news|last=Kellett|first=Christine|title=We couldn't prove it: DPP|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/we-couldnt-prove-it-dpp-20090609-c1v4.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=9 June 2009}} On 18 June 2009, Dick announced the state would appeal against the inadequacy of Watson's sentence.{{cite news|title=Honeymoon killer appeal: father's thanks|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/honeymoon-killer-appeal-fathers-thanks-20090618-cij9.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=18 June 2009|agency=Australian Associated Press}} ===Appeal=== The appeal was heard by the Queensland Court of Appeals on 17 July 2009. The Crown asked the court to increase Watson's prison term to two and a half years. The [[defense (law)|defence]] argued that Watson had had a momentary lapse in judgment, had been accused of a crime he did not commit, and had voluntarily returned to Australia to co-operate with the court, and that the penalty imposed by the trial judge was fair and just.{{cite news|last=Oberhardt|first=Mark|title=Judge too soft in Gabe Watson sentencing, says solicitor-general|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/judge-too-soft-in-gabe-watson-sentencing-says-solicitor-general/story-e6freon6-1225751415990|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]]|date=17 July 2009}} The findings on appeal were handed down on 18 September 2009. Two members allowed the prosecution's appeal, increasing Watson's period of incarceration by six months to a total of eighteen. One justice by minority opinion was in favour of dismissing the appeal.{{cite news|last=Calligeros|first=Marissa|title=Jail term extended for honeymoon dive killer|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/jail-term-extended-for-honeymoon-dive-killer-20090918-fu8c.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=18 September 2009}} ==Further incidents== Tina was buried in her native Pelham, [[Alabama]]. Her remains were [[exhumation|exhumed]] in 2007 and moved to a different lot bought by Watson.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article4818156.ece|title=Tina Watson: the bride who drowned at the Barrier Reef|last=Ham|first=Paul|date=28 September 2008|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|accessdate=2 February 2010|location=London}} {{registration required}} After being informed by her family that flowers and gifts were repeatedly being vandalized or disappearing from the grave site, even when chained down, police surveillance videos showed Watson removing them with bolt cutters and throwing them in trash cans.{{cite news | url=http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/article/2008/01/25/10097_news.html | newspaper=Townsville Bulletin | title= Caught on film | first=Andy | last=Toulson | date=25 January 2008 | accessdate=19 June 2013 }} Watson later said he removed them because they were "big, gaudy, plastic arrangements".{{cite news|title=Why I took flowers from Tina's grave: Honeymoon killer Gabe Watson breaks silence on US TV|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/honeymoon-death-gabe-watson-breaks-silence-on-us-tv/story-e6freoof-1226285885608|accessdate=4 November 2013|newspaper=The Courier-Mail|date=1 March 2012|agency=Australian Associated Press}} Her grave was unmarked until 2009, when Watson provided a [[Footstone|foot marker]], prompting her father to request her body be returned for reburial. In 2011, the Probate Court removed Watson as administrator of Tina's estate and appointed her father, who also wants her school and college pictures and yearbooks returned. Watson has appealed against the ruling and refused to provide the court with an inventory of Tina's possessions. Pending Watson's trial, the [[Alabama Circuit Courts|Alabama Circuit Court]] ordered him to stay away from the grave.{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Tuck|title='Honeymoon killer' Gabe Watson refuses to hand over Tina Thomas' body|url=http://www.news.com.au/national-news-2/killer-refuses-to-hand-over-tinas-body/story-e6frfkvr-1226092718403|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=News.com.au|date=12 July 2011}} ==Trial in United States== ===Alabama investigation=== In May 2010, King announced he had information not yet made public and wanted to try Watson for [[capital murder]], asserting jurisdiction based on the theory that the alleged crime was planned in Alabama.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/02/23/justice/alabama-honeymoon-trial/|title=Murder case dismissed in death of newlywed wife}} King petitioned Australia for the evidence held by police, but was refused access until he gave an undertaking that the death penalty would not be imposed, as required under Australian law. This condition has been strongly criticised by King and Don Valeska, chief of the Attorney General's violent crime division, who stated: "If an Australian woman was killed here, we would immediately send the evidence there. We would not presume to tell the Australian authorities how to run their criminal justice system".{{cite news|url=http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2010/02/post_436.html|title=Australian DA wants no death penalty if charges filed here in honeymoon death|last=Thomas-Ogle|first=Marienne|date=9 February 2010|work=[[The Birmingham News]]|accessdate=11 May 2010}} In response to the announcement, Watson's parents came to the defence of their son, breaking their public silence on the case. Friends and family of Watson questioned whether he had any motive for the murder, noting that his affection for Tina had seemed genuine, there was no life insurance policy naming him as beneficiary, and he appeared to be emotionally devastated for an extended time following her death.{{cite news|url=http://blog.al.com/spotnews/2010/05/gabe_watsons_family_speaks_7_y.html|title=Gabe Watson's family speaks 7 years after his wife, Tina Watson, drowned on Australian honeymoon|last=Robinson|first=Carol|date=9 May 2010|work=The Birmingham News|accessdate=11 May 2010}} In June 2010, King assured the Queensland Attorney-General he would not seek the death penalty if Watson was tried in the U.S. for his wife's death.{{cite news|title=US rules out death penalty for honeymoon dive killing|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/us-rules-out-death-penalty-for-honeymoon-dive-killing-20100629-zjcg.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=30 June 2010|agency=Associated Press}} In August 2010 it was announced Watson would be released in November and was likely to be deported to the US, where he faced being charged with murder. Valeska stated he would pursue an additional charge of kidnapping by deception.{{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/honeymoon-killer-may-face-new-charge-20100814-123or.html|title=Honeymoon killer may face new charge|last=Martin|first=Lisa|date=14 August 2010|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=15 August 2010}} The case was placed before a grand jury in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], in October 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/world/date-set-in-honeymoon-dive-killer-case/story-e6frev00-1225935506842|title=Date set in honeymoon dive killer case|last=Paul|first=Nathan|date=7 October 2010|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=7 October 2010}} Watson was released from prison on 10 November 2010. He was transferred to an [[Australian immigration detention facilities|immigration detention centre]] while his deportation was delayed.{{cite news|title=Honeymoon killer Gabe Watson heads to Melbourne|url=http://www.news.com.au/national-news-2/honeymoon-killer-gabe-watson-released-from-jail-in-queensland/story-e6frfkvr-1225951669938|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=News.com.au|date=11 November 2010|agency=Australian Associated Press}} During this time, Australian authorities sought further written assurances from the US Attorney General that he would not face the death penalty in Alabama if convicted of murder. Under international human rights law, Australia could not deport Watson if he faced execution in his home country.{{cite news|title=Australia in dilemma over deportation of Honeymoon Killer to the U.S.|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/australia-dilemma-over-deportation-honeymoon-killer-us-246954|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=11 November 2010}} On 25 November 2010 he was deported to the United States and immediately arrested.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/honeymoon-killer-gabe-watson-leaves-australia-20101125-187sg.html|title=Honeymoon killer Gabe Watson leaves Australia|last=Calligeros|first=Marissa|date=25 November 2010|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=25 November 2010}} ===Arrest=== Alabama prosecutors charged Gabe with murder at the conclusion of his prison sentence in Australia after finding what they claimed was evidence he had plotted to kill his wife while still in the United States.{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/great-barrier-reef-honeymoon-dive-killer-in-us-kill-plot-20090609-c1av.html|title=Great Barrier Reef honeymoon dive killer 'in US kill plot'|last=Kellett|first=Christine|date=9 June 2009|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=9 June 2009}} A Birmingham grand jury indicted Watson on murder charges in October 2010. In July 2011, the Circuit Court set the trial date for 13 February 2012; Watson was released on bond.{{cite news|last=Thompson|first=Tuck|title=Gabe Watson to go to trial in February 2012 in Alabama charged with murdering wife Tina|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/world/honeymoon-killer-gabe-watson-to-go-to-trial-in-february-2012-in-alabama-charged-with-murdering-wife-tina/story-e6frea8l-1226093499022|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Advertiser|date=13 July 2011}} ===New evidence=== Colin McKenzie, a key diving expert in the original investigation who had maintained that "a diver with Watson's training should have been able to bring Tina up", subsequently retracted much of his testimony after being provided with Tina and Gabe's diver logs, certificates and medical histories, to which he had not previously had access. McKenzie claimed Gabe should not have been allowed in the water and never as a dive buddy for his wife, who had no open water scuba experience. Tina had heart surgery to correct an irregular heartbeat two years earlier but on her dive application had stated that she had never had heart problems or surgery. Professor Michael "Mike" Bennett, a leading expert in [[Diving medicine|dive medicine]], stated that Tina was unfit to dive without clearance from a cardiologist. Gabe had received his [[Rescue Diver|rescue certification]], normally a four-day course, after completing a two-day course in an Alabama quarry. He had no rescue experience and little open water experience.{{cite news|last=Patrick|first=Peter|title=Death at 27 metres|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/death-at-27-metres-20110421-1dqgf.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Age|date=22 April 2011}}{{cite news|title=Watson a 'coward but not a killer'|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/watson-a-coward-but-not-a-killer-20110422-1dr35.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Age|date=22 April 2011|agency=Australian Associated Press}} According to McKenzie, "He had no hope of being competent, he could barely save himself [that day] let alone his wife; I don't believe he intended to kill her." Revelations that Watson needed help to don his diving equipment that day underscored that he was a "dangerous amateur" who showed "a complete lack of courage" when he abandoned his wife. The dive company had offered an orientation and guided dive with a dive master, which both Tina and Gabe had refused. Company head Mike Ball said his people took Watson at his word, believing he was an experienced and certified rescue diver. The company later pleaded guilty to contravening safety standards (their code of conduct said both Gabe and Tina must be supervised by at least a [[divemaster]] on the dive in question) and was fined $6,500, plus costs of $1,500. ===Dismissal of the case=== Alabama judge Tommy Nail ruled that evidence of Watson's behaviour following Tina's death was inadmissible. Nail also blocked Tina's father from giving evidence regarding Watson's alleged attempts to increase Tina's life insurance. On 23 February 2012, Nail acquitted Gabe for lack of evidence without the defence needing to present its case. Nail said that the state's evidence was "sorely lacking" and that the prosecution could not prove that Watson had any financial motive. Prosecutor Don Valeska said that this was the first time he had had a trial end in a judge's acquittal in the 41 years he had been trying cases. Regarding the judge's decision, Thomas said, "It should have gone to the jury for them to decide."{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Rick|title=Murder case dismissed in death of newlywed wife|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/02/23/justice/alabama-honeymoon-trial/index.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=24 February 2012}}Jay Reeves. "Husband's acquittal in drowning unexpected", ''[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]]'', 25 February 2012, pg. 64 ==In media== A feature on the death of Tina Watson was broadcast in a 90-minute account that aired on ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' on 19 May 2008.{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/24713499/ | title=Mystery in the deep blue sea | work=Dateline | publisher=NBC | accessdate=19 June 2013 | date=19 May 2008 | first=Dennis | last=Murphy }} An examination of Tina's death and Gabe's subsequent trial and appeal was published by ''[[The Age]]'' on 17 July 2010. The author was [[Walkley Award]] winning investigative journalist, Peter Patrick.{{cite news|last=Patrick|first=Peter|title=Death on reef mystery|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/death-on-reef-mystery-20100716-10eb1.html|accessdate=23 October 2013|newspaper=The Age|date=17 July 2010}} A feature on the death of Watson and her husband's Alabama acquittal was broadcast on an episode of the Australian ''[[60 Minutes (Australian TV program)|60 Minutes]]'' on 25 March 2012. [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] produced a made-for-TV movie, ''[[Fatal Honeymoon]]'', based on the death of Tina Watson, starring [[Harvey Keitel]], [[Billy Miller (actor)|Billy Miller]] and [[Amber Clayton]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2012/08/lifetime_movie_fatal_honeymoon.html|title=Lifetime movie ''Fatal Honeymoon'' takes on story of Gabe and Tina Watson (video)}} It premiered on 25 August 2012. Tina Watson's death was explored on ''[[Casefile True Crime Podcast]]'' (Case 51) which was published on 22 April 2017. ==References== {{Portal|2000s}} {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Simpson|first=Lindsay|title=Honeymoon dive|year=2010|publisher=Pan Macmillan|isbn=978-1-4050-4012-9|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/37288175?|author2=Cooke, Jennifer }} *Tina Watson Death - [http://www.michaelmcfadyenscuba.info/viewpage.php?page_id=791 Michael McFadyen's Scuba Diving Web Site] ==External links== *[http://www.courts.qld.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0003/86727/cif-watson-cm-20080424.pdf Inquest into the death of Christina Mae Watson known as Tina Watson] *[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/24713499// Mystery in the deep blue sea - NBC Dateline transcript] *[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article4818156.ece Tina Watson: the bride who drowned at the Barrier Reef - The Sunday Times] *[http://www.smh.com.au/national/princess-bride-feared-being-left-on-shelf-20090619-cmcm.html 'Princess bride' feared being left on shelf - The Sydney Morning Herald] *[http://www.smh.com.au/national/death-down-under-20100716-10e6t.html Death Down Under - The Sydney Morning Herald] *[http://www.abc.net.au/austory/specials/unfathomableone/default.htm Unfathomable - Australian Story] *[http://memorialwebsites.legacy.com/tinamaethomas/homepage.aspx Obituary at Legacy.com] *[http://tinasstory.googlepages.com/ Tina's Story] - a collection of news articles up to 2009 *[http://casefilepodcast.com/case-51-tina-watson/ Casefile True Crime Podcast - Case 51: Tina Watson] - 22 April 2017 {{DEFAULTSORT:Watson, Death of Tina}} [[Category:2003 crimes in Australia]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:American manslaughter victims]] [[Category:Australia–United States relations]] [[Category:Crime in Queensland]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:Manslaughter in Australia]] [[Category:People from Helena, Alabama]] [[Category:October 2003 events]] [[Category:Underwater diving deaths]]
