{{Infobox Officeholder | name = Jamal Uddin Ahmad | image = | order = | office = [[Deputy Prime Minister of Bangladesh]] | term_start = 1977 | term_end = 1982 | predecessor= ? | successor = ? | primeminister = [[Mashiur Rahman (politician from Rangpur)|Mashiur Rahman]]
[[Shah Azizur Rahman]] | birth_date = c. 1929 | birth_place= | death_date = January 3, 2015 | death_place= [[Baridhara]], [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] | alma_mater = | profession = [[Accountant]]
University administrator | residence = [[Baridhara]], [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] | spouse = | party = }} '''Jamal Uddin Ahmad''' (c. 1929 – January 3, 2015) was a [[Bangladesh]]i [[politician]] and [[accountant]]. He served as the [[Deputy Prime Minister]] of Bangladesh from 1977 until 1982.{{cite news|first= |last=|title=Former deputy prime minister Jamal Uddin Ahmad dies |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/01/04/former-deputy-prime-minister-jamal-uddin-ahmad-dies |work=[[Bdnews24.com]] |date=2015-01-14 |accessdate=2015-01-04}} He also served as the former President of the [[South Asian Federation of Accountants]], as well as the President of the Institute of Chartered Accountants of Bangladesh (ICAB) for two terms. In 1954, Ahmad received a [[master's degree]] in [[commerce]] from the [[University of Dhaka]]. Ahmad died at his home in the [[Baridhara]] neighborhood in [[Dhaka]] at approximately 10 p.m. on January 3, 2015, at the age of 85. His first funeral prayer was held at the Gulshan Azad Mosque in [[Gulshan Thana]] with burial at a family cemetery in [[Daulatpur union]], [[Fatikchhari Upazila]], [[Chittagong District]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmad, Jamal Uddin}} [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Deputy Prime Ministers of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Bangladeshi accountants]] [[Category:University of Dhaka alumni]] [[Category:People from Dhaka]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]]

revision.comment: link to state party, replaced: [[Australian Labor Party| → [[Australian Labor Party (New South Wales Branch)| using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox Politician |honorific-prefix = |name = John Beveridge |honorific-suffix =[[Justice of the Peace|JP]] | image = John Beveridge JP Alderman for Redfern 1889.jpg | office = 15th [[Municipality of Redfern|Mayor of Redfern]] | term_start = 12 February 1891 | term_end = 29 May 1891 | predecessor = [[Thomas Clarke (New South Wales politician)|Thomas Clarke]] | successor = George Howe | office1 = [[Alderman]] on the [[Municipality of Redfern|Redfern Municipal Council]] | term_start1 = 20 September 1886 | term_end1 = 29 May 1891 | predecessor1 = [[Francis Augustus Wright]] | successor1 = [[William Poole (Australian politician)|William Poole]] | constituency1 = Belmore Ward | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1848|08|08}} | birth_place = [[Windsor, New South Wales|Windsor]], [[New South Wales|Colony of New South Wales]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1916|03|15|1848|08|08}} | death_place = [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]], New South Wales, Australia | party = [[Free Trade Party]] | relations = | spouse = Priscilla Wright (1853–1929) | children = | residence = | occupation = Merchant and businessman | alma_mater = | religion = Presbyterian | signature = }} '''John Beveridge''', [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] (8 August 1848{{spaced ndash}}15 March 1916) was a New South Wales businessman, sportsman and local government politician, who served as an Alderman (1886–1891) and [[Municipality of Redfern|Mayor of Redfern]] (1891).
==Early life and background== Beveridge was born 8 August 1848 in the town of [[Windsor, New South Wales|Windsor]], [[New South Wales|Colony of New South Wales]]. He was the son of John Beveridge, a baker and [[Confectionery|confectioner]], and Jane Greig, who as assisted migrants had emigrated from [[Kirkcaldy]], [[Fife]], [[Scotland]], to Sydney on 16 January 1839. At the age of 19, Beveridge entered the mercantile firm of ''George Griffiths and Co.'' in 1867. On 8 August 1871 he was married to Priscilla Wright, the [[Anglo-Irish]] daughter of teacher and later principal of the [[Sydney Teachers College|Fort Street Training School]] John Wright (1822–1887),<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13657570 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=24 May 1887 |accessdate=15 April 2015 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> at St Andrew's Presbyterian Church, Sydney, by the Rev. Robert Lewers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13243090 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=14 August 1871 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref name=ISN>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63621940 |title=Leaders in Our Mercantile World. |newspaper=[[Illustrated Sydney News]] |date=22 August 1889 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Beveridge and his wife Priscilla had seven children: John Stuart (1872–1874),<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13339415 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=20 November 1874 |accessdate=15 April 2015 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> [[Percy Beveridge|Percy]] (1875–1947), Mabel (1878–1955), Harry (1882–1943), Violet (1886–1975), Cecil (1888–1946)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22252748 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=22 June 1946 |accessdate=18 April 2015 |page=20 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and Roy Stuart (1893–1916). In 1880 he was made a partner in the firm, and on the retirement of Griffiths became the owner, which specialised in "wholesale grocery and general merchandise" from its premises on the corner of [[Bridge Street, Sydney|Bridge]] and Young streets, Sydney.<ref name=ISN/>
A prominent member of the flourishing business community in Sydney and Redfern, Beveridge became involved as a member of the [[Sydney Chamber of Commerce]] and as a director of the Mortgage, Guarantee and Mercantile Finance Corporation of New South Wales, the Sydney Real Estate Bank and the Australian Traders' Fire Insurance Company.<ref name=ISN/> Beveridge also became a member of the Redfern Branch of the [[Free Trade Party|Free Trade Association]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13697600 |title=MEETINGS. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=24 September 1888 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> A keen sportsman, Beveridge was a member of the Cricket Union (vice-president in 1889) and was instrumental in the development of the Surry United Cricket Club, being captain from 1879 (now the Surry Hills Cricket Club).<ref name=ISN/>
==Public service== Beveridge eventually stood for office as a free trader and became an [[alderman]] unopposed on [[Municipality of Redfern|Redfern Municipal Council]] for Belmore Ward on 20 September 1886, filling a vacancy created by the departure of Alderman [[Francis Augustus Wright]], and was re-elected in February 1888.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13642295 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|location=NSW |date=21 September 1886 |accessdate=1 February 2016 |page=14 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13672542 |title=THE MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS AND NOMINATIONS. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=8 February 1888 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article222438175 |title=BOROUGH OF REDFERN. |newspaper=New South Wales Government Gazette |issue=550 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=28 September 1886 |accessdate=2 June 2016 |page=6578 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In September 1888 he presided over a meeting at [[Redfern Town Hall]] to support the ultimately-unsuccessful candidacy of free trader John Martin for a by-election to the [[New South Wales Legislative Assembly]] seat of [[Electoral district of Redfern|Redfern]]; the meeting was attended by [[Henry Parkes|Sir Henry Parkes]] who also spoke in support.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13695695 |title=REDFERN ELECTION. ADDRESS BY MR. J. A. MARTIN. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=5 September 1888 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=12 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Beveridge strongly aligned himself with the politics of Parkes and later stood for the seat of Redfern himself as a Free Trade candidate at the [[New South Wales colonial election, 1889|1889 colonial election]], but was unsuccessful, missing out by a margin of over 100 votes, despite the overall success of the Free Trade movement at that election, with Parkes forming government.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13712311 |title=Advertising |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |issue=15,868 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=30 January 1889 |accessdate=22 May 2018 |page=12 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13712655 |title=Advertising |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |issue=15,870 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=1 February 1889 |accessdate=22 May 2018 |page=13 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Green |first1=Antony |title=NSW Elections – Redfern 1889 |url=https://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/resources/nswelectionsanalysis/1889/Redfern.htm |website=NSW Elections Index |publisher=Parliament of New South Wales |accessdate=27 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150826001442/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/resources/nswelectionsanalysis/1889/Redfern.htm |archivedate=26 August 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13712299 |title=THE REDFERN ELECTORATE. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=30 January 1889 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article160793841 |title=THE ELECTIONS IN NEW SOUTH WALES. |newspaper=[[Adelaide Observer]] |location=SA |date=9 February 1889 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=37 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Even so, on 12 June 1890 he was appointed to the Redfern Sub-District Public School Board by the Governor [[Charles Wynn-Carington, 1st Marquess of Lincolnshire|Lord Carrington]], on the advice of Free Trader Minister for Public Instruction, [[Joseph Carruthers]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article219922146 |title=PUBLIC SCHOOL BOARDS. |newspaper=[[New South Wales Government Gazette]] |issue=316 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=13 June 1890 |accessdate=29 May 2016 |page=4632 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
On 12 February 1891 Beveridge was elected to be mayor of the council and was instrumental in making Redfern the first suburb in Sydney to have electricity and electric street lighting, which occurred when the Council voted unanimously in 1891, following the recommendations of the improvements committee, to build its own power station in Turner Street to power the suburb.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article114311716 |title=Advertising |newspaper=Evening News |issue=7376 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=15 January 1891 |accessdate=22 May 2018 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13814379 |title=REDFERN. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=18 February 1891 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113884043 |title=A Redfern Loan. |newspaper=[[The Evening News (Sydney)|The Evening News]]|location=Sydney |date=24 April 1891 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Beveridge then proposed and passed through council a loan of £50,000 for the purpose.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article235888446 |title=A REDFERN BOROUGH LOAN. |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |issue=3688 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=24 April 1891 |accessdate=22 May 2018 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article235877997 |title=THE PROPOSED REDFERN LOAN. |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |issue=3691 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=28 April 1891 |accessdate=22 May 2018 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> This movement by the council was later affirmed and protected by the [[Parliament of New South Wales]] when it passed the ''Borough of Redfern Electric Lighting Act 1895''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Borough of Redfern Electric Lighting Act 1895|url=http://www5.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/num_act/borela1895nb376.pdf|website=austlii.edu.au|publisher=Australasian Legal Information Institute|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref>
However, by May 1891 Beveridge had resigned as mayor and an alderman for Redfern prior to his candidacy for the [[New South Wales colonial election, 1891|1891 election]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113882008 |title=Resignation of the Mayor of Redfern. |newspaper=[[The Evening News (Sydney)|The Evening News]]|location=Sydney |date=30 May 1891 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> His vacancy in Belmore Ward was subsequently filled by [[William Poole (Australian politician)|William Poole]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article222097361 |title=BOROUGH OF REDFERN. |newspaper=New South Wales Government Gazette |issue=397 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=23 June 1891 |accessdate=2 June 2016 |page=4632 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Beveridge stood again as a Free Trade candidate for Redfern, reaffirming his support for the Free Trade vision for [[Australian Federation]] and noting that overall wages in New South Wales were higher compared to Victoria and taxation was lower owing to the Free Trade system in NSW, a system "that is best for the commercial interests of the colony."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13828422 |title=REDFERN. THE FREETRADE BUNCH. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=17 June 1891 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Beveridge was however again unsuccessful at the June election which saw the Free Traders lose out to the [[Australian Labor Party (New South Wales Branch)|Labor Party]] and the [[Protectionist Party|Protectionists]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Green |first1=Antony |title=NSW Elections – Redfern 1891 |url=https://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/resources/nswelectionsanalysis/1891/Redfern.htm |website=NSW Elections Index |publisher=Parliament of New South Wales |accessdate=27 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150826001528/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/resources/nswelectionsanalysis/1891/Redfern.htm |archivedate=26 August 2015 |df= }}</ref>
==Later life== Following this defeat, Beveridge returned to business, taking up a high-ranking position in the Sydney office of the [[New York Life Insurance Company]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article66444966 |title=News in Brief. |newspaper=Windsor and Richmond Gazette|location=NSW |date=13 October 1894 |accessdate=9 October 2015 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> On 25 November 1891, Beveridge sold his merchandise business, ''George Griffiths and Co.'' to David Cohen and Company.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article219925564 |title=Transfer of Trade-mark (registered No. 3,533) under sec. 6 of Trade-marks Act 28 Vic. No. 9. |newspaper=[[New South Wales Government Gazette]] |issue=751 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=27 November 1891 |accessdate=29 May 2016 |page=9344 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Beveridge nevertheless retained his keen interest in the Free Trade movement and in politics generally, including presiding over the election committee for [[John Neild]]'s unsuccessful bid for the seat of [[Electoral district of Woollahra|Woollahra]] at the [[New South Wales colonial election, 1894|1894 election]] (he lost to [[Adrian Knox]], standing as an 'Independent Free Trade' candidate).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13954208 |title=WOOLLAHRA ELECTORATE. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=6 June 1894 |accessdate=30 March 2015 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> [[George Reid (Australian politician)|George Reid]]'s Free traders were successful at that election and Beveridge, in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald, noted: "the vote of last Tuesday must inspire every thinking man in the community with the idea that the people are ripe for the establishment of a progressive policy, and I believe Mr Reid is the man for the hour."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13961124 |title=THE NEXT PARLIAMENT. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=24 July 1894 |accessdate=30 March 2015 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
===Lithgow=== By 1896, Beveridge had opened his own retail business in the rural and mining town of [[Lithgow]] and involved himself in various community activities, including in cricket. Reporting on his attendance at a Lithgow reception for Premier Reid in May 1896, the ''[[Windsor and Richmond Gazette]]'' noted: "no doubt, ere long Mr. [Beveridge] will take a leading part in matters connected with the welfare of the town, for he is too good a man to be allowed to stay long in clover. His ability is already recognised in his new home, and a matter of a few months will decide whether he enters the Municipal arena or not. If he does, Lithgow will be the gainer."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article72548695 |title=TOPICS OF THE DAY. |newspaper=Windsor and Richmond Gazette|location=NSW |date=23 May 1896 |accessdate=9 October 2015 |page=1 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In early 1896 Beveridge nominated to take up a vacancy on Lithgow Ward on [[City of Lithgow|Lithgow Municipal Council]], but received only 6 votes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14036705 |title=MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS. |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=NSW |date=10 February 1896 |accessdate=25 January 2016 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The next year he stood again for Lithgow Ward but lost by one vote.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article108865231 |title=MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS. |newspaper=[[Empire (newspaper)|Evening News]] |location=Sydney, NSW |date=8 February 1897 |accessdate=25 January 2016 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Beveridge became heavily involved in local cricket circles, donating the "Beveridge Cup" for district matches, and becoming President of the Lithgow District Cricket Association in 1899; the patron of the association that year was prominent local politician [[Joseph Cook]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71333288 |title=Country Clubs. |newspaper=[[Australian Town and Country Journal]] |location=Sydney, NSW |date=9 September 1899 |accessdate=25 January 2016 |page=52 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
A supporter of [[Federation of Australia|Australian Federation]], Beveridge was nominated to attend the People's Federal Convention at [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]] in November 1896, which had convened to discuss the 1891 draft Constitution being proposed for the Commonwealth of Australia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article156708966 |title=People's Federal Convention. |newspaper=[[The National advocate|National Advocate (Bathurst, NSW : 1889 - 1954)]] |location=Bathurst, NSW |date=18 November 1896 |accessdate=9 October 2015 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The most important recommendation made by the convention was that the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] should be directly-elected. In December 1897, Beveridge established the Lithgow Land, Building, and Investment Company and became a company director.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article108875515 |title=LITHGOW ITEMS. |newspaper=Evening News|location=Sydney, NSW |date=7 December 1897 |accessdate=9 October 2015 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> As a longstanding [[Justice of the Peace]], on 23 January 1899 Beveridge was appointed by Governor [[Henry Brand, 2nd Viscount Hampden|Lord Hampden]], on the recommendation of Minister for Justice [[Charles Lee (Australian politician)|Charles Lee]], as [[Coroner]] for Lithgow and for the colony at large.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28250079 |title=GOVERNMENT GAZETTE. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=25 January 1899 |accessdate=31 March 2015 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article220989471 |title=Government Gazette Appointments and Employment |newspaper=[[New South Wales Government Gazette]] |issue=72 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=24 January 1899 |accessdate=29 May 2016 |page=643 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
===Hay=== By 1901, Beveridge had moved again to the Riverina town of [[Hay, New South Wales|Hay]], and opened his own general merchandise store, "''Beveridge & Co.''", in the town.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article140157722 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[The Riverine Grazier]] |issue=3452 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=16 May 1902 |accessdate=30 March 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> It was not long before Beveridge again returned to Cricketing circles, gaining much respect in the Hay Cricket Association, later serving as vice-president, and rising to be President of the Hay Chamber of Commerce in 1901.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article144653851 |title=Hay Chamber of Commerce. |newspaper=[[Riverina Times, Hay Standard and Journal of Water Conservation]] |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=10 October 1901 |accessdate=30 March 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In February 1901, Beveridge was elected as Honorary Secretary at the inaugural meeting of the Hay Free Trade Association and later assisting in the campaign of Free Trade candidate [[James Ashton (politician)|James Ashton]] for the seat of [[Division of Riverina|Riverina]] at the [[Australian federal election, 1901|first federal election]] a month later.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article143538934 |title=FREETRADE. |newspaper=The Riverine Grazier |issue=3340 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=22 February 1901 |accessdate=30 March 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article143542414 |title=THE FEDERAL ELECTION. |newspaper=The Riverine Grazier|issue=3349 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=29 March 1901 |accessdate=30 March 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In May 1902 Beveridge departed Hay for a visit to [[London]] for the [[Coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article86218656 |title=FROM WEEK TO WEEK. |newspaper=Windsor and Richmond Gazette|location=NSW |date=10 May 1902 |accessdate=9 October 2015 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article144657851 |title=WISHING MR J. BEVERIDGE BON VOYAGE. |newspaper=Riverina Times, Hay Standard and Journal of Water Conservation |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=10 March 1902 |accessdate=30 March 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
===Return to Sydney=== After moving back to Sydney with his family, in later years he served as the general manager of the Merchants' and Traders' Employment Bureau, which his brother Peter had purchased in July 1908.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article85864250 |title=FROM WEEK TO WEEK. |newspaper=[[Windsor and Richmond Gazette]] |location=NSW |date=25 July 1908 |accessdate=29 March 2015 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The Bureau's offices were sited within the New York Mutual Life Building at 14 [[Martin Place]], Sydney.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sands Sydney, Suburban and Country Commercial Directory|url=http://cdn.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/learn/history/archives/sands/1910-1919/1913-part18.pdf|publisher=City of Sydney|accessdate=7 December 2015|date=1913}}</ref> Beveridge moved with his family to a new residence, "Violet" in Balfour Road, [[Kensington, New South Wales|Kensington]], but in later years his health suffered greatly owing to "acute heart trouble", which led to his death aged 67 on 15 March 1916.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15655339 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=17 March 1916 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article121178683 |title=DEATH OF MR. JOHN BEVERIDGE. |newspaper=[[The Referee (newspaper)|The Referee]]|location=Sydney |date=22 March 1916 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=12 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> His youngest son [[Lance sergeant]] Roy Stuart Beveridge ([[20th Battalion (Australia)|20th Battalion]]) was later killed in action following the [[Battle of Flers]] in France on 12 November 1916.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15688792 |title=WAR CASUALTIES. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=15 December 1916 |accessdate=28 March 2015 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>The battlefield conditions were so muddy that they were described by the official historian, [[Charles Bean]], as "the worst ever encountered by the AIF".{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11207.asp|title=20th Battalion |work=First World War, 1914–1918 units|publisher=Australian War Memorial}}</ref> His eldest son [[Percy Beveridge]] became a notable cricketer in New Zealand, while his son Cecil became an actor and theatre director and, also of the 20th Battalion, was injured during the [[Battle of Pozières]] in 1916.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1020902 |title=PERSONAL. |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart, Tas. |date=17 August 1916 |accessdate=15 April 2015 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>Cecil Beveridge was injured later in September and was promoted to the rank of [[Warrant Officer]] Class One before receiving a medical discharge on 21 March 1920, he later worked for [[Hoyts|Hoyts Cinemas]]. [[National Archives of Australia|NAA]]: B2455, BEVERIDGE C</ref> He is interred with his wife (d. 1929) and his third son, Harry (d. 1943, who was a branch manager for the [[Commonwealth Bank]]) at [[Waverley Cemetery]].
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
{{s-start}} {{s-civ}} {{s-bef| before= [[Thomas Clarke (New South Wales politician)|Thomas Clarke]] }} {{s-ttl |title= [[Municipality of Redfern|Mayor of Redfern]] | years =1891 }} {{s-aft|after=George Howe}} {{s-end}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Beveridge, John}} [[Category:Australian coroners]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Australian federationists]] [[Category:Australian Presbyterians]] [[Category:Australian people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Burials at Waverley Cemetery]] [[Category:Cricketers from Sydney]] [[Category:Mayors of Redfern]] [[Category:New South Wales local government politicians]] [[Category:Free Trade Party politicians]] [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:1916 deaths]]

revision.comment: /* Aftermath */ title --> Outcome
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Karmein Chan | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1977|11|5}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Circa}} {{Death date and age|1991|4|13|1977|11|5|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]] | death_cause = Murder (gunshot) | body_discovered = Edgars Creek, Thomastown (9 April 1992) | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = Chinese-Australian | known_for = Murder victim | parents = Phillis lam | awards = $1,000,000 reward }}
'''Karmein Chan''' was a 13-year-old [[Australians|Australian]] girl who was abducted from her home in [[Templestowe, Victoria]], during the night of 13 April 1991 and was subsequently murdered.<ref>{{cite news|last=Silvester|first=John|title='Mr Cruel' filmed his victims, say police|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2006/04/07/1143916721667.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1|accessdate=28 September 2012|newspaper=The Age|date=8 April 2006}}</ref>
==Kidnapping== Chan was at home babysitting her two younger sisters while both her parents worked at a Chinese restaurant they owned in the nearby Melbourne suburb of [[Eltham, Victoria|Eltham]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Heath |first1=Sally |title=Agony and hope of the waiting family |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22082532/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=11 April 1992 |page=20 |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{free access}}</ref> Chan and her sisters were confronted by a man in a [[Balaclava (clothing)|balaclava]] with a knife. He forced Chan's sisters into a wardrobe before fleeing with Chan.<ref name="TheAgeMay1991">{{cite news |last1=Catalano |first1=Antony |title=Brutal abductor breeds fear with cruelty |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22082285/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=4 May 1991 |page=20 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> Before leaving, he spray painted "Asian drug deal", "payback" and "more to come" on a vehicle in their front yard.<ref name="TheAgeMay1991"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Daley |first1=Paul |last2=Catalano |first2=Antony |title=A man in dark shatters a happy family |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22072015/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Sunday Age |date=21 April 1991 |page=5 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> Police suspect this was a ruse to distract them from the killer's real motive.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tobin |first1=Bruce |title=Rumors hurting family, says kidnap girl's father |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22082517/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=3 May 1991 |page=5 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> Chan's mother made an emotional plea on television for Chan's return.
==Related events== There had been several abductions of girls in Melbourne prior to the abduction of Chan by an offender known in the media as [[Mr Cruel]]. [[Victoria Police]] had started scaling down Operation Challenge the day before Chan's abduction that had been established to investigate two abductions in which the victim was raped and an earlier home invasion also involving rape.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tobin|first1=Bruce|title=Why Mr Cruel has to be caught|work=The Age|date=11 April 1993}}</ref> Detectives believed that Chan would be released the same as previous girls abducted.
==Investigation== On 6 May 1991, 23 days after Chan's abduction, Victoria Police formed the Spectrum Taskforce to investigate Chan's abduction and to continue Operation Challenge investigations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tobin|first1=Bruce|title=Police receive 400 calls on kidnap drawings|work=The Age|date=28 January 1993}}</ref> A reward of $100,000 was offered for information on her abduction.<ref>{{cite web|title=Karmein Chan $100,000 award announced 1991 |url=http://www.vicpolicenews.com.au/rewards/3405-karmein-chan.html |website=Victoria Police News |publisher=Victoria Police Media Unit |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401022649/http://www.vicpolicenews.com.au/rewards/3405-karmein-chan.html |archivedate=1 April 2010 }}</ref>
On 9 April 1992, Chan's remains were found nearly a year later in a landfill area at [[Edgars Creek Trail|Edgars Creek]] in the suburb of [[Thomastown, Victoria|Thomastown]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tobin |first1=Bruce |title=Karmein possibly shot in panic |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22082552/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=13 April 1992 |page=4 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> The skull had three bullet holes in the back of the head. The body had probably been there for 12 months.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Holgate |first1=Ben |last2=Daley |first2=Paul |title=Mr Cruel executed Karmein: police |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22072627/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Sunday Age |date=12 April 1992 |pages=1–2 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> On 31 January 1994, the Spectrum Taskforce was disbanded.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tobin |first1=Bruce |title=Taskforce hunting Mr Cruel to wind up |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22115360/the_age/ |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=30 November 1993 |page=1 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref> The offender was never brought to justice.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Moor|first1=Keith|title=A cruel time on manhunt|work=Herald Sun|date=2 April 2001}}</ref>
==Outcome== An inquest was held in 1997 with the coroner finding that she met her death through foul play, but it was not possible to identify the person or people responsible.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Button |first1=Victoria |title=Police keep file open on Karmein |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22115415/the_age/ |accessdate=23 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=13 September 1997 |page=A3 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}</ref>
The case has remained open with cold case detectives regularly reviewing the investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=New clues in police hunt for 'Mr Cruel'|url=http://www.smh.com.au//breaking-news-national/new-clues-in-police-hunt-for-mr-cruel-20101214-18vna.html|website=Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=14 December 2010|accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
On the 25th anniversary of her abduction the reward was increased from $100,000 to $1,000,000.<ref>{{cite |title=$1 million reward announced Karmein Chan|website=Victoria Police News|publisher=Victoria Police Media Unit|date=13 April 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite news |last1=Daly |first1=Martin |title=Cruel legacy |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22082407/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=13 April 1996 |page=A19 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}} * {{cite news |last1=Delianis |first1=Paul |title=To catch a killer |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22079109/the_age/ |accessdate=22 July 2018 |work=The Age |date=15 February 1993 |page=11 |via=Newspapers.com}} {{free access}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chan, Karmein}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:Australian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Crime victims from Melbourne]] [[Category:Formerly missing people found dead]] [[Category:Kidnapped Australian children]] [[Category:Murdered Australian children]] [[Category:Murder in 1991]] [[Category:People from Melbourne]] [[Category:People murdered in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:Unsolved murders in Australia]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Education in the United States]]; added [[Category:United States proposed federal education legislation]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{orphan|date=January 2013}} The '''Keeping All Students Safe Act''' refers to a pair of [[American (USA)|American]] legislative proposals introduced in the [[United States House of Representatives]] on April 6, 2011 as [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:h.r.1381: H.R. 1381] and in the [[United States Senate|Senate]] on December 16, 2011 as [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:s.2020: S.2020]. The bills are designed to protect children from the abuse of restraint and seclusion in school. The first Congressional bill was introduced in the United States House of Representatives on December 9, 2007 and named the Preventing Harmful Restraint and Seclusion in Schools Act.<ref name="HR4247">[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:H.R.4247: HR4247] Preventing Harmful Restraint and Seclusion in Schools Act, H.R. 4247, U.S. House of Representatives, Dec. 9, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref> The primary sponsors of the two bills are Senator [[Tom Harkin]] (D-IA), Chair of the [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions|Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee]], Congressman [[George Miller (California politician)|George Miller]] (D-CA), Ranking Member of the [[United States House Committee on Education and the Workforce|House Education and Workforce Committee]], and Congressman [[Gregg Harper]] (R-MS).
==Background & Legislative History== Restraint involves immobilizing an individual and preventing him or her from moving his or her arms, legs, body, or head freely. Seclusion involves the involuntary confinement of an individual in a room or area from which the individual is physically prevented from leaving, whether the room is locked or the door is blocked by furniture.<ref name="S2020">[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:s.2020: S.2020] Keeping All Students Safe Act, sec. 2, S.2020, U.S. Senate, Dec. 16, 2011. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref>
In 2009, the United States [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) undertook a nationwide study of the use of restraint and seclusion in schools and its effects.<ref name="GAO1">[http://www.gao.gov/assets/130/122526.pdf U.S. GAO Report] United States Government Accountability Office, “Seclusions and Restraints, Selected Cases of Death and Abuse at Public and Private Schools and Treatment Centers,” May 19, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref> The GAO found "hundreds of cases of alleged abuse and death related to the use of these methods on schoolchildren during the past two decades."<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/senate-oks-bill-limiting-teachers-in-restraint-seclusion-of-students-q93u2gl-137984118.html Journal Sentinel], “Senate OKs Bill Limiting Teachers In Restraint, Seclusion Of Students,” Journal Sentinel, Jan. 24, 2012. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> Most of the incidents involved children with [[disabilities]] who are enrolled in [[special education]], the GAO reported.<ref name="GAO1" />
The GAO documented 20 deaths of children from restraint. The GAO also reported about restraints that resulted in broken arms, and kindergartners who were tied to chairs with duct tape and who suffered bloody noses.<ref name="GAO1" /> One teenager hanged himself in a seclusion room, while a teacher sat outside the room. Before the final episode, he was confined 19 times in a concrete 8 foot by 8 foot room for an average of 94 minutes each time. His parents were never informed.<ref>[http://www.ajc.com/news/death-highlights-lack-of-100352.html Atlanta Journal Constitution], Alan Judd, “Death Highlights Lack of Regulation at Psycho-educational Schools,” Atlanta Journal Constitution, July 27, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> The GAO found that a New York child was placed alone in a seclusion room 75 times in 6 months for whistling and slouching.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/printedition/news/20090519/1arestraints19.art.htm USA Today], Greg Toppo, "Disabled Kids Restrained, Confined," USA Today, May 19, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> The National Disability Rights Network and the Council of Parents Attorneys and Advocates also documented the nationwide use of restraint and seclusion in 2009.<ref name="USN1">[https://www.usnews.com/education/articles/2009/07/07/students-suffer-abusive-restraint-gao-says U.S. News & World Report] Jessica Calefati, “Students Suffer Abusive Restraint, GAO Says,” U.S. News & World Report, July 7, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref> NDRN documented the use of restraint and seclusion in 2/3 of states in 2009.<ref>[http://www.napas.org/images/Documents/Resources/Publications/Reports/SR-Report2009.pdf NDRN Report] School is Not Supposed to Hurt, NDRN, January, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref>
On May 19, 2009, the House Education and Labor Committee held hearings about the use of restraint and seclusion, chaired by Congressman George Miller.<ref name="hearing1">[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-111hhrg49597/pdf/CHRG-111hhrg49597.pdf U.S. House of Representatives Hearings] U.S. Congress, Hearing Before the House Committee on Education and Labor, Examining the Abusive and Deadly Use of Seclusion and Restraint in Schools, 111th Congress, May 19, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref>
One witness testified that her 14-year-old son was killed when restrained by his 230-pound teacher, who smothered him by lying on top of him in a restraint during a disagreement about lunch.<ref>[http://articles.cnn.com/2009-05-19/politics/schools.abuse_1_teacher-testimony-toni-price?_s=PM:POLITICS CNN Restraints] Congress Hears Accounts Of Abused Special-Needs Students, CNN, May 19, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> Another witness testified that her 7-year-old daughter was bruised when she was restrained face down for playing with her tooth, but the parent was never informed by the school. She also testified that her child was later restrained again, and received a severe abrasion, but she was not informed of the restraint. She testified that other children were denied access to food, water, and the bathroom while isolated in seclusion confinement rooms.<ref name="hearing1" />
The GAO presented testimony about its report and findings about restraint and seclusion, and the risk of death and injury.<ref name="hearing1" /> The GAO also reported that restraint and seclusion have been used to control minor student misbehaviors such as speaking out of turn or refusing to remain in one’s chair.<ref name="USN1" /> Another hearing witness testified that restraint may be needed in emergencies. He noted that sometimes educators need to use restraint in emergency situations, where there is a risk that a child will injure himself or others and nothing else will work to prevent the immediate danger. Teachers may use restraint and seclusion appropriately in those circumstances, the witness testified.<ref name="NPR2">[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=104277070 National Public Radio] Joseph Shapiro, “Report: Discipline Methods Endanger Disabled Kids,” National Public Radio, May 19, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref> An Illinois State Board of Education representative presented data from Illinois showing that implementing school-wide positive behavioral supports reduced the use of restraint and seclusion significantly.<ref name="hearing1" />
The United States House of Representatives reported that children, most often children with disabilities, are subjected to seclusion and restraint at much higher rates than adults, and are at greater risk of injury as a result of these practices. The House further reported that children under the age of 12 are restrained or secluded at higher rates than any other age group. The House of Representatives also reported that, “the use of restraint and seclusion often exacerbates the behaviors that staff are trying to eliminate.”<ref>[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CRPT-111hrpt417/pdf/CRPT-111hrpt417.pdf House Report 111-417], U.S. House of Representatives, Committee on Education & Labor, House Report 111-417, Preventing Harmful Restraint and Seclusion in Schools, Feb. 23, 2010. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref>
Because there is no federal law, state restraint and seclusion laws control.<ref name="CNNState">[http://articles.cnn.com/2009-05-18/politics/siu.schools.abuse_1_special-needs-students-teacher-gao?_s=PM:POLITICS CNN Report] Abbie Boudreau & Steve Turnham, “GAO report: Special-Needs Kids Abused In Schools,” CNN, May 18, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref> A 2012 report by Jessica Butler for the Autism National Committee summarized state seclusion and restraint laws and policies. It reported that only 14 states limited the use of restraint to emergencies involving threats of physical injury. Only 11 either banned all forms of seclusion or restricted it to emergency threats of physical harm. There are 27 states that have no requirement to notify parents when a child is restrained or secluded and only 12 states that require same day or next day notification.<ref name="HowSafe">[http://www.autcom.org/pdf/HowSafeSchoolhouse.pdf How Safe Is the Schoolhouse?] Jessica Butler, “How Safe Is The Schoolhouse? A Summary and Analysis of State Restraint and Seclusion Laws and Policies,” January 20, 2012. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref>
As there is no national clearinghouse that gathers data on the use of the techniques, the exact number of children subjected to restraint and seclusion in school is unknown.<ref name="USN1" /> The GAO found that only five states kept records. In two of them, Texas and California, there were over 33,000 cases in 2007-08. Many of the children had cognitive disabilities, autism, mental health disabilities, attention deficit disorder and other disabilities.<ref name="NPR2" /> Professor Reece Peterson testified at the House Education and Labor hearing about the need for federal law requiring data collection nationwide.<ref name="hearing1" />
On December 9, 2009, six months after the House hearing, the first national restraint and seclusion bill was introduced by Congressman George Miller. It was cosponsored by Congresswoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers. A companion bill was introduced in the Senate by Senator Chris Dodd.<ref>[http://www.disabilityscoop.com/2009/12/09/restraint-bill-introduced/6448/ Disability Scoop], Michelle Diament, “Lawmakers Unveil Restraint And Seclusion Bill,” Disability Scoop, December 9, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref>
The 2009 House bill was numbered H.R. 4247 and entitled “Preventing Harmful Restraint and Seclusion in Schools Act.”<ref name="HR4247"/> The Senate bill was numbered S. 2860 and had the same title.<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:S2860: S.2860], S. 2860, Preventing Harmful Restraint and Seclusion in Schools Act, December 9, 2009. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref>
On March 3, 2010, the House of Representatives passed H.R. 4247 (now renamed the Keeping All Students Safe Act). The vote was 262-153, with 238 Democrats and 24 Republicans voting in favor.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/04/health/04restraint.html NY Times], Benedict Carey, “House Votes to Protect Pupils Against Abusive Discipline,” New York Times, March 3, 2010. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> The bill did not pass the Senate.<ref name="HR4247" /> A revised Senate bill, S.3895, was introduced on September 29, 2010, and cosponsored by Senator Dodd and Senator Burr. It did not pass the Senate.<ref>[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:S3895: S.3895], S. 3895, Keeping All Students Safe Act, Sept. 29, 2010. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> Because passage by both houses of Congress is required for the President to consider a bill in America, both bills died at the end of the 111th Congress in December 2010.
Restraint and seclusion bills were introduced again in the 112th Congress in 2011. On April 6, 2011, Congressman George Miller (D-CA), Ranking Member of the House Education and Workforce Committee, reintroduced the Keeping All Students Safe Act, cosponsored by Congressman Greg Harper (R-MS).<ref name="HR1381">[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:h.r.1381: H.R.1381], H.R. 1381, Keeping All Students Safe Act, April 6, 2011. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref> On December 16, 2011, the second anniversary of Congressman Miller’s first bill, Senator Tom Harkin, Chairman of the Senate Health Education Labor and Pensions Committee, introduced a slightly different version of the Keeping All Students Safe Act, S. 2020.<ref name="S2020" />
==Description of the Keeping All Students Safe Act== This section of the article focuses on the two newest bills introduced in the 112th Congress in 2011. The House and Senate versions of the Keeping All Students Safe Act differ.
The House bill prohibits physical restraint except in emergencies when there is an imminent threat of physical injury and less restrictive measures will not resolve the situation. The Senate bill bars physical restraint unless there is an immediate threat of serious bodily injury and less restrictive measures will not solve the situation. Both bills would forbid the use of restraint or seclusion for destruction of property, educational disruption, failing to follow instructions, and for coercion, discipline, or in place of proper educational planning.
The House bill also forbids seclusion unless there is an immediate threat of physical injury and less restrictive methods will not resolve the situation. The House bill will require staff to continuously visually monitor (watch) children who are confined to seclusion rooms to ensure that they are safe. The Senate bill bans all seclusion of children, which is defined as locking children in rooms or other spaces or blocking the door so they cannot leave (e.g., with furniture).<ref name="S.2020 sec 4">[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:s.2020: S.2020 sec 4] Keeping All Students Safe Act, sec. 4, S.2020, U.S. Senate, Dec. 16, 2011. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012.</ref><ref name="H.R.1381 sec 5">[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:h.r.1381: H.R.1381 sec 5], Keeping All Students Safe Act, sec. 5, H.R. 1381, April 6, 2011. Retrieved March 11, 2012, 2012</ref>
Both bills require restraint to end when the emergency ends, and the House bill requires seclusion to end when the emergency ends. Both bills ban the use of mechanical restraints, meaning devices that lock and restrain children, or taping or tying them to chairs or furniture. Both bills ban chemical restraints and restraints that impair breathing or otherwise threaten life.<ref name="S.2020 sec 4"/><ref name="H.R.1381 sec 5"/>
Both bills require schools to notify parents in writing within 24 hours of restraint and verbally the same day.<ref name="S.2020 sec 4"/><ref name="H.R.1381 sec 5"/> There are 27 states that do not have legal requirements for schools to tell parents a child was restrained/secluded.<ref name="HowSafe" />
Both bills impose training requirements to ensure that staff who use restraint and seclusion are trained in evidence-based techniques and that the techniques are not misused in even more dangerous manners. Both bills prohibit putting physical restraint as a planned intervention in Individual Education Programs, 504 plans, behavioral intervention plans, student safety plans, or other educational planning documents for individual students. The bills also require the collection of data nationwide and disaggregating the data by such categories as race, sex, income, and disability status.<ref name="S.2020 sec 4"/><ref name="H.R.1381 sec 5"/>
The Senate bill also bans restraints that interfere with the ability to communicate.<ref name="S.2020 sec 4"/> The GAO reported on at least four cases in which verbal children who died or were injured in restraint told staff that they could not breathe.<ref name="GAO1" /> Numerous children cannot speak or have difficulty doing so, and rely on sign language or augmentative communications devices.<ref name="HowSafe" /> Additionally, the Senate bill requires that a debriefing be held, where school staff, the parents, and the student may attend.<ref name="S.2020 sec 4"/> Debriefings are intended to reduce and eliminate restraint and seclusion, by determining what caused the event and how to avoid it in the future, and by analyzing, planning for, and implementing positive interventions.<ref>[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=2001_register&docid=01-1649-filed.pdf Federal Register], Medicaid Program; Use of Restraint and Seclusion in Psychiatric Residential Treatment Facilities Providing Psychiatric Services to Individuals Under Age 21; Interim Final Rule, 66 Fed. Reg. 7148, Jan. 22, 2001. Retrieved March 11, 2012.</ref>
==Statement of Congressman Miller on Introduction==
When Congressman Miller re-introduced the House bill in 2011, he described his reasons for doing so, “In 2009, the Government Accountability Office told our committee of the shocking wave of abuse by untrained school staff who were misusing emergency interventions. Most of these victims were children with disabilities. Some were 3 and 4 years old. In some cases, children died. Restraint and seclusion should be used only as a last resort and by trained professionals, but the GAO found that was not the case. . . . A media report out yesterday highlights that these horrific abuses continued through this past year. In Chicago, a 4-year-old boy’s wrists were taped together with painter’s tape and then duct tape because he refused to take a nap and he didn’t wash his hands.”<ref>[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-2011-04-07/pdf/CREC-2011-04-07-pt1-PgH2413-7.pdf#page=1 Congressional Record House], Congressman George Miller, Congressional Record, April 6, 2011. Retrieved Feb. 18, 2012</ref>
==Statement of Senator Harkin on Introduction== Senator Harkin introduced his bill and explained the reasons for doing so. He said, “I am pleased to introduce today the Keeping All Students Safe Act. This important legislation will protect school children against ineffective harmful and life threatening seclusion and restraint practices. . . . Restraint and seclusion-related fatalities and injuries most often involve children with disabilities. This vulnerable population must especially be protected from this type of abuse, and this legislation seeks to do just that. . . .The act does allow for the use of restraint in emergency situations to prevent serious bodily injury to the student, other students in the classroom, or staff, it also requires State-approved crisis intervention training program as to how to approach these types of emergency situations.”<ref name="CRHarkin">[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-2011-12-16/pdf/CREC-2011-12-16-pt1-PgS8735.pdf Congressional Record Senate], Senator Tom Harkin, Congressional Record, Dec. 16, 2011. Retrieved Feb. 18, 2012</ref>
Senator Harkin also addressed data issues, “Another issue uncovered by the GAO study was that no web site, Federal agency, or other entity currently collects comprehensive data related to the use of restraint and seclusion in our Nation's schools. This Act will remedy this situation, as it requires each State educational agency to prepare and submit a report documenting” the use of restraint and seclusion.”<ref name="CRHarkin" />
==Related Events== In March 2012, the Office of Civil Rights of the United States Department of Education presented a report about its Civil Rights Data Collection. It reported that students with disabilities made up represent 12% of students in its data collection sample, but nearly 70% of the students who are physically restrained by adults in school. For those schools which reported data, there was a total of 38, 792 incidents of physical restraint. CRDC also found racial and ethnic disproportionality in restraint and seclusion use. African-American students were 21% of students with disabilities under served under the IDEA, but 44% of students with disabilities subjected to mechanical restraint. Hispanic children were disproportionately subjected to seclusion.<ref>[http://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/docs/crdc-2012-data-summary.pdf CRDC Data Collection] Dept. of Education, Office of Civil Rights, Civil Rights Data Collection, Revealing New Truths About Our Nation’s Schools, March 2012. Retrieved March 11, 2012</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://KeepAllStudentsSafe.com] Act to Keep All Students Safe Advocacy Group *[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:s.2020: S.2020], Full text of Keeping All Students Safe Act, S.2020 via [[THOMAS]] *[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d112:h.r.1381:], Full text of Keeping All Students Safe Act, H.R.1381 via [[THOMAS]]

[[File:Lithotomy position.jpg|thumb|Lithotomy position.]] The '''lithotomy position''' is a medical term referring to a common position for surgical procedures and medical examinations involving the pelvis and lower abdomen, as well as a common position for [[childbirth]] in Western nations. The lithotomy position involves the positioning of an individual's feet above or at the same level as the hips (often in stirrups), with the [[perineum]] positioned at the edge of an examination table. References to the position have been found in some of the oldest known medical documents including versions of the [[Hippocratic oath]] (see [[lithotomy]]); the position is named after the ancient surgical procedure for removing [[kidney stones]] and [[bladder stones]] via the [[perineum]]. The position is perhaps most recognizable as the 'often used' position for childbirth: the patient is laid on the back with knees bent, positioned above the hips, and spread apart through the use of [[stirrup]]s.
The position is frequently used and has many obvious benefits from the doctor's perspective. Most notably the position provides good visual and physical access to the perineal region. The position is used for procedures ranging from simple pelvic exams to surgeries and procedures including those involving [[reproductive|reproductive organs]], [[urological|urology]], and [[gastrointestinal]] systems. New observations and scientific findings, combined with a greater sensitivity to patient needs have raised awareness of the physical and psychological risks the position may pose for prolonged surgical procedures, pelvic examinations, and, most notably, childbirth.
==Use for prolonged surgical procedures== Some studies have found a significant relationship between prolonged surgical procedures with the patient in the lithotomy position and a circulatory complication known as [[compartment syndrome]],<ref name="pmid10893585">{{cite journal |vauthors=Anema JG, Morey AF, McAninch JW, Mario LA, Wessells H |title=Complications related to the high lithotomy position during urethral reconstruction |journal=Journal of Urology |volume=164 |issue=2 |pages=360–3 |date=August 2000 |pmid=10893585 |doi= 10.1016/S0022-5347(05)67360-0|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0022-5347(05)67360-0}}</ref><ref name="pmid11336771">{{cite journal |vauthors=Cohen SA, Hurt WG |title=Compartment syndrome associated with lithotomy position and intermittent compression stockings |journal=[[Obstet Gynecol]] |volume=97 |issue=5 Pt 2 |pages=832–3 |date=May 2001 |doi= 10.1016/S0029-7844(00)01141-8|pmid=11336771}}</ref> Nerve injury by pressure is also possible, the femoral or peroneal nerve are at risk.<ref>Manski, D: Online textbook of urology http://www.urology-textbook.com/lithotomy-position.html</ref>
==Use for childbirth== A Cochrane Review found that the lithotomy position may not be the ideal position for child birth, noting that while it makes care easier for physicians by placing the patient in an easily accessible position, it is often harder on birthing mothers as use of the lithotomy position can narrow the birth canal by up to a third. In lieu of the lithotomy position, the Cochrane Review recommended birthing mothers make informed choices about birthing positions and find the position that is most comfortable for them.<ref>http://apps.who.int/rhl/reviews/langs/CD002006.pdf</ref>
==Use for pelvic examinations== Patients have reported feeling a loss of control and increased sense of vulnerability when examined in the lithotomy position because they cannot see the area being examined. Other, equally effective positions have been suggested for examinations of conscious patients.<ref name="urlEditorials — July 1, 2000 - American Family Physician">{{cite web |url=http://www.aafp.org/afp/20000701/editorials.html |title=Editorials — July 1, 2000 - American Family Physician |work= |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="pmid16803941">{{cite journal |vauthors=Seehusen DA, Johnson DR, Earwood JS, etal |title=Improving women's experience during speculum examinations at routine gynaecological visits: randomised clinical trial |journal=[[BMJ]] |volume=333 |issue=7560 |pages=171 |date=July 2006 |pmid=16803941 |doi=10.1136/bmj.38888.588519.55 |url=http://bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16803941 |pmc=1513491}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Childbirth positions]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101025223022/http://birthingnaturally.net/barp/lithotomy.html Lithotomy Position]. Information and research on the use of the Lithotomy Position in Childbirth * [http://www.lithotomyposition.net/effect-of-lithotomy-position-on-spinal-anesthesia.php Effect Of Lithotomy Position On Spinal Anesthesia]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lithotomy Position}} [[Category:Human positions]] [[Category:Childbirth]]

revision.text:
The '''Memphite Necropolis''' is an [[ancient Egypt]]ian [[necropolis]] located in the city of [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]], [[Lower Egypt]]. It includes the sites of [[Giza]], [[Saqqara]] and [[Dahshur]]. Most of the [[Egyptian pyramids|pyramid]]s of the [[Old Kingdom of Egypt|Old Kingdom]] were built here, along with many [[mastaba]]s and other tombs.
==Saqqara== Saqqara is the site of the first Egyptian pyramid, the [[Pyramid of Djoser]].<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/86 © UNESCO World Heritage Centre 1992-2011] approximately 11:40GMT 2.9.11</ref>
==Dahshur== The size of the necropolis is 2.5 by 6 kilometres, located about 30 kilometres south of Cairo.<ref>[http://www.dainst.org/en/project/dahshur?ft=all DAI website-copyright © 2011 Deutsches Archäologisches Institut] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218151540/http://www.dainst.org/en/project/dahshur?ft=all |date=2013-12-18 }} retrieved 12:14GMT 2.10.11</ref>
==Contents of burials== Burials in the necropolis include the [[Apis bull]]s, falcons, ibises, baboons,<ref>[http://www.cardiff.ac.uk/share/contactsandpeople/academicstaff/K-O/nicholson-paul-dr-overview_new.html © Cardiff University] 12:26GMT [http://www.saqqara.nl/saqqara/landmarks/sacred-animal-necropolis] 12:28GMT</ref><ref>[http://escholarship.org/uc/item/5t48n007#page-2 UCLos Angeles (including 30 referenced articles)] retrieved 12:18GMT 1.10.11</ref><ref>[http://www.pasthorizonspr.com/index.php/archives/04/2011/tunnels-contain-the-mummified-remains-of-millions-of-dogs recent archeological activity] 11:41GMT 1.10.11</ref> and boats.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/pss/3821724 The Journal of Egyptian Archaeology © 1985 Egypt Exploration Society]</ref><ref>[http://cairodahshur.imrd.org/ retrieved 11:51GMT 1.10.11]</ref>
==Excavations== The tomb of Nakht-Min at the Abusir-Memphite Necropolis (''Kahled Daoud'') [ [[Egypt Exploration Society]] ] <ref>[http://www.ees.ac.uk/research/Excavation%20Award%20Grants.html © Egypt Exploration Society 2011 Registered Charity No. 212384 ] retrieved 11;26GMT 1.10.11</ref>
[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1095-9270.2008.00214.x/full ''An Exploratory Geophysical Survey at the Pyramid Complex of Senwosret III at Dahshur, Egypt, in Search of Boats'' from Copyright © 1999–2011 John Wiley & Sons, Inc. All Rights Reserved] retrieved 12:06GMT 1.10.11
research on constructions within Dashar necropolis since 2008 [https://web.archive.org/web/20131218151540/http://www.dainst.org/en/project/dahshur?ft=all © 2011 Deutsches Archäologisches Institut] (re-retrieved 12:18GMT 2.10.11)
==See also == *[[Ancient Egypt]] *[[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] *[[Necropolis]] *[[Giza Necropolis]] *[[Cemetery GIS]] *[[Central Field, Giza]] *[[Giza East Field]] *[[Giza West Field]] *[[Jacques de Morgan]] *[[Senusret III]] *[[Jacques Kinnaer]] *[[German Archaeological Institute]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *[http://www.brepols.net/Pages/ShowProduct.aspx?prod_id=IS-9782503533537-1 C. J. Martin - Demotic Papyri from the Memphite Necropolis In the Collections of the National Museum of Antiquities in Leiden, the British Museum and the Hermitage Museum] (retrieved 11:08GMT 1.10.11) *[https://www.britishmuseum.org/pdf/Raven.pdf Document pertaining to the ''[[Book of the Dead|Book of Coming Forth by Day]]'')] - Maarten J. Raven (retrieved 11:16 1.10.11)
==External links== *[http://beta.feetxl.nl/Saq_bib/literature.asp Leiden Mission database-(Copyright by Feet XL© 2011)] retrieved 13:36 1.10.11 *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8440843p Émile Prisse d'Avennes - [Necropolis of Memphis (pyramids of Giza)] - Bibliothèque nationale de France
