revision.text:
{{Infobox sportsperson | headercolor = | name = Micah True | image = Micah True.jpg | image_size = <!--Only for images narrower than 220 pixels.--> | caption = | birth_name = Michael Randall Hickman | nickname = Caballo Blanco | nationality = American | residence = [[Boulder, Colorado]], U.S. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1953|11|10}}<ref name=Shapiro/> | birth_place = [[Oakland, California]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2012|03|27|1953|11|10}}<ref name="Byars"/> | death_place = {{Nowrap|[[Gila Wilderness]], [[New Mexico]], U.S.}} | sport = {{Unbulleted list| [[Boxing]] | [[Running]] }} | event = {{Unbulleted list| [[Middleweight]] boxing | [[Ultramarathon]] running}} }}
'''Micah True''' (November 10, 1953 – March 27, 2012), born '''Michael Randall Hickman''' and also known as '''Caballo Blanco''' (white horse), was an American [[ultrarunning|ultrarunner]] from [[Boulder, Colorado]], who received attention because of his depiction as a central character in [[Christopher McDougall]]'s book ''[[Born to Run: A Hidden Tribe, Superathletes, and the Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen|Born to Run]]''.<ref name="FirstPost">{{citation|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/world-news/46121/body-runner-micah-true-caballo-blanco-found#ixzz1qnjUNip9 |title=Body of runner Micah True, 'Caballo Blanco', found |work=[[The First Post]] |location=London |accessdate=April 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66ecmj9C8?url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/world-news/46121/body-runner-micah-true-caballo-blanco-found |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="Metzler">{{Harvtxt|Metzler|2010}}</ref> True's inclusion in the book garnered him some attention in ultrarunning circles, and some readers credited him as their inspiration for taking up the sport.<ref name="Byars">{{Harvtxt|Byars|2012a}}</ref><ref name="USA">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-04-01/micah-true-dead/53919320/1 |title=Renowned runner Micah True's body found |work=[[USA Today]] |date=April 2, 2012 |accessdate=April 2, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66efcbNZr?url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-04-01/micah-true-dead/53919320/1 |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="Christie">{{Harvtxt|Christie|2012}}</ref><ref name="au">{{cite news |url= http://media.theage.com.au/news/world-news/micah-true-a-super-athlete-3182951.html |title= Micah True, a super athlete |work=[[The Age]] |location= Melbourne |date=April 3, 2012 |format= Video |accessdate=April 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Bryan">{{Harvtxt|Bryan|2012a}}</ref>
During the 1980s and 90s True spent several months per year trail running in [[Central America]]. In 2003 True decided to organize a race for the [[Tarahumara people]] in Mexico that would help them preserve their culture and running heritage. True died on March 27, 2012, during a run in the [[Gila Wilderness]], part of the [[Gila National Forest]] in southwestern New Mexico.
==Life== Micah True was born ''Michael Randall Hickman'' in [[Oakland, California]], the son of a [[World War II]] Marine Corps Gunnery Sergeant<ref name="Shapiro">{{Harvtxt|Shapiro|2012}}</ref> and the second of four children.<ref name="LastRun"/> He grew up traveling the country as his family relocated to various nationally located Marine Corps bases.<ref name=Shapiro/> His family was conservative [[Roman Catholic]], but True aligned himself with the counter-culture movement of the 1960s and 70s.<ref name=LastRun/>
True attended [[Humboldt State University]], where he studied [[Eastern religion]]s and [[Native American history]].<ref name=Shapiro/> To earn money he began prizefighting in informal boxing bouts, using the name "Gypsy Cowboy," and perhaps taking the occasional dive for an easy payday.<ref name=LastRun/><ref name=CM-B2R>{{Harvtxt|McDougall|2009}} prizefighting in college pp.276-277. returned to Colorado p.281.</ref> Between 1974 and 1982, Hickman was a professional middleweight boxer, fighting under the name Mike "True" Hickman. His career record was 9 wins (KO 2), 11 losses (KO 9), and 0 draws.<ref>{{citation |author= |url= http://boxrec.com/list_bouts.php?human_id=28561&cat=boxer |work=BoxRec |title= Mike Hickman |accessdate= April 6, 2012}}</ref>
At some point True spent 10 months living in a cave in [[Hawaii]] where he fell in love with a rich girl.<ref name=LastRun/> It was when she left him, he said, that he took up long-distance running.<ref name=Shapiro/> He also changed his name from Michael Hickman to Micah True.<ref name=Shapiro/> (The name Micah comes from the [[Bible]], while True came from the name of a beloved pet: True Dog.)<ref name=LastRun/>
By 1982 True had moved to [[Boulder, Colorado]], where he began working as a self-employed furniture mover.<ref name="LastRun">{{Harvtxt|Bearak|2012}}</ref> By then he had become a "trailrunning bum" (like a "surfing bum or a climbing bum").<ref name=Shapiro/> For almost 20 years, he spent winters running in Mexico, Guatemala, and Central America, averaging {{convert|170|mi|km}} per week.<ref>{{Harvtxt|Brick|2000}}</ref><ref name="BBC">{{Harvtxt|McDougall|2009}}</ref> He would return to Boulder during the summers to earn enough money to live on the rest of the year.<ref name=CM-B2R/> Among villagers he became known as "El Caballo Blanco" or "The White Horse" for his long blond hair and pale skin.<ref name=LastRun/>
In 1993 True came in contact with the [[Tarahumara people|Tarahumara]] or Rarámuri runners from [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua, Mexico]]. In 1994 he began spending his winters running in the [[Copper Canyon]]s, where he built a hut and began establishing a relationship with the Tarahumara natives.<ref name=LastRun/>[[File:Copper Canyons marathon in Urique.jpg|thumb|Copper Canyons marathon in Urique|left]]
==Copper Canyon Ultra Marathon== In 2003 True decided to organize a race for the Tarahumara natives that would help them preserve their culture and running heritage.<ref name=LastRun/> The first Copper Canyon Ultra Marathon was held on March 23, 2003;<ref>{{citation|last=True|first=Micah|title=Copper Canyon Ultra Marathon|url=http://coppercanyonultra.com/Historical.html|accessdate=21 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413231025/http://coppercanyonultra.com/Historical.html|archivedate=13 April 2012|df=}}</ref> though turnout was small, it became an annual tradition.<ref name="Post">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/foundation-formed-to-keep-alive-runner-micah-trues-ultra-marathon-in-copper-canyon/2012/04/09/gIQAtSje6S_story.html |title=Foundation formed to keep alive runner Micah True’s ultra-marathon in Copper Canyon |publisher=Washington Post |place=Albuquerque, New Mexico |date=April 9, 2012 |df= }}{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="Outside"/><ref name="Castellanos">{{Harvtxt|Castellanos|2012}}</ref>
In 2006 True got the idea of having American ultrarunners to compete with the Tarahumara.<ref name=LastRun/> After initially reaching out on the internet, he wrote an article in ''[[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health]]'', elucidating many of the lessons he internalized from the [[Tarahumara people]].<ref name="McDougall">{{Harvtxt|McDougall|2006}}</ref><ref name="IBT">{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/322859/20120402/caballo-blanco-micah-true-found-dead-gila.htm |author=Staff Reporter |work=[[International Business Times]] |title=Caballo Blanco Dead: Micah True Found Beside a Stream, Fans Respond to Death of a Legend |date=April 2, 2012 |accessdate=April 2, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66efRZ1ZG?url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/322859/20120402/caballo-blanco-micah-true-found-dead-gila.htm |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He also contacted [[Christopher McDougall]], a writer for ''Men's Health'', who would later write the book ''[[Born to Run: A Hidden Tribe, Superathletes, and the Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen|Born to Run]]''.
The 2012 event took place on March 12 and was the largest ever with hundreds of participants. Most were local Tarahumara, known for their running endurance, both as a general means of travel and while participating in ceremonial, team-based, long distance running events, most famously the Rarajipari, or ball game. In addition to prize money for the top ten finishers, the event awards seed corn vouchers to all runners who complete the distance. The race has its start and finish in the town square of [[Urique]], Chihuahua, Mexico, covering an estimated {{convert|50|mi|km}} of single track trail and dirt road.<ref name="Byars"/><ref name="Outside">{{citation|url=http://www.outsideonline.com/blog/born-to-run-caballo-blanco-interview.html |work=[[Outside (magazine)|Outside]] |date=March 31, 2010 |title=Born to Run: Caballo Blanco Interview |format=Video |author=Outside Online |accessdate=April 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66eeGgqtz?url=http://www.outsideonline.com/blog/born-to-run-caballo-blanco-interview.html |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/sports/ultrarunner-micah-true-found-dead-in-new-mexico.html |title=Missing Ultramarathoner Found Dead in New Mexico |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 1, 2012 |agency=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=April 3, 2012 |page=SP10 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66ed3AUyQ?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/sports/ultrarunner-micah-true-found-dead-in-new-mexico.html?_r=1 |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==''Born to Run''== [[File:Tarahumara.jpg|thumb|Tarahumara women selling baskets, blankets and oranges]] In 2009 True was featured prominently in Christopher McDougall's best selling book ''[[Born to Run: A Hidden Tribe, Superathletes, and the Greatest Race the World Has Never Seen|Born to Run]]''.{{#tag:ref|The book was on the [[New York Times Best Seller List]] for more than four months, although book critic Dan Zak, writer of the Style section of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' thought it contained extraneous efforts to be "gonzo and overly clever".<ref name=Zak>{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/19/AR2009061901078.html |last1= Zak |first1= Dan |title= Running, the Natural Way |work= Washington Post |date= June 21, 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091027125057/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/19/AR2009061901078.html |archivedate= October 27, 2009 |deadurl= no}}</ref>|group=upper-alpha|name=book}} <ref name=Shapiro/> The book told the story of the Copper Canyons ultra marathon and the Tarahumara, while promoting the [[endurance running hypothesis]], arguing that humans left the forests and moved to the savannas by developing the ability to run long distances in order to hunt prey by simply outlasting them in a long chase.<ref name="Pope">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/27/health/27well.html |last1=Parker-Pope |first1=Tara |title=The Human Body is Built for Distance Well |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 26, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66enpKZwg?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/27/health/27well.html?_r=1 |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Becoming a central character in a best selling book changed True's life significantly.<ref name=LastRun/> Previously he had lived a quiet simple life, not seeing himself as the eccentric and amazing person in the book. He said he sometimes felt like he had to "live up to the expectations of the book" and told people that the book contained exaggerations and inaccuracies.<ref name=LastRun/> Nevertheless, he became active on Facebook where he encouraged people to follow him. It was through Facebook that he met Maria Walton, who became his girlfriend for the last two years of his life.<ref name=LastRun/>
True also began using his celebrity status to help raise funds for the annual Copper Canyon race. He spoke at various events, beginning with a [[Saucony]] sponsored event in Utah, and then eventually traveling to Sweden, Denmark, and England.<ref name=LastRun/> According to Walton, True was never comfortable with his fame, only wanting to be known as someone who was genuine and real.<ref name="Heil">{{Harvtxt|Heil|2012}}</ref>
==Death and race continuation== On March 27, 2012, True failed to return after heading out for a run in the [[Gila Wilderness]], part of the [[Gila National Forest]] in southwestern New Mexico. He departed from the Wilderness Lodge in [[Gila, New Mexico|Gila]], saying he was going for a 12-mile (19 km) run. A subsequent [[mountain rescue]] effort involved three aircraft and at least nine [[search and rescue]] teams in off-road vehicles and on horseback, looking across {{convert|200,000|acre}} of high desert.<ref name="Stainburn">{{Harvtxt|Stainburn|2012}}</ref><ref name="Camera">{{citation|url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_20300894/body-ultrarunner-micah-true-58-found-new-mexico |title=Body of ultrarunner Micah True, 58, found in New Mexico wilderness |date=April 1, 2012 |work=[[Denver Post]] |agency=[[Camera (newspaper)|The Daily Camera]] |accessdate=April 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66efwwliv?url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_20300894/body-ultrarunner-micah-true-58-found-new-mexico |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Searchers included ultra-runners such as [[Scott Jurek]], [[Kyle Skaggs]], [[Timothy Olson]], and many athletes and friends who had participated in the 51 mile Copper Canyon Ultra Marathon.<ref name="VanHoven">{{Harvtxt|Van Hoven|2012}}</ref>
On March 31 True was found dead with his legs dangling in a stream.<ref name="Bryan"/><ref name="Wulfhorst">{{Harvtxt|Wulfhorst|2012}}</ref> The local sheriff said there were "no obvious signs of trauma",<ref name="Taylor">{{Harvtxt|Taylor|2012}}</ref> although True had scrapes and abrasions on his hands, arms, and knees, suggesting a fall.<ref name=Heil/> His remains were removed by horseback. Because of difficult terrain and remote location, the recovery was not completed until April 1.<ref name="Byars"/><ref name="Christie"/><ref name="Stainburn"/><ref name="Wulfhorst"/> An [[autopsy]]<ref name="Bryan"/> was inconclusive with respect to the actual [[cause of death]], revealing, however, that True was suffering from idiopathic [[cardiomyopathy]], which had caused the left [[Ventricle (heart)|ventricle]] of his heart to become enlarged. The autopsy report of the [[Coroner|Office of the Medical Investigator]] of New Mexico noted that "the decedent did not have a regular physician and no medical records, particularly [[electrocardiogram]]s or [[blood pressure]] readings were available for review" and "the best determination is that of unclassified cardiomyopathy which resulted in a [[cardiac dysrhythmia]] during exertion."<ref>{{Harvtxt|Bryan|2012c}}</ref>
However, Dr. James O'Keefe Jr., the director of Preventative Cardiology Fellowship Program and the Director of Preventative Cardiology at Cardiovascular Consultants at the Saint Luke's Mid America Heart Institute, a large cardiology practice in Kansas City, looked at the pathology report and believes that Micah True's enlarged thickened heart with scar tissue is a pathology some extreme endurance athletes develop termed [[Pheidippides|Phidippides]] cardiomyopathy by Peter A. McCullough in research conducted with Justin E. Trivax.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22222888 | doi=10.1002/clc.20994 | volume=35 | title=Phidippides cardiomyopathy: a review and case illustration. | date=Feb 2012 | journal=Clin Cardiol | pages=69–73}}</ref><ref>O'Keefe Jr., James (27 November 2012). "Run for your life! At a comfortable pace and not too far," TEDxUMKC. retrieved 1 February 2013.</ref> According to McCullough and Trivax's hypothesis,<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mayocp.2012.04.005|title = Potential Adverse Cardiovascular Effects From Excessive Endurance Exercise|last = O'Keefe|first = James|date = June 2012|journal = Mayo Clinic Proceedings|doi = 10.1016/j.mayocp.2012.04.005|pmid = 22677079|access-date = March 12, 2015|pmc=3538475|volume=87|pages=587–95}}</ref> "this pathology occurs because endurance sports call for a sustained increase in cardiac output for several hours" which puts the heart "into a state of volume overload. It has been shown that approximately one-third of marathon runners experience dilation of the right atrium and ventricle, have elevations of cardiac troponin and natriuretic peptides, and in a smaller fraction later develop small patches of cardiac fibrosis that are the likely substrate for ventricular tachyarrhythmias and sudden death."<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Trivax | first1 = Justin E. | last2 = McCullough | first2 = Peter A. | year = 2012 | title = Phidippides Cardiomyopathy: A Review and Case Illustration | url = | journal = Clin Cardiol | volume = 35 | issue = | pages = 69–73 | doi = 10.1002/clc.20994 | pmid=22222888}}</ref><ref name="ICTMN">{{cite news|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2012/04/06/micah-trues-death-may-have-ripple-effect-for-raramuri-indians-106860 |title=Micah True's Death May Have Ripple Effect for Rarámuri Indians |author=ICTMN Staff |publisher=Indian Country Today Media Network |date=April 6, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66qJtm079?url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2012/04/06/micah-trues-death-may-have-ripple-effect-for-raramuri-indians-106860 |archivedate=April 11, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
A simple memorial gathering was held at [[Colorado Chautauqua]] in Boulder on April 6, in which friends ran up [[Flagstaff Mountain, Boulder, Colorado|Flagstaff Mountain]] in Colorado and assembled on the Chautauqua park lawn to swap stories and remembrances of him.<ref name="memorial">{{Harvtxt|Byars|2012b}}</ref>
Due to True's role in the organization and production of the [[Copper Canyon]] [[Ultramarathon]], after his death the continuation of the event was placed in doubt.<ref name="Bryan"/> Soon after True's death, the charitable foundation Norawas de Raramuri was formed again as part of an effort to keep the Copper Canyon race going.<ref name="Post"/> It was decided the event would continue under the direction of Micah True's girlfriend Maria Walton and Fuego y Agua Events LLC. Director Josue Stephens. In honor of Micah, the race has since taken the name by which it has always been known in Mexico, [[Ultramaraton Caballo Blanco]].
==See also== {{Portal|Sports and games}} *[[James A. Corea]] *[[Jim Fixx]] *[[Bill Smith (fell runner)]] — similar incident, remote location, well known runner, difficult body recovery<ref name="Carbone">{{cite news|url=http://keepingscore.blogs.time.com/2012/04/02/micah-true-how-did-an-experienced-ultramarathoner-go-off-course/ |title=Micah True: How Did an Experienced Ultramarathoner Go Off Course |first1=Nick |last1=Carbone |date=April 2, 2012 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=April 2, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66eglejIy?url=http://keepingscore.blogs.time.com/2012/04/02/micah-true-how-did-an-experienced-ultramarathoner-go-off-course/ |archivedate=April 3, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{for|the newspaper archive|morgue file}} {{Redirect|Mortuary|other uses|Mortuary (disambiguation)}} {{multiple issues| {{Globalize|date2010|date=April 2014}} {{More citations needed|date=October 2008}} }} [[File:Royal United Hospital, mortuary and pathology laboratory.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|A hospital mortuary and [[Clinical pathology|pathology laboratory]] in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], England]] [[File:Morgue.JPG|thumb|upright=1.8|Inside view of a morgue]] [[File:13-11-12-rechtsmedizin-berlin-charite-by-RalfR-20.jpg|thumb|upright=1.8|A close-up view of a dead body in the morgue in [[Charité]].]] A '''morgue''' or '''mortuary''' (in a [[hospital]] or elsewhere) is used for the storage of human [[corpse]]s awaiting identification or removal for [[autopsy]] or respectful [[burial]], [[cremation]] or other method. In modern times corpses have customarily been [[refrigerated]] to delay [[decomposition]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Management of Dead Bodies after Disasters: A Field Manual for First Responders|last=Morgan|first=Oliver|publisher=Pan American Health Organization|year=2006|isbn=92 75 12630 5|location=|pages=49|quote=}}</ref>
==Etymology and lexicology== ''Mortuary'' early 14c., from Anglo-French mortuarie "gift to a parish priest from a deceased parishioner," from Medieval Latin mortuarium, noun use of neuter of Late Latin adjective mortuarius "pertaining to the dead," from Latin ''mortuus'', pp. of ''mori'' "to die" (see mortal (adj.)). Meaning "place where bodies are kept temporarily" first recorded 1865, a euphemism for earlier English term "deadhouse."
''Morgue'' from the [[French language|French]] ''morgue'', which means 'to look at solemnly, to defy'. First used to describe the inner wicket of a [[prison]], where new prisoners were kept so that jailers and turnkeys could recognize them in the future, it took on its modern meaning in fifteenth-century [[Paris]], being used to describe part of the [[Grand Châtelet|Châtelet]] used for the storage and identification of unknown corpses.
''Morgue'' is predominantly used in [[North American English]], while ''mortuary'' is more common in [[British English]], although both terms are used interchangeably. The [[euphemism]]s “Rose Cottage” and “Rainbow’s End”<ref>BBC documentary - ''Fry's Planet Word: Episode 3: "Uses and Abuses"'' 9 Oct 2011</ref> are sometimes used in [[United Kingdom|British]] hospitals to enable discussion in front of patients, the latter mainly for children.
A person responsible for handling and washing bodies is now known as a [[diener]], morgue attendant, or [[autopsy]] technician.
==Types of cold chambers==
There are two types of mortuary cold chambers: ;Positive temperature Bodies are kept between 2 °C (36 °F) and 4 °C (39 °F). While this is usually used for keeping bodies for up to several weeks, it does not prevent decomposition, which continues at a slower rate than at room temperature.<ref>''Zentralblatt der allgemeine Pathologie''; 1957 May 4; 96(5-6):280-86; [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/13457004?log$=activity NIH.gov]</ref>
;Negative temperature Bodies are kept at between −10 °C (14 °F) and −50 °C (−58 °F). Usually used at forensic institutes, particularly when a body has not been identified. At these temperatures the body is completely [[Freezing|frozen]] and [[decomposition]] is very much reduced.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
==Mortuaries across the globe== {{Unreferenced section|date=July 2010}} [[Image:A Scene in the New York Morgue.jpg|thumb|right|The first morgue in [[New York City]], opened in 1866 at [[Bellevue Hospital]]]] [[File:Rembrandt - The Anatomy Lesson of Dr Nicolaes Tulp.jpg|thumb|right|An [[autopsy]] is performed in the morgue. This image was the [[The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp|Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp]]]]
In some countries, the body of the deceased is [[embalmed]] before disposal, which makes refrigeration unnecessary.
In many countries, the family of the deceased must make the burial within 72 hours (three days) of death, but in some other countries it is usual that burial takes place some weeks or months after the death. This is why some corpses are kept as long as one or two years at a hospital or in a [[funeral home]]. When the family has enough money to organize the ceremony, the corpse is taken from the cold chamber for burial.
In some funeral homes, the morgue is in the same room, or directly adjacent to, the specially designed ovens, known as [[retort]]s, that are used in funerary [[cremation]]. Some religions dictate that, should a body be cremated, the family must witness its incineration. To honor these religious rites, many funeral homes install a viewing window, which allows the family to watch as the body is inserted into the retort. In this way, the family can honor their customs without entering the morgue.
Oversized mortuary fridge spaces have been installed in British hospitals to cope with the increase in obesity.<ref>{{cite news |title=London mortuaries install more fridges for obese bodies |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-44337436 |accessdate=7 September 2018 |publisher=BBC |date=27 June 2018}}</ref>
===Waiting mortuary=== <!-- This section is linked from the redirect [[Waiting mortuary]] --> A '''waiting mortuary''' is a mortuary building designed specifically for the purpose of confirming that deceased persons are truly deceased. Prior to the advent of modern methods of verifying death, people feared that they would be buried alive. To alleviate such fears, the recently deceased were housed for a time in waiting mortuaries, where attendants would watch for signs of life. The corpses would be allowed to decompose partially prior to burial. Waiting mortuaries were most popular in 19th-century Germany, and were often large, ornate halls.
A bell was strung to the corpses to alert attendants of any motion. Although there is no documented case of a person being saved from accidental burial in this way,<ref>{{cite book |last=Roach |first=Mary |authorlink= Mary Roach|title=[[Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers]] |year=2003 |publisher= [[W. W. Norton & Company]] |location= |isbn= 0-393-32482-6}}</ref> it is sometimes erroneously believed that this was the origin of the phrase “saved by the bell”, whilst in fact, the phrase originates from the sport of [[boxing]].<ref>[http://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/311000.html Saved by the bell at Phrases.org]</ref>
==Alternate meanings==
In [[American English]]:
*'''Morgue''' is used to refer to the room in which [[newspaper]] or [[magazine]] [[publisher]]s keep their back issues and other historical references, as they serve a similar purpose to human morgues. See [[Morgue file]]. *'''Morgue''' is used in some science fiction books as the name for the armory aboard ships, when they contain some form of powered armor. {{Citation needed|date=April 2015}} *'''Mortuary''' can also refer to a [[funeral home]].
{{Commons cat|Morgues}}
==See also== *[[Body bag]] *[[Diener]] *[[Pathology]] *[[Tissue digestion]] *[[Toe tag]] *[[Body farm]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{death}}
[[Category:Medical aspects of death]] [[Category:Forensic facilities]]

revision.text:
[[File:Sketch of an overview of the courtroom that includes the judges bench and the defense table. 24.jpg|thumb|Courtroom sketch of the murder trial in 1970.]]
In 1970 there was a series of criminal prosecutions in [[New Haven, Connecticut]] against various members of the [[Black Panther Party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/427/427.F2d.239.772.34604.html |title=427 F.2d 239 |publisher=Bulk.resource.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> The charges ranged from criminal conspiracy to felony murder. All indictments stemmed from the murder of 19-year-old Alex Rackley in the early hours of May 21, 1969. The trials became a rallying-point for the [[American Left]], and marked a decline in public support, even among the black community, for the Black Panther Party.
==The crime== On May 19, 1969, members of the [[Black Panther Party]] kidnapped fellow Panther [[Alex Rackley]], who had fallen under suspicion of informing for the FBI. He was held captive at the New Haven Panther headquarters on Orchard Street, where he was tortured and interrogated for two days until he confessed. His interrogation was tape recorded by the Panthers.<ref name=tape>Paul Bass, [http://www.newhavenindependent.org/index.php/archives/entry/rackley_trial_tape_surfaces/ Black Panther Torture “Trial” Tape Surfaces], New Haven Independent, Feb 21, 2013</ref> During that time, national party chairman [[Bobby Seale]] visited New Haven and spoke on the campus of [[Yale University]] for the Yale Black Ensemble Theater Company.<ref>{{Cite journal | url = https://books.google.com/?id=4-ICAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA52 | title = New York Magazine | author1 = New York Media | first1 = LLC | date = 1970-11-23}}</ref> After his speech, Seale briefly stopped by the headquarters where Rackley was being held captive, though it was never proven that he went inside or knew about Rackley's treatment.
Early the next day, three Panthers - [[Warren Kimbro]], [[Lonnie McLucas]], and national Panther "Field Marshal" [[George Sams, Jr.]] - drove Rackley to the nearby town of [[Middlefield, Connecticut]]. Kimbro shot Rackley once in the head and McLucas shot him once in the chest. They dumped his corpse in the [[Coginchaug River]], where it was discovered the next day.
Police raided the Panther headquarters, eventually arresting nine [[New Haven]] area Black Panthers (in addition to two juveniles). McLucas and Sams were captured later.
Sams and Kimbro confessed to the murder, and agreed to testify against McLucas in exchange for a reduction in sentence. Sams also implicated Seale in the killing, telling his interrogators that while visiting the Panther headquarters on the night of his speech, Seale had directly ordered him to murder Rackley. In all, nine defendants were indicted on charges related to the case. In the heated political rhetoric of the day, these defendants were referred to as the "New Haven Nine", a deliberate allusion to other ''cause-celebre'' defendants like the "[[Chicago Seven]]".
==Protest and unrest== The first trial was that of Lonnie McLucas, the only person who physically took part in the killing who refused to plead guilty. In fact, McLucas had confessed to shooting Rackley, but since some of the charges brought against him made him eligible for the [[death penalty]], a not-guilty plea was the only logical trial strategy.
Jury selection began in May 1970. The case and trial were already a national ''cause célèbre'' among critics of the Nixon administration, and especially among those hostile to the actions of the [[FBI]]. Under the Bureau's then-secret "Counter-Intelligence Program" ([[COINTELPRO]]), FBI director [[J. Edgar Hoover]] had ordered his agents to disrupt, discredit, or otherwise neutralize radical groups like the Panthers. Hostility between groups organizing political dissent and the Bureau was, by the time of the trials, at a fever pitch. Hostility from the left was also directed at the two Panthers cooperating with the prosecutors. Sams in particular, never widely popular in the movement, was accused of being an informant, and lying to implicate Seale to hide his own complicity with the FBI.
Beginning with the pretrial proceedings, tens of thousands of supporters of the Panthers arrived in New Haven individually and in organized groups. They were housed and fed by community organizations and by sympathetic Yale students in their dormitory rooms. The Yale college dining halls provided basic meals for everyone. Protesters met daily ''en masse'' on the [[New Haven Green]] across the street from the Courthouse (and one hundred yards from Yale's main gate) to hear protest speakers. Among the speakers were [[Jean Genet]], [[Benjamin Spock]], [[Abbie Hoffman]], [[Jerry Rubin]], and [[John Froines]] (an assistant professor of chemistry at the University of Oregon). Teach-ins and other events were also held in the colleges themselves.
Towards midnight on May 1, two bombs exploded in Yale's [[Ingalls Rink]], where a concert was being held in conjunction with the protests.<ref name="BassRae">{{cite book |last1=Bass |first1=Paul |last2=Rae |first2=Douglas |authorlink2=Douglas W. Rae |title=Murder in the Model City: The Black Panthers, Yale, and the Redemption of a Killer |publisher=Basic Books |year=2006 |pages=159–160}}</ref> Although the rink was damaged, no one was injured, and no culprit was identified.<ref name="BassRae"/>
Yale chaplain [[William Sloane Coffin]] stated, "All of us conspired to bring on this tragedy by law enforcement agencies by their illegal acts against the Panthers, and the rest of us by our immoral silence in front of these acts," while Yale President [[Kingman Brewster Jr.]] issued the statement, "I personally want to say that I'm appalled and ashamed that things should have come to such a pass that I am skeptical of the ability of Black revolutionaries to achieve a fair trial anywhere in the U.S." Brewster's generally sympathetic tone enraged many of the university's older, more conservative alumni, heightening tensions within the school community.
As tensions mounted, Yale officials sought to avoid deeper unrest and to deflect the real possibility of riots or violent student demonstrations. [[Sam Chauncey]] has been credited with winning tactical management on behalf of the administration to quell anxiety among law enforcement and New Haven's citizens, while [[Kurt Schmoke]], a future [[Rhodes Scholar]], mayor of [[Baltimore, MD]] and Dean of [[Howard University]] School of Law, has received kudos as undergraduate spokesman to the faculty during some of the protest's tensest moments. Ralph Dawson, a classmate of Schmoke's, figured prominently as moderator of the Black Student Alliance at Yale (BSAY).
In the end, compromises between the administration and the students quashed the possibility of violence. While Yale (and many other colleges) went "on strike" from May Day until the end of the term, like most schools it was not actually "shut down". Classes were made "voluntarily optional" for the time and students were graded "Pass/Fail" for the work done up to then.
==Trials== [[File:Oil Pastels and ink drawing of jurors consisting of six African American women, one white woman and one white man. 20.jpg|thumb|left|Black Panther trial sketch by [[Robert Clark Templeton]]]] [[File:Sketch of four head representations, including Ericka Huggins, Warren Kimbro, Bobby G. Seale and George Sams Jr.jpg|thumb|Courtroom portraits including Huggins, Kimbro, Seale and Sams, 1970.]] McLucas's trial set new records for the scale of judicial proceedings in Connecticut. It was the first in Connecticut to have [[metal detector]]s installed at the courtroom doors; jury selection took six weeks, a Connecticut record, and the jury deliberated for six days, another Connecticut record.<ref name="panthers2.htm">{{cite web|url=http://www.edwardjayepstein.com/archived/panthers2.htm |title=Edward Jay Epstein's Home Page |publisher=Edwardjayepstein.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> Despite impassioned accusations from protesters that McLucas was being railroaded into the electric chair by a "racist jury,"<ref>Black, Jonathan, "How do you try a revolutionary? A Black Panther trial in New Haven," ''Village Voice'', July 23, 1970</ref> the jurors (ten white, two black) acquitted him on the most severe charges, convicting him instead on the sole charge of conspiracy to commit murder. His defense attorney declared, "The judge was fair, the jury was fair, and, in this case, a black revolutionary was given a fair trial."<ref>"[http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,902777,00.html Justice In New Haven]," in ''Time'' Magazine, September 14, 1970</ref> McLucas was sentenced to twelve to fifteen years in prison. His two collaborators in the murder, who had pleaded to second degree murder, were released after four years.<ref name="panthers2.htm"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edwardjayepstein.com/archived/panthers.htm |title=Edward Jay Epstein's Home Page |publisher=Edwardjayepstein.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref><ref name="FTR-bobbyseale.HTML">{{cite web|url=http://www.gadflyonline.com/8-6-01/FTR-bobbyseale.HTML |title=Gadfly Online |publisher=Gadfly Online |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref>
In October, 1970, [[Bobby Seale]] went on trial alongside [[Ericka Huggins]], founder of the New Haven chapter. This trial was an even larger undertaking, involving a full four months of jury selection. Seale's attorney emphasized that it was only Sams' testimony that tied Seale to Rackley's murder. Huggins's voice was heard on a tape recording of the victim's interrogation, played for the jury. Her lawyer argued that Huggins had been acting under duress.<ref name="tape"/> The jury was unable to reach a verdict, deadlocked 11 to 1 for Seale's acquittal and 10 to 2 for Huggins' acquittal. On May 25, 1971 Judge Harold Mulvey stunned courtroom spectators by dismissing the charges against Huggins and Seale saying, "I find it impossible to believe that an unbiased jury could be selected without superhuman efforts -- efforts which this court, the state and these defendants should not be called upon either to make or to endure".<ref>New York Times, March 1, 2000 [https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/01/nyregion/harold-m-mulvey-86-judge-at-tense-black-panther-trials.html Harold M. Mulvey, Judge at Tense Black Panther Party Trials]</ref>
==Aftermath== Both the Panthers and the FBI suffered damage to their reputations, after the public exposure of their most unsavory activities.
In 1971, a group of left-wing radicals calling themselves the [[Citizens' Commission to Investigate the FBI]] burglarized an FBI field office in [[Media, Pennsylvania]], which was found to be spying on [[Swarthmore College]] students and faculty. Among the materials stolen in this break-in were documents revealing the nature of the COINTELPRO program. Within the year, Director [[J. Edgar Hoover|Hoover]] declared that the centralized COINTELPRO was over.<ref>[http://www.albionmonitor.net/9905a/jbcointelpro.html A Short History of FBI COINTELPRO], retrieved July 13, 2007.</ref>
For the Panthers, the Seale trial may have been the height of their national exposure and their popularity among the broader left-wing movement. A string of violent confrontations with law-enforcement, along with the trials and convictions of national party leaders that followed, left the movement spent and adrift, and by the mid-1970s it was largely inactive.
The trial surfaced again in the news in 2000, when former first lady [[Hillary Clinton]] ran for U.S. Senate in the state of New York. Anti-Clinton activists discovered that during the trials, Clinton (then a Yale law student named Hillary Rodham) volunteered to monitor the trial for violations of civil rights, for the [[American Civil Liberties Union]]. Widely circulated mass [[e-mails]] erroneously ascribed to Clinton responsibility for "getting the defendants off," and also blamed the future head of the [[Bill Clinton|Clinton]] [[U.S. Justice Department]]'s [[Civil Rights Division]], [[Bill Lann Lee]], who was a Yale undergraduate at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/politics/clintons/panthers.asp |title=Urban Legends Reference Pages: Black Panthers and Hillary Clinton |publisher=Snopes.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> Although both were much too junior to have had any role in the actual legal defense, according to John Elvin of the conservative newsmagazine ''[[Insight on the News]]'', "Insight reviewed biographies of Hillary Clinton by Milton, [[David Brock|[David] Brock]] and [[Roger Morris (American writer)|Roger Morris]] for this story and lengthy selections from such other biographies as [[Barbara Olson]]'s Hell to Pay. Together, relying on primary and other firsthand sources, they unquestionably back [[David Horowitz (conservative writer)|David Horowitz]]'s contention that Hillary was a campus leader during the Panther protests";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truthorfiction.com/rumors/h/hillarypanthers.htm |title=Hillary Clinton once supported Black Panthers on trial for murder-Truth! |publisher=Truthorfiction.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}}</ref> Lee apparently played no prominent role in any protests.<ref name="hillary.html">[http://tafkac.org/ulz/hillary.html Urban Legend Zeitgeist: Hillary Clinton and the Black Panthers<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 2006, Kelly Moye revealed that he was a police informant recruited to infiltrate the Panthers by Nick Pastore, head of New Haven Police's Intelligence Division. George Sams held a gun to Moye's head and demanded he turn over his car. Rackley was driven to his death in Moye's car. The police followed Moye's car as it left toward the murder destination but lost sight of the car prior to the murder.<ref>[http://www.newhavenindependent.org/index.php/archives/entry/after_37_years_spy_comes_in_from_cold/ After 37 Years, Spy Comes In From Cold, by Paul Bass, New Haven Independent, Aug 4, 2006]</ref> The State Police discovered Rackley's body the next day. This epilogue was detailed in an article "After 37 Years, Spy Comes In From Cold" by Paul Bass, author of Murder In The Model City: The Black Panthers, Yale and the Redemption of a Killer.
Detective [[Nick Pastore]], who arrested Seale and brought him to New Haven to stand trial, went on to become New Haven's Chief of Police, widely renowned for his successful policy of [[community policing]], and now heads a nonprofit advocacy group in [[Washington, DC]] named Criminal Justice Policy. Thirty one years later, when Seale returned to New Haven to speak at the [[Yale Repertory Theatre]], Pastore decided to attend and even presented Seale with a pink [[Porcelain pigs|porcelain pig]] and a hug, congratulating him for continuing "the struggle".<ref name="FTR-bobbyseale.HTML"/>
==See also== *[[Revolutionary Communist League (Internationalist)]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} *[http://www.hartfordadvocate.com/gbase/News/content.html?oid=oid:43434 The Night of the Panthers], [[Hartford Advocate]], November 20, 2003
{{commons category|Black Panther Trial Sketches}}
{{Black Panther Party}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox animal | name = Obo | image = Obo-II-Drawing.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Ch. Obo, foundation sire of the American Cocker Spaniel. | birth_name = | othername = | species = Dog | breed = [[American Cocker Spaniel]] | gender = Male | birth_date = August 7, 1882<ref name="studcard">{{cite web|url=http://www.asc-cockerspaniel.org/images/history/obostud.pdf|title=Obo Stud Card|format=PDF|publisher=American Spaniel Club|accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref> | birth_place = | death_date = January 2, 1895 | death_place = | resting_place = Rollinsford, New Hampshire | resting_place_coordinates = | relativeage = | nationality = United States | occupation = | employer = | role = [[Conformation show|Show]] dog | years_active = | known = Foundation sire of the [[American Cocker Spaniel]] breed | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = Mr J.P. Willey | parents = Oboe (sire), Chloe II (dam) | children = | weight = {{convert|23|lb|kg}} | height = {{convert|10|in|cm}} at the [[withers]] | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} [[Championship (dog)|Ch.]] '''Obo''' (1882–1895), was an [[American Cocker Spaniel]] who is considered to be the father of the modern breed, though physically, he was different from today's American Cocker.<ref name="happyhealthy">{{cite book|last=Palika|first=Liz|title=Cocker Spaniel: Your Happy Healthy Pet|year=2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-39060-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tVdraCvRVNcC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=%22obo+ii%22&source=bl&ots=FNvyEoHTUO&sig=oBp4Vjd-RpumIPbFjgjLBsL0cOI&hl=en&ei=wVk7TZLOJJCJhQfj84DICg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBzge#v=onepage&q=%22obo%20%22&f=false|page=21}}</ref> During his day, he was a successful [[conformation show|show]] dog, winner of many Best-in-Show titles.
==Background== The Obo kennel of Spaniels were owned by James Farrow, who was breeding dogs from the 1870s onwards. Obo's sire and namesake, Obo, was whelped on June 14, 1879. F. E. Schofield, an authority on Spaniels, wrote, "Obo, it goes without saying, was the greatest force in the revival of the Cocker."<ref name="lloyd16">[[#lloyd1939|Lloyd (1939)]]: p. 16</ref> Obo was so well known for his victories in [[conformation show]]s that his owner, Farrow, spoke of an offer made from America, "The dog's stock did so well in America that one hundred guineas was offered by an American breeder for the use of this Spaniel for one season's stud service. The offer was refused."<ref name="lloyd18">[[#lloyd1939|Lloyd (1939)]]: p. 18</ref>
==Birth and career== J. P. Willey of [[Rollinsford, New Hampshire#Salmon Falls Village|Salmon Falls]], [[New Hampshire]], was already a [[cocker spaniel]] breeder in America when he attempted to purchase Obo from Farrow in England. He was turned down, but managed to purchase Chloe II, a successful female Cocker Spaniel show dog and had her mated to Obo prior to her being shipped to the United States.<ref name="mercer111">[[#mercer1890|Mercer (1890)]]: p. 111</ref>
From Chloe II's litter came two males, Obo and Black Silk, and a female named Black Gem. Black Gem would die from [[Canine distemper|distemper]] after returning from winning the Produce Stake at a New York show.<ref name="mercer111"/> Obo was shown for the first time at [[Manchester, New Hampshire]] in September 1883, where he placed first. He would go on to have further wins at [[Lowell, Massachusetts|Lowell]], [[New Haven, Connecticut]] and [[New York City]]. Obo II's trophy for Best Cocker Spaniel from the New Haven Kennel Club show in 1884 was gifted to the American Spaniel Club in 2004.<ref name=ascoboii /> Obo's [[American Kennel Club]] number was 4911.<ref name="mercer121">[[#mercer1890|Mercer (1890)]]: p. 121</ref>
His puppies were also highly successful, winning puppy prizes at Lowell, first and second at New York and the top three puppy places at New Haven.<ref name=ascoboii /> Four of his best known offspring are Red Brucie, Sandspring Surmise, Midcliff Miracle Man and Limestone Laddie.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilcox|first=Charlotte|title=The Cocker Spaniel|year=1997|publisher=Capstone Press|isbn=978-1-56065-540-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BN3aRpI4pVUC&pg=PA18&dq=%22obo+ii%22&hl=en&ei=PEo7TcK6MYGGhQeC-tWLCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CGkQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22obo%20ii%22&f=false|page=19}}</ref> In addition, Obo II was the sire of the first dark red Cocker Spaniel in America, Little Miss Rover.<ref>{{cite book|last=Iby|first=Judith P.|title=The Cocker Spaniel|year=1995|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-87605-381-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E_DdzZ3KfQMC&q=%22obo+ii%22&dq=%22obo+ii%22&hl=en&ei=tFc7TfiLDc22hAejtbnxCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBzgo|page=21}}</ref>
==Death and legacy== Modern writers consider Obo to be the father of the modern American Cocker Spaniel. He was different from the modern breed, being {{convert|10|in|cm}} tall with a long body.<ref name="happyhealthy"/>
Obo died on January 2, 1895, and was buried on the property of his owner in Salmon Falls village in Rollinsford. Today, the grave is located behind the [[Rollinsford Grade School]] in the town of Rollinsford. At the request of the American Spaniel Club, the grave site was registered with the Rollinsford Historical Society as a historical monument.<ref name=ascoboii>{{cite web|title=Obo|url=http://www.asc-cockerspaniel.org/index.php/history/articles-and-artifacts/194-obo-ii.html|publisher=American Spaniel Club|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> [[File:Obo II Grave site.jpg|thumb|Grave marker of Obo II.]]. The gravestone is listed to the National Register of Historic Places as a contributing resource to Rollinsford Grade School.
Obo was the first American example of the Obo type which was recognisable on both sides of the Atlantic in many dogs with the prefix "Obo" or "Omo". H. S. Lloyd in the 1939 edition of ''The Popular Cocker Spaniel'' pointed out that compared to the Cocker Spaniel breed of the 1930s that the Obo type was low to the ground and a "trifle full in eye".<ref name="lloyd18"/>
==References== ;Specific {{reflist|2}}
;General *{{cite book|last=Mercer|first=F.H.F.|title=The Spaniel and its Training|year=1890|publisher=Forest and Stream Publishing Co|url=https://archive.org/stream/spanielitstraini00merc#page/n0/mode/2up|location=New York|ref=mercer1890}} *{{cite book|last=Lloyd|first=H.S.|title=The Popular Cocker Spaniel|year=1939|publisher=Popular Dogs Publishing Company|location=London|edition=4th|ref=lloyd1939}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{orphan|date=July 2013}}{{no footnotes|date=July 2013}}{{essay-like|date=July 2013}}}}
'''Oxytocin Treatment for Postpartum Depression'''
[[Oxytocin|Oxytocin (OT)]] has potential to be a treatment for [[Postpartum depression|Postpartum Depression (PPD)]]<sup>[[#References|[1]]]</sup>. Oxytocin is released when a mother cares for her child, making the interaction pleasurable<sup>[[#References|[2]]]</sup>. Mothers that report high levels of infant-mother bonding and demonstrate responsive and sensitive parenting generally show increased levels of OT and brain reward center activation during play sessions<sup>[[#References|[1]]]</sup>. According to Slattery and Neumann, the oxytocin system of mothers experiencing PPD may have altered activity<sup>[[#References|[3]]]</sup>. These mothers have trouble bonding with their infants when they are born<sup>[[#References|[1]]]</sup>. An experiment found that mothers, who have low attachment ratings to adults and their infants, also have lower levels of OT when caring for their children<sup>[[#References|[3]]]</sup>. It is thought that women experiencing PPD may benefit from intranasal OT because this treatment would help the mother feel happier and assist her in bonding with the child <sup>[[#References|[1]]]</sup>. Another experiment shows that administering OT to a mother sheep increases the amount of care that she gives to offspring <sup>[[#References|[2]]]</sup>. Further experimentation needs to be done in order to determine the effectiveness of OT as a treatment for Postpartum Depression<sup>[[#References|[3]]]</sup>.
==Intranasal Administration== Intranasal (IN) administration, as opposed to more conventional routes, such as oral or intravenous infusion, offers an alternative method for drug delivery. This method is often the preferred method<sup>[[#References|[4]]]</sup>. [[Oxytocin|Oxytocin (OT)]] is a neuropeptide that can be administered in this manner. IN delivery methods are gaining popularity due to the non-invasive nature of the method. IN generally does not require complicated sterile preparations, is relatively painless, and often can be administered quickly by a medical doctor, or in some cases the patient. IN maximizes the convenience and comfort of the patient, making a treatment regimen more likely to be followed<sup>[[#References|[4]]]</sup>. During [[Postpartum depression|Postpartum Depression (PPD)]], some women may be less likely to seek treatment if treatment is inconvenient. In addition, new mothers (especially if suffering with depression) may feel socially isolated or overwhelmed by responsibilities of caring for a new infant. IN not only provides a convenient delivery method, but is also a logical choice based on efficacy. Tissue in nasal cavities is highly vascular, providing a large surface area for absorption. Large surface areas allow for quick drug onset, meaning greater potential for the drug to reach the central nervous system without undergoing [[first-pass metabolism]]<sup>[[#References|[4]]]</sup>. Avoiding first-pass metabolism allows more of the drug to be available for treatment. Gastrointestinal discomfort and digestive side-effects can also be avoided by IN dosage<sup>[[#References|[4]]]</sup>. IN delivery allows OT to cross the [[blood brain barrier]], expediting the drug to the central nervous system<sup>[[#References|[5]]]</sup> and cerebrospinal fluid. The blood-brain-barrier normally protects the brain by blocking certain chemicals and toxins from reaching the brain. Increased levels of OT can be found in salivary samples after intranasal administration of the neuropeptide. Salivary OT levels can remain higher than baseline levels four hours after dosage, suggesting that OT is still producing an active response<sup>[[#References|[5]]]</sup>. This may be an effective way of monitoring levels of OT levels during short-term treatment or help identify women at risk of or have a history of PPD. Though OT can be administrered intravenously (and is sometimes the appropriate method depending on the medical situation), IN administration offers many advantages that make it an ideal choice for short-term treatment.
==Side Effects== A review of 38 randomized and controlled trials suggests that short-term use of intranasal oxytocin appears to have few side-effects, with no difference when compared to a placebo group. Short-term use of intranasal [[Oxytocin|oxytocin (OT)]] appears to be equally safe in vulnerable individuals as well as those deemed healthy. Three adverse incidents have been reported; two were thought to be caused by actual misuse of the nasal spray and one was linked with a more lengthy treatment regimen. The most frequently reported subjective sensation was calmness; however, there were no detectable differences between groups of OT use and placebo<sup>[[#References|[6]]]</sup>. Given that [[Postpartum depression|Postpartum Depression (PPD)]] is not a chronic illness in nature, short-term intranasal OT treatment may be a logical application to alleviate some of the negative consequences associated with PPD. Effects of OT that may be beneficial are reduced levels of anxiety, increased trust levels and increased eye gaze<sup>[[#References|[6]]]</sup>, all which could be beneficial side-effects for women suffering from PPD. Duration of treatment seems to be a key factor in safety. Allergic reactions, neurological disorders, and cardiovascular conditions should always be considered, but especially so if treatment is long-term. OT can modify heart rates and cause excessive fluid intake (antidiuretic effect). Intravenous infusion (IV) of oxytocin is often used to induce labor and enhance milk lactation during postpartum care. IV use can cause side-effects such as cardiovascular manifestations in the form of [[tachycardia]] and [[bradycardia]]. In addition, nausea, vomiting, and headaches can occur with IV application. Less frequently, water intoxication, skin rash, and anaphylactoid reactions have been reported<sup>[[#References|[6]]]</sup>.
==Experimentation== Intranasal oxytocin (OT) has been used to alleviate some of the symptoms associated with [[Postpartum depression|Postpartum Depression (PPD)]]. Research by McErlean and Dadds suggests that intranasal OT, when combined with behavioral interventions, can remediate some of the mother-infant disturbances associated with PPD. This was the first study to evaluate both the individual effects of OT and the combined effects of OT in conjunction with maternal coaching. The study consisted of seventy-seven mothers (with sub-clinical levels of PPD) with infants ranging from eight to thirty weeks. In addition to the mother-baby interaction coaching, randomly selected mothers were treated with either 24IU OT or a placebo nasal spray over a period of two sessions; measurements were taken over a course of three time periods. Both questionnaire data and observational data, such as eye contact, positive vocalizations, and interaction quality, were used for evaluation purposes. There were significant interactions between the therapy and the OT in regard to maternal behavior. OT also seemed to benefit those mothers who were not involved with the therapy when compared to those that received the placebo nasal spray<sup>[[#References|[1]]]</sup>. OT has also been linked with lowering the human stress response<sup>[[#References|[3]]]</sup>. Lowering a stress response in women that are suffering from PPD may be beneficial to the infant-mother bond. Studies have shown that breast-feeding causes levels of plasma OT to increase in women. Experiments designed and performed in the 1980s helped researchers understand the correlation between breastfeeding prior to a stressful event and the decreased stress response observed during the peripartum period. As part of this experiment, lactating women were asked to either breastfeed their infant or hold their infant for a fifteen-minute period approximately thirty minutes before being subjected to a [[Trier social stress test|Trier Stress Test (TSST)]]. During the TSST, women were asked to give an unprepared speech and calculate mental arithmetic in front of an audience. Results indicate that the women that breastfed their infant exhibited less stress during the TSST in comparison to the women that just held their infant<sup>[[#References|[3]]]</sup>. Rising OT levels during breastfeeding may contribute to the lower stress situation.
==References== {{reflist}} * [https://www.academia.edu/1210764/Are_we_there_yet_The_clinical_potential_of_intranasal_oxytocin_in_psychiatry Liu, J., McErlean, R., & Dadds, M. (n.d.). Are we there yet? The clinical potential of intranasal oxytocin in psychiatry.] * Churchland, P. (2011). ''Braintrust''. (pp. 40–42, 100-102). Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press. * [http://www.mdpi.com/1424-8247/3/3/702 Slattery, D., & Neumann, I. (2010). Oxytocin and major depressive disorder: Experimental and clinical evidence for links to aetiology and possible treatment. Pharmaceuticals, 1(3), 702-724.] * Costantino, H. R., Illum, L., Brandt, G., Johnson, P. H., & Quay, S. C. (2007). Intranasal delivery: Physicochemical and therapeutic aspects. International Journal of Pharmaceutics, (337), 1-24. * Weisman, O., Zagoory-Sharon, O., & Feldman, R. (2012). Intranasal oxytocin administration is reflected in human saliva. Psychoneuroendocrinology,(37), 1582–1586. * MacDonald, E., Dadds, M. R., Brennan, J. L., Williams, K., Levy, F., & Cauchi, A. J. (2011). A review of safety, side-effects and subjective reactions to intranasal oxytocin in human research. Psychoneuroendocrinology, (36), 1114–1126.
[[Category:Pathology of pregnancy, childbirth and the puerperium]] [[Category:Treatment of depression]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox royalty | name = Pharasmanes II | succession = 13th [[List of monarchs of Caucasian Iberia|King of Iberia]] | image = Pharasmanes II relief.jpg | image_size = | caption = [[Relief]] of King Pharasmanes | reign = 117–138 | successor = [[Ghadam of Iberia|Ghadam]] | coronation = | predecessor = [[Amazasp I of Iberia|Amazasp I]] | heir = | spouse = [[Ghadana of Armenia|Ghadana]] | issue = [[Ghadam of Iberia|Ghadam]] | house = [[Pharnavazid dynasty]] | house-type = Dynasty | royal anthem = | father = [[Amazasp I of Iberia]] | mother = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Mtskheta]], [[Kingdom of Iberia]] | death_date = 138 | death_place = | place of burial= | religion = [[Georgian paganism]] |}} '''Pharasmanes II the Valiant''' or '''the Brave''' ({{lang-ka|ფარსმან II ქველი}}) was a king of [[Kingdom of Iberia|Iberia]] ([[Kartli]]) from the [[Pharnavazid dynasty]], contemporary of the [[Roman emperor]] [[Hadrian]] (r. 117–138). Professor [[Cyril Toumanoff]] suggests AD 116–132 as the years of Pharasmanes’ reign. He features in several [[Classical antiquity|Classical]] accounts. ==Life== The medieval Georgian annals report Pharasmanes' joint rule with Pharasmanes Avaz, [[diarchy|diarchs]] (one source has the extra pair: Rok and Mihrdat), but several modern scholars consider the Iberian diarchy unlikely as it is not corroborated by the contemporary evidence. Pharasmanes is reported to have been the son of his predecessor, King [[Amazasp I of Iberia|Amazasp I]]. He is said to have married [[Ghadana of Armenia|Ghadana]], daughter of King [[Vologases III of Parthia]] who ruled in [[Armenia]]. According to the medieval ''Life of Kings'', the traditional friendship of the two dyarchs soured at the instigation of the [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] wife of Mihrdat. Toumanoff regards this information a back-projection of the historically recorded enmity of [[Pharasmanes I of Iberia]] and his brother [[Mithridates of Armenia]].Toumanoff, Cyril. Chronology of the Early Kings of Iberia. ''Traditio'' 25 (1969), p. 17. The chronicle then continues a story of an Armenian-[[Roman Empire|Roman]] alliance and their invasion of the [[Parthian Empire|Iranian]]-backed Iberia in which Pharasmanes finds his death.Rapp, Stephen H. (2003), ''Studies In Medieval Georgian Historiography: Early Texts And Eurasian Contexts'', pp. 289-290. Peeters Publishers, {{ISBN|90-429-1318-5}}. ==Reign== [[File:Armazi Bilingual.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Pharasmanes II is mentioned on [[Armazi stele of Serapit]].]] The ''[[Georgian royal annals]]'' describe Pharasmanes in the following way: {{cquote|ფარსმან ქუელი იყო კაცი კეთილი და უხუად მომნიჭებელი და შემნდობელი, ასაკითა შუენიერი, ტანითა დიდი და ძლიერი, მჴნე მჴედარი და შემმართებელი ბრძოლისა, უშიში ვითარცა უჴორცო და ყოვლითავე უმჯობესი ყოველთა მეფეთა ქართლისათა, რომელნი გარდაცვალებულ იყვნეს უწინარეს მისსა.
Pharasmanes the Valiant was a man of kindness and abundance and compassion, beautiful of his age, of big and strong body, courageous horseman and inspirational warrior, fearless as fleshless and all the greater with everything of all the kings of [[Kartli]], who were dead before him.Georgian royal annals, p. e. 51, l. e. 2-3-4-5-6}} The contemporary Classical authors, with more solid historical background, focus on Pharasmanes’ uneasy relations with Rome. He refused in 129 to come and pay homage to the emperor [[Hadrian]]. According to the Aelius Spartianus, one of the authors of [[Augustan History]]: {{cquote|And when some of the kings came to him, he treated them in such a way that those who had refused to come regretted it. He took this course especially on account of Pharasmanes, who had haughtily scorned his invitation.The Historians of Ancient Rome: An Anthology of the Major Writings, Ronald Mellor, p. 552Aelius Spartianus, The Life of Hadrian, XIII}} Pharasmanes then went touring the East, and prompted the [[Alans]] to attack the neighboring Roman provinces by giving them a passage through his realm, even though the emperor had sent him greater gifts including a [[war elephant]], than to any other king of the East. In his pique, Hadrian dressed some 300 criminals in the gold-embroidered cloaks which were part of the return gift of Pharasmanes, and sent them into the arena. According to Spartianus: {{cquote|He showed a multitude of favours to many kings, but from a number he even purchased peace, and by some he was treated with scorn; to many he gave huge gifts, but none greater than to the king of the Iberians, for to him he gave an elephant and a band of fifty men, in addition to magnificent presents. And having himself received huge gifts from Pharasmanes, including some cloaks embroidered with gold, he sent into the arena three hundred condemned criminals dressed in gold-embroidered cloaks as an insult to the king.Aelius Spartianus, The Life of Hadrian, XVII}} [[File:King Pharasmanes on Fasti Ostienses.jpg|thumb|Fragment of the ''[[Fasti Ostienses]]'' which mentions King Pharasmanes' visit to Rome.]] Eventually, the ancient sources report a highly honored visit paid by Pharasmanes to Hadrian’s successor [[Antoninus Pius]]. According to [[Cassius Dio]], he came to Rome as guest of [[Antoninus Pius]], together with his wife, son, and noble retinue where he was especially honored, being allowed to sacrifice in the [[Capitoline Hill|Capitol]] and to have his equestrian statue in the [[Temple of Bellona (Rome)|temple of Bellona]], and also the emperor increased the territory of his kingdom.Kavtaradze, Giorgi Leon (June 2000). "[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/komblema/orte.htm&date=2009-10-26+01:28:18 Caucasica II: The Georgian Chronicles and the Raison d'Ètre of the Iberian Kingdom]", ''Orbis Terrarum'': p. 218. This Pharasmanes, however, might have been [[Pharasmanes III of Iberia|Pharasmanes III]], Pharasmanes II’s possible grandson. This visit was recorded on a fragment of the [[Fasti Ostienses]].Vidman, Ladislav (1982) ''Fasti Ostienses: edendos, illustrandos, restituendos, curavit Ladislavs Vidman''. p.124 According to the ''[[Georgian royal annals]]'' King Pharasmanes was poisoned by the [[chef]] sent by the [[Parthian Empire|Parthians]]. {{cquote|მაშინ სპარსთა გება-ყვეს სიმარჯუე ესე, რამეთუ მოიყვანეს მზარეული ერთი, და აღუთქუეს მას კეთილი დიდი, და რქუეს ესრეთ, ვითარმედ: "წარვედ და შემწყნარე ფარსმან ქუელსა, და წარიტანე შენ თანა წამალი სასიკუდინე, და შეუზავე საჭმელსა თანა მისსა და შეაჭამე". ხოლო წარვიდა მზარეული იგი და ყო ეგრეთ, ვითარცა უთხრეს სპარსთა მათ. და ესრეთ მოკლა ფარსმან მეფე ქუელი.
And then the Persians tried to have some adroitness, and they brought one chef, and promised him great bestowal, and they told him: "Go and serve Pharasmanes the Valiant, and carry with yourself a medicine of death, and mix it with his meal and make him eat it". And a chef went and did so, as the Persians told him to. And that's how he killed Pharasmanes, the valiant king.Georgian royal annals, p.e. 53, l.e. 3-4-5-6-7}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[Pharnavazid dynasty]]||||138 AD}} {{s-bef|before = [[Amazasp I of Iberia|Amazasp I]]}} {{s-ttl|title = [[List of Georgian monarchs|King of Kartli]]|years=117–138}} {{s-aft|after = [[Ghadam of Iberia|Ghadam]]}} {{end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pharasmanes 02 Of Iberia}} [[Category:Kings of Iberia]] [[Category:2nd-century monarchs in Asia]] [[Category:Deaths by poisoning]] [[Category:Pharnavazid dynasty]] [[Category:Assassinated royalty]] [[Category:Assassinated heads of state]] [[Category:Deaths from food poisoning]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox animal | name = Pickles | image = Pickles dog.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | othername = | species = Dog | breed = Mixed Breed [[Collie]] | gender = Male | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = 1967 | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | relativeage = | nationality = | occupation = | employer = | role = | years_active = | known = finding the missing [[FIFA World Cup Trophy#Jules Rimet Trophy|Jules Rimet Trophy]] | tricks = | awards = [[Dogs Trust|National Canine Defence League]] (silver medal) | title = | owner = David Corbett | height = | appearance = | namedafter = | website = }} '''Pickles''' (born 1962 or 1963; died 1967) was a black and white [[collie]] dog, known for his role in finding the stolen [[FIFA World Cup Trophy#Jules Rimet Trophy|Jules Rimet Trophy]] in March 1966, four months before the [[1966 FIFA World Cup]] was scheduled to kick off in [[England]].
==Trophy theft== {{main article|Theft of the Jules Rimet Trophy}} The World Cup trophy was stolen on the afternoon of Sunday 20 March 1966. It had been on public display in a glass cabinet during the "Sport with Stamps" [[Stanley Gibbons]] [[Stampex]] [[Philatelic exhibition|rare stamp exhibition]] at [[Methodist Central Hall Westminster|Methodist Central Hall]] in Westminster. The thief evaded the round-the-clock security, and ignored rare stamps with a value of £3 million to steal the [[silver-gilt]] trophy, which was generally thought to be worth far less.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/20/newsid_2861000/2861545.stm 1966: Football's World Cup stolen]. BBC, On This Day</ref>
A telephone call from a man who called himself "Jackson" to [[Joe Mears]], chairman of [[Chelsea F.C.]] and [[The Football Association]], alerted him that a package would be left at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] the following day: it contained a £15,000 ransom demand, accompanied by the removable lining from the top of the trophy. The package was turned over to the police, who arranged to meet "Jackson". However, when they arrested the man who had mailed the package, whose real name was Edward Betchley, he claimed that he was a middleman, and the real culprit, a man he called "The Pole", was never identified. Betchley was eventually convicted for demanding money with menace, and sentenced to two years' imprisonment. If indeed there were other persons involved in the theft, no one else has ever been found. <ref>[[The Sunday Times]] ''Illustrated History Of Football'' Reed International Books Limited. 1996. p.133 {{ISBN|1-85613-341-9}}</ref>
==Recovery== The rest of the trophy was found on Sunday 27 March, just seven days after it was stolen, wrapped in newspaper lying by the front wheel of a neighbor's car in [[Beulah Hill]], [[Upper Norwood]], South [[London]], by the four-year-old Pickles, while taking a walk with his owner, David Corbett, who worked as a Thames lighterman.<ref>{{cite news | first=Alastair | last=Reid | title=The World Cup | date=10 September 1966 | publisher= | url =http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1966/09/10/1966_09_10_152_TNY_CARDS_000286584?currentPage=3 | work =The New Yorker | page =3 | accessdate =2 February 2007}}</ref><ref name=guardian>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/apr/23/newsstory.sport1 A twist in the tale], The Observer, 23 April 2006</ref> Suspicion of involvement in the theft was attached briefly to David Corbett.<ref>{{cite book|title=The world's strangest mysteries|year=1987|publisher=Gallery Books|location=New York|isbn=0-8317-9678-2|page=545|chapter=The Canine Sherlock Holmes}}</ref> When [[England national football team|England]] won the trophy, as a reward, Pickles was invited to the celebration banquet.
Corbett collected nearly £5,000 as a reward.<ref>Equivalent to nearly £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|5000|1966}} }} in today's pounds</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35872662|title=How Pickles the dog found the World Cup trophy - 50 years on|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> He used the money to buy a house in [[Lingfield, Surrey]], in 1967.<ref>[http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/Owner-looks-life-dog-World-Cup/story-28623899-detail/story.html I'd love a Pickles statue on Wembley Way', says owner of dog which found World Cup in Croydon], Croydon Advertiser, 31 January 2016</ref> Pickles was awarded the silver medal of the [[Dogs Trust|National Canine Defence League]].<ref>[http://www.britishpathe.com/video/30-second-news-three-stories/ Pickles, the World Cup dog, gets his reward], British Pathé, 7 April 1966</ref>
The Football Association had a replica of the cup made in base metal, for publicity use, so the gold original could be kept safe. The original cup was awarded permanently to Brazil after the [[1970 FIFA World Cup]], but it was stolen from the headquarters of [[Brazilian Football Confederation]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]] in December 1983 and never recovered. The replica was bought by FIFA at auction in 1987 for £254,000, and it is held by the [[National Football Museum]] in [[Manchester]].
==Later life== Pickles starred with [[Eric Sykes]] and [[June Whitfield]] in the 1966 film ''[[The Spy with a Cold Nose]]''.<ref name="death"/> He also appeared on several television programmes, including ''[[Blue Peter]]'' and ''[[Magpie (TV series)|Magpie]]''. He was also named "Dog of the Year", and awarded a year of free food by pet food manufacturer [[Spillers]].<ref name=guardian/>
Pickles died in 1967 when he was strangled by his [[choke chain]] lead that caught on a tree branch while he was eating cheddar cheese near his new home in Surrey.<ref name="death">{{cite news | first=Paul | last=Fleckney | title=How Pickles the dog dug up the accursed World Cup | date=10 June 2006 | publisher= | url =http://www.thisislocallondon.co.uk/news/790191.How_Pickles_the_dog_dug_up_the_accursed_World_Cup/ | work =This Is Local London | accessdate =2 February 2007 }}</ref><ref name=guardian/> He was buried in his owner's back garden,<ref>[http://www.lostandfond.co.uk/pet-tribute/pickles/corbett/234 Tribute to Pickles] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403044424/http://www.lostandfond.co.uk/pet-tribute/pickles/corbett/234 |date=3 April 2016 }}, Lost & Fond</ref> and his collar is on display in the [[National Football Museum]] in [[Manchester]].
An entirely fictional version of the story was told in a 2006 [[ITV Network|ITV]] drama written by [[Michael Chaplin (writer/producer)|Michael Chaplin]], called ''Pickles: The Dog Who Won The World Cup''. He was voiced by [[Harry Enfield]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0814261/ Pickles: The Dog Who Won the World Cup (2006) (TV)], IMDB</ref>
A plaque was put up in September 2018, near the spot where Pickles found the World Cup Trophy on Beulah Hill, Upper Norwood.
[[File:PicklesSignBeulahHill.jpg|thumb|Plaque for Pickles on Beulah Hill, Upper Norwood.]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=m7SbwNM4Y0sC The Theft of the Jules Rimet Trophy: The Hidden History of the 1966 World Cup], Martin Atherton, Meyer & Meyer Verlag, 2008, {{ISBN|1841262277}} * [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=purzCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT134 Super Dogs: Heart-warming Adventures of the World’s Greatest Dogs], Malcolm Croft, Summersdale Publishers, 2014, {{ISBN|1783722215}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pickles (cat)}} [[Category:1967 animal deaths]] [[Category:Individual dogs]] [[Category:1966 FIFA World Cup]]
