{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= [[File:Bannockburn in drydock.jpg|300px|''Bannockburn'' in drydock in Kingston, Ontario]] |Ship caption= ''Bannockburn'' in drydock in Kingston, Ontario }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship registry={{flag|Canada|1868}} Montreal, Quebec, Canada |Ship owner=Montreal Transportation Company of Montreal, Quebec |Ship operator= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=[[Sir Raylton Dixon]] & Company, Middlesbrough, England |Ship yard number=386 |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1893 |Ship christened= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship identification=C102093 |Ship acquired= |Ship nickname= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service=November 21, 1902 |Ship fate=Lost |Ship status=Missing |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=[[Lake freighter]] |Ship tonnage= * 1,620[[Gross register tonnage|GRT]] * 1,035[[Net Register Tonnage|NRT]] |Ship displacement= |Ship length={{convert|245|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|40.1|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship depth={{convert|18.4|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship hold depth= |Ship draft= |Ship ice class= |Ship power=Triple expansion three cylinder engine with two boilers, machinery aft |Ship propulsion=One propeller |Ship speed= |Ship capacity= |Ship crew=20 |Ship notes=Often towed the four-masted schooner barge [[Minnedosa (schooner barge)|''Minnedosa'']] }} |}
The steamship '''''Bannockburn''''' was a Canadian registered steel-hulled freighter which disappeared on [[Lake Superior]] in snowy weather on November 21, 1902.<ref name=BEE2>{{cite news|last= |first= |coauthors= |title=Bannockburn (Propeller), C102093, sunk, 25 Nov 1902 | newspaper=[[Buffalo News|Buffalo Evening News]] |pages= |date=November 28, 1902 |url=http://images.maritimehistoryofthegreatlakes.ca/56750/data?n=2 |accessdate=November 1, 2011}}</ref> She was sighted by the captain of a passing vessel, the SS ''Algonquin'', around noon of that day but minutes later disappeared. The wreck of the ship has never been found, with the exception of an oar and a life preserver, and no bodies were ever recovered. Within a year of her disappearance she acquired a reputation as a [[ghost ship]] and became known as '''The [[Flying Dutchman]] of the Great Lakes'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marmuseum.ca/MillsUpdateSept04.html |accessdate=April 13, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410114735/http://www.marmuseum.ca/MillsUpdateSept04.html |title=Marine Museum of the Great Lakes at Kingston| archivedate=April 10, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="MOO">{{cite book|first=John Robert |last=Colombo |title=Mysteries of Ontario |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YGFLAQ-Cu6sC&pg=PA186 |accessdate=3 August 2014 |year=1999 |publisher=Dundurn |isbn=978-0-88882-205-5|page=186}}</ref><ref name=boyer>{{cite book |title=Ghost Ships of the Great Lakes |last=Boyer |first=Dwight |edition=1st |year=1968 |publisher=Freshwater |location=Cleveland, Ohio |isbn= 978-0912514475 |oclc=}}</ref>
==History of the ship prior to sinking== The ''Bannockburn'' had technically sunk once before, on the morning of October 15, 1897: under Captain John Irving, laden with grain and destined for Kingston, Ontario from Chicago, Illinois, she had struck the wing wall of Lock No. 17 of [[Welland Canal]] and sprung a leak sending her to the bottom of the shallow canal where she took on nine feet of water before coming to rest. However, no lives were lost and she was raised afterward.<ref>{{cite news | last=| first=| title=Bannockburn (Propeller), C102093, leak, sunk, 15 Oct 1897 | newspaper=[[Buffalo News|Buffalo Evening News]] | pages=| language=| publisher=| date=October 15, 1897 | url=http://images.maritimehistoryofthegreatlakes.ca/55867/data?n=1 | accessdate =October 30, 2011 }}</ref> She had also been badly damaged several months prior when she ran on the rocks near Snake Island Light on the morning of April 27 while at full speed—however, after dumping 30,000 bushels of grain cargo she was able to float<ref>{{cite news | last=| first=| coauthors=| title=Bannockburn (Propeller), C102093, sunk, 27 Apr 1897 | newspaper=Milwaukee Evening |location=Wisconsin | pages=| language=| publisher=| date=April 21, 1897 | url=http://images.maritimehistoryofthegreatlakes.ca/58916/data?n=3 | accessdate =October 31, 2011}}</ref> and again no lives were lost though her forefoot and frame were badly stove in.<ref>{{cite news | last=| first=| coauthors=| title=Bannockburn (Propeller), C102093, sunk, 27 Apr 1897 | newspaper=[[Buffalo News|Buffalo Evening News]] | pages=| publisher=| date=May 1, 1897 | url=http://images.maritimehistoryofthegreatlakes.ca/58916/data?n=3 | accessdate =October 30, 2011 }}</ref>
==Chronology of disappearance== The final voyage of the ''Bannockburn'' began at the Canadian lakehead near what is now known as [[Thunder Bay]], under Captain George R. Wood. She was [[downbound]] carrying 85,000 bushels of wheat, leaving the city of [[Fort William, Ontario|Fort William]] on November 20 and headed for [[Georgian Bay]]. She suffered a slight grounding but no apparent damage on her way out to the open lake, and her departure was delayed one day. She recommenced her journey on the 21st.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Annual report |author=Canada. Dept. of Marine |year=1903 |page=129 |publisher=Ottawa, Printer to the King |place=Ottawa, Canada |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HAsUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PR4&dq=%22ss+bannockburn%22&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=3#v=onepage&q=%22ss%20bannockburn%22&f=false |accessdate= |isbn= |oclc= }}</ref> Sometime that day, Captain James McMaugh of the [[downbound|upbound]] ''Algonquin'', another lake freighter, reported viewing her through binoculars about {{convert|7|mi|abbr=on}} to the southeast of him, about {{convert|80|mi|abbr=on}} off [[Keweenaw Peninsula|Keweenaw Point]] and {{convert|40|mi|abbr=on}} off [[Isle Royale]]. He was well-acquainted with her profile and he stated that he viewed her "several times" over the course of a few minutes to note her progress, which was very nearly on course. At a certain moment, however, he attempted to spot her and was surprised that he was unable to do so. He blamed this sudden disappearance on the somewhat foggy weather, and dismissed it.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bannockburn Probably Lost |first= |last= |url= http://www3.gendisasters.com/michigan/15801/lake-superior-mi-unknown-location-steamer-bannockburn-lost-nov-1902 |newspaper=Daily News Record| location=Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan |date= November 29, 1902|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref>
A powerful winter storm raked Lake Superior that night. At 11:00 pm the nightwatch pilothouse crew of the passenger steamer ''Huronic'', also upbound on the lake, reported seeing lights on a ship they passed in the storm which they believed were in the pattern of those of the ''Bannockburn''.<ref>{{cite book |title=Off watch: today and yesterday on the Great Lakes |last=Young |first=Anna G. |year=1957 |page=94 |publisher=Ryerson |place=Toronto |isbn= |oclc=3612374 }}</ref> However, no signals of distress were observed, and the two ships passed each other without incident.
The ''Bannockburn'' was reported overdue the following morning at the [[Soo Locks]], but given the weather the previous night, this was not considered unusual. When she still did not report several days later, however, the fear that she had been lost began to grow.
On November 25 the steamer ''John D. Rockefeller'' passed through a field of floating debris near [[Stannard Rock Light]] which might have been that of the ''Bannockburn'',<ref name=BEE1>{{cite news | last=| first=| coauthors=| title =Bannockburn (Propeller), C102093, sunk, 25 Nov 1902 | newspaper=[[Buffalo News|Buffalo Evening News]] | pages=| language=| publisher=| date=November 30, 1902 | url=http://images.maritimehistoryofthegreatlakes.ca/56750/data?n=2 | accessdate =October 30, 2011 }}</ref> though at this time the ''Bannockburn'' had not yet been reported lost and the crew of the ''Rockefeller'' did not know what might have caused the debris field. By November 30, the ship and crew were officially given up as "lost".<ref name=BEE1/>
By November 26, under pressure from the increasingly distressed families of the crew, a Mr. L.L. Henderson, a manager of the Montreal Transportation Company, claimed he had received a wire from the Chicago office of the underwriter's association which was providing insurance coverage for the ship. He told a local newspaper, ''The Fort Williams Times Journal'', that the message read: "The steamer Bannockburn Has been located on the north shore of Lake Superior opposite [[Michipicoten Island]]. Crew safe."<ref name=boyer/>{{rp|p.20}} He later admitted he had no positive information as to her whereabouts but had based his hopeful assertion on news he had heard from the ''Germanic'', another freighter, that she had been seen safely anchored there.
Eventually the underwriters came to the conclusion that the ''Bannockburn'' had stranded on [[Caribou Island]]. This island is surrounded by a dangerous reef, and its lighthouse had been intentionally turned off on November 15.<ref name=boyer/>{{rp|p.22}} If the captain of the ''Bannockburn'' had been hoping to spot its warning light in the darkness of the storm on the 21st, the only evidence he would have had of his closing proximity would have been the shock of the hull striking the reef itself.
On Friday, December 12, the Captain of the Grand Marais Lifesaving Station found a cork life preserver from the ''Bannockburn'' washed up on the beach.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |title=Bannockburn (Propeller), C102093, sunk, 25 Nov 1902 | newspaper=Port Huron Daily Times | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = December 13, 1902 | url = http://images.maritimehistoryofthegreatlakes.ca/56750/data?n=2 | accessdate =October 30, 2011 |oclc=12267844}}</ref> This item is the only known wreckage from the ship ever to have been recovered.
Captain Wood, from Port Dalhousie, Ontario, was the oldest person aboard the vessel, at age 37. Most of the crew were between the ages of 17 and 20. His first mate, Alex Graham, was also from Port Dalhousie, Ontario. One of the ship's two [[Helmsman|wheelsmen]], Arthur Callaghan, was only 16.<ref>{{cite book |title= Shipwrecks, monsters, and mysteries of the Great Lakes |last=Butts |first=Ed |year=2010 |pages=34–35 |publisher= Tundra Books of Northern New York |place=Plattsburgh, New York |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=AQffnhGHgGEC&pg=PA34&dq=%22bannockburn%22+ship+dutchman&hl=en&ei=I9uvTsvpL6TUiAKT3-we&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22bannockburn%22%20ship%20dutchman&f=false |accessdate=October 30, 2011 |isbn=978-1-77049-206-6}}</ref> Although the ship was considered to be of recent manufacture (at nine years old it was still thought of as almost new) the overall inexperience of her crew might have been a factor in her being lost. Such young crews, however, were common on the Great Lakes at the turn of the 20th century because they were inexpensive to hire and shipping firms had strong financial incentives and no legislative reason not to take advantage of this whenever they might, even in Canada.
There are many theories as to what went wrong. Captain McMaugh proposed that the ship might have experienced a boiler explosion<ref name=BEE2/> though he did not hear one and no charred wreckage typical of such an explosion was later found anywhere along the route that the ''Bannockburn'' was known to have taken. Alternatively, the at-that-time uncharted danger of the [[Superior Shoal]] might also have been the cause.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Great lakes ship wrecks: and other Great lakes stories, a compilation of original stories from the pages of the Great lakes gazette |last=Gerred |first=Janice |year=1978 |page=11 |publisher=Voyager |place=Grand Marais, Michigan |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=W6K1TqyFFcaZiQK2if1h&ct=result&id=M2_hAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22superior+shoal%22+bannockburn&q=%22superior+shoal%22#search_anchor |accessdate= |isbn= |oclc=4050245 }}</ref> When the Soo locks were drained at the end of that season, a hull plate from a ship was found in the lock. It was supposed to have belonged to the ''Bannockburn'', and without it her hull would have had an unknown weak point.
The only known memorial to the ''Bannockburn'' is a stone tablet in a church in Port Dalhousie, Ontario. It is in memory of her captain, and was purchased by his brother.<ref name=MOO/>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
[[File:FEMEN Calls for Sex-Boycott.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian group [[Femen]] calling for a sex strike to protest against sexual exploitation of women.]] A '''sex strike''', sometimes called a '''sex boycott''', is a [[Strike action|strike]], a method of [[non-violent resistance]] in which one or multiple persons (usually [[women]]) refrain from [[Human sexual behavior|sex]] with their partners to achieve certain goals. It is a form of temporary [[sexual abstinence]].
Sex strikes have been used to protest many issues, from [[war]] to [[Gang#Gang violence|gang violence]].
== Historical == [[File:Lysistrate (Marble Stele).jpg|thumb|Marble stele of [[Lysistrate]]]]
=== Ancient Greece === The most famous example of a sex strike in the arts is the [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] playwright [[Aristophanes]]' work ''[[Lysistrata]]'', an [[anti-war]] comedy.<ref>[http://investorshub.advfn.com/boards/read_msg.aspx?message_id=27673724 Lucy Burns, sex-strikes through the ages.]</ref> The female characters in the play, led by the eponymous Lysistrata, withhold sex from their husbands as part of their strategy to secure peace and end the [[Peloponnesian War]].
=== Nigeria === Among the [[Igbo people]] of Nigeria, in pre-colonial times, the community of women periodically formed themselves into a Council, a kind of women's trade union. This was headed by the Agba Ekwe, 'the favoured one of the goddess Idemili and her earthly manifestation'. She carried her staff of authority and had the final word in public gatherings and assemblies. Central among her tasks was to ensure men's good behaviour, punishing male attempts at harassment or abuse. What men most feared was the Council's power of strike action. According to Ifi Amadiume, an Igbo anthropologist: "The strongest weapon the Council had and used against the men was the right to order mass strikes and demonstrations by all women. When ordered to strike, women refused to perform their expected duties and roles, including all domestic, sexual and maternal services. They would leave the town ''en masse'', carrying only suckling babies. If angry enough, they were known to attack any men they met."<ref>Amadiume, I. 1987. ''Male Daughters, Female Husbands. Gender and sex in an African society.'' London and New Jersey: Zed Books, pp. 66-67.</ref>
=== World history and prehistory === Citing similar examples of women's strike action in [[hunter-gatherer]] and other precolonial traditions around the world, some [[anthropologist]]s argue that it was thanks to solidarity of this kind—especially collective resistance to the possibility of [[rape]]—that language, culture, and religion became established in our species in the first instance. This controversial hypothesis is known as the "[[Female cosmetic coalitions|Female Cosmetic Coalitions]]", "Lysistrata",<ref>Camilla Power, 1990. [http://www.radicalanthropologygroup.org/old/pub_lysistrata.pdf Lysistrata, the ritual logic of the sex strike.] University of East London (Anthropology) Occasional Papers.</ref> or "sex strike"<ref>Knight, C. 1991. [http://www.chrisknight.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2007/09/Sex-Strike.pdf "The Sex Strike".] In ''Blood Relations. Menstruation and the origins of culture.'' New Haven and London: Yale University Press, pp. 122-153.</ref><ref>Power, C. and I. Watts 1996. Female strategies and collective behaviour: the archaeology of earliest ''Homo sapiens sapiens.'' In J. Steele and S. Shennan (eds), ''The Archaeology of Human Ancestry.'' London and New York: Routledge, pp. 306-330.</ref><ref>Power, C. and L. C. Aiello 1997. "Female Proto-symbolic Strategies". In L. D. Hager (ed.), ''Women in Human Evolution.'' New York and London: Routledge, pp. 153-171.</ref><ref>Power, C. 1999. "Beauty magic: the origins of art". In R. Dunbar, C. Knight and C. Power (eds), ''The Evolution of Culture''. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, pp. 92-112.</ref> theory of human origins.
== Modern times ==
=== Colombia === In October 1997, the chief of the [[Military of Colombia]], General Manuel Bonnet publicly called for a sex strike among the wives and girlfriends of the Colombian left-wing guerrillas, [[drug trafficker]]s, and paramilitaries as part of a strategy—along with diplomacy—to achieve a ceasefire. Also the [[mayor of Bogota]], [[Antanas Mockus]], declared the [[Bogota|capital]] a women-only zone for one night, suggesting men to stay at home to reflect on violence. The guerrillas ridiculed the initiatives, pointing at the fact that there were more than 2,000 women in their army. In the end the ceasefire was achieved, but lasted only a short time.
In September 2006 dozens of wives and girlfriends of gang members from [[Pereira, Colombia|Pereira]], [[Colombia]], started a sex strike called ''La huelga de las piernas cruzadas'' ("the strike of crossed legs") to curb [[gang violence]], in response to 480 deaths due to gang violence in the [[coffee]] region. According to spokeswoman Jennifer Bayer, the specific target of the strike was to force gang members to turn in their weapons in compliance with the law. According to them, many gang members were involved in violent crime for status and sexual attractiveness, and the strike sent the message that refusing to turn in the guns was not sexy.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/5341574.stm | work=[[BBC News]] | title=Colombian gangsters face sex ban | date=2006-09-13 | accessdate=2010-05-23}}</ref> In 2010 the city's murder rate saw the steepest decline in Colombia, down by 26.5%.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2011/feb/09/sex-strike-belgium | work=[[The Guardian]] | title=Do sex strikes ever work? | date=2011-02-09 | accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
In June 2011, women organized in the so-called Crossed Legs Movement in the secluded town of [[Barbacoas, Nariño|Barbacoas]] in southwestern Colombia, started a sex strike to pressure the government to repair the road connecting Barbacoas and its neighboring towns and cities.<ref name="GNAD">{{cite web|url=http://nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu/content/colombian-women-use-sex-strike-pressure-government-repair-road-huelga-de-piernas-cruzadas-20|title=Colombian women use sex strike to pressure government to repair road (Huelga de piernas cruzadas), 2011|website=Global Nonviolent Action Database|publisher=Swarthmore College|accessdate=April 29, 2016}}</ref> They declared that if the men of the town were not going to demand action, they would refuse to have sex with them. The men of Barbacoas showed no support at the beginning of the campaign, but they soon joined in the protest campaign.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Montes|first1=Euclides|title=The "Crossed Legs" Movement: How a Sex Strike Got Things Done|url=http://www.alternet.org/story/151940/the_%22crossed_legs%22_movement%3A_how_a_sex_strike_got_things_done|website=AlterNet|accessdate=April 29, 2016}}</ref> After 112 days strike in October 2011, the Colombian government promised action on road repairs, and construction ensued.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Otis|first1=John|title=Colombian women on 'crossed legs' sex strike over crumbling highway|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/other/colombian-women-crossed-legs-sex-strike-over-crumbling-highway-f8C11531725|accessdate=April 29, 2016|agency=NBC News|date=November 5, 2013}}</ref>
=== Kenya === {{Main|2009 Kenya sex strike}}
In April 2009 a group of [[Kenya]]n women organised a week-long sex strike aimed at [[Politics of Kenya|politicians]], encouraging the wives of [[president of Kenya|the president]] and [[Prime Minister of Kenya|prime minister]] to join in too, and offering to pay [[prostitute]]s for lost earnings if they joined in.<ref name="bbc 8025457">{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8025457.stm | title= Kenyan women hit men with sex ban | publisher= [[BBC News]] | date= 29 April 2009 | accessdate= 9 April 2017}}</ref>
=== Liberia === [[File:Leymah Gbowee (October 2011).jpg|thumb|[[Leymah Gbowee]], awarded with 2011 [[Nobel Peace Prize]]]] In 2003 [[Leymah Gbowee]] and the [[Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace]] organized [[nonviolence]] protests that included a sex strike. Their actions led to peace in [[Liberia]] after a 14‑year [[Second Liberian Civil War|civil war]] and the election of [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]], country's first female head of state.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/moyers/journal/06192009/profile.html Bill Moyers Journal], [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]. June 19, 2009</ref> Leymah Gbowee was awarded the 2011 [[Nobel Peace Prize]] "for her [[nonviolence|non-violent]] struggle for the safety of women and for [[women's rights]] to full participation in peace-building work."<ref name=autogenerated5>{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/laureates/2011/press.html |title=The Nobel Peace Prize 2011 – Press Release |publisher=Nobelprize.org |date=2011-10-07 |accessdate=2011-10-07}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated7>"Kevin Conley, "The Rabble Rousers" in ''O, the Oprah Magazine'', Dec. 2008, posted at www.oprah.com/omagazine/Leymah-Gbowee-and-Abigail-Disney-Shoot-for-Peace-in-Liberia/2#ixzz1bTSs28cd. Retrieved 21 October 2011.</ref>
=== Naples, Italy === In the build-up to [[New Year's Eve#Italy|New Year's Eve]] in 2008, hundreds of Neapolitan women pledged to make their husbands and lovers "sleep on the sofa" unless they took action to prevent [[fireworks]] from causing serious injuries.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7806367.stm Naples sex strike over fireworks], ''BBC News'', Wednesday 31 Dec 2008.</ref>
=== The Philippines === During the summer of 2011, women in rural [[Mindanao]] imposed a several-week-long sex strike in an attempt to end fighting between their two villages.<ref>[http://unhcr.org/v-4e70beb16 "Philippines: Sex Strike Brings Peace"], ''UNHCR''.</ref><ref>Karen Smith, [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/09/19/philippines.sex.strike/index.html?iref=NS1 "Sex strike brings peace to Filipino village"]. ''CNN''. September 19, 2011.</ref>
=== South Sudan === In October 2014, [[Pricilla Nanyang]], a politician in South Sudan, coordinated a meeting of women peace activists in [[Juba]] "to advance the cause of peace, healing and reconciliation." Attendees issued a statement which called on women of South Sudan "to deny their husbands conjugal rights until they ensure that peace returns."<ref>{{Cite news | title = South Sudan women propose sex ban until peace restored – Sudan Tribune: Plural news and views on Sudan | work = Sudan Tribune: Plural news and views on Sudan | accessdate = 2014-10-26 | date = 2014-10-23 | url = http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article52825 }}</ref>
=== Togo === In 2012, inspired by the 2003 Liberian sex strike, the [[Togo]]lese opposition coalition "[[Let's Save Togo]]" asked women to abstain from sex for a week as a [[Protests against Faure Gnassingbé|protest]] against President [[Faure Gnassingbé]], whose family has been in power for more than 45 years. The strike aimed to "motivate men who are not involved in the political movement to pursue its goals".<ref>"[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19389625 Togo women call sex strike against President Gnassingbe]", ''BBC'', 27 August 2012. Retrieved 27 August 2012.</ref> Opposition leader [[Isabelle Ameganvi]] views it as a possible "weapon of the battle" to achieve political change.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stanglin|first=Douglas|title=Togo Women Call Sex Strike to Force President's Resignation|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2012/08/togo-women-call-sex-strike-to-force-presidents-resignation/1#.UG9ZSpjA_3E|newspaper=USA Today|date=27 August 2012}}</ref>
== In entertainment == * [[Lysistrata]] * [[Absurdistan (film)]] * [[Chi-Raq (film)]]
== See also == * [[Matriarchy]] * [[Menstrual synchrony]] * [[Reproductive synchrony]]

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[File:Verscheiden wijzen van pijnigen bij de inquisitie gebruikelijk.jpg|thumb|300px|An artist's depiction of a torture chamber of the Inquisition, ca. 1736. The Inquisitors and the clerk are seen on the right.<ref name="Maxwell">{{cite book|author=James Maxwell Anderson|title=Daily life during the Spanish Inquisition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XxUvfIko1TUC&pg=PA68|accessdate=30 August 2011|year=2002|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-31667-8|pages=68–69}}</ref> The Inquisitors were present to hear the confession, as soon as the torture victim gave up resisting, and the clerk recorded it.<ref name="Maxwell"/> The ''strappado'' i.e. the rope and pulley system through which the victims, having their hands tied behind their backs and the lifting rope attached to their wrists, were raised and then lowered violently from the chamber ceiling, is visible on the right.<ref name="Inquisition from Its Establishment">{{cite book|author1=A. L. Maycock|author2=Ronald Knox|title=Inquisition from Its Establishment to the Great Schism: An Introductory Study|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DmL8CljbqDwC&pg=PA162|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=July 2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-7290-6|page=162}}</ref>]]
A '''torture chamber''' is a room where [[torture]] is inflicted.<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Torture%20chamber Torture chamber. Dictionary.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629015948/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Torture%20chamber |date=29 June 2011 }}. WordNet 3.0. Princeton University. (accessed: July 29, 2009).</ref><ref name="Princeton">[http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=Torture+chamber&sub=Search+WordNet&o2=&o0=1&o7=&o5=&o1=1&o6=&o4=&o3=&h= Princeton Wordnet definition of Torture chamber]. Wordnetweb.princeton.edu. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref> The medieval torture chamber was windowless and often built underground, was lit by a few candles and was specifically designed to induce "horror, dread and despair" to anyone but those possessing a strong mind and "nerves of steel".<ref name="Ryley Scott"/>
Historically, torture chambers were located in royal palaces, in castles of the nobility and even buildings belonging to the church. They featured secret trap-doors which could be activated to throw victims into dark [[dungeon]]s where they remained and eventually died. The skeletal remains of people who disappeared were strewn on the floor of the hidden dungeons. Other times the dungeons under the trap-doors included pits of water where the victim was thrown to drown after a lengthy torture session in the chamber above.<ref name="Alger1889"/>
In Peru, the torture chambers of the [[Inquisition]] were specifically constructed with thick walls so that the screams of the victims could not penetrate them and no sound could be heard from the outside. Other more sophisticated designs used principles of [[acoustics]] to muffle the screams of the tortured and included walls which recessed and protruded in such a fashion as to reflect the screams of the victims so that the sounds would not be carried to the exterior.
The mere presence of the torture chamber was used as a form of intimidation and coercion. The victims were first shown the chamber and if they confessed they would not be tortured inside it. Other times the torture chamber was used as the final destination in a series of prison cells where the victims would gradually be moved from one type of cell to another, under progressively worsening conditions of incarceration, and if they did not recant in the earlier stages they would finally reach the torture chamber. The final stage of actually going to the torture chamber itself, just prior to the initiation of torture, was euphemistically called the "Question".<ref name="Maxwell"/>
== History == [[File:Tower of London, Traitors Gate.jpg|thumb|300px|right|The Tower of London and Traitors Gate. In the [[Middle ages]], torture was carried out in its chambers]] Throughout history torture chambers have been used in a multiplicity of ways starting from [[Torture#Torture in the past|Roman]] times. Torture chamber use during the Middle Ages was frequent. Religious, social and political persecution led to the widespread use of torture during that time. Torture chambers were also used during the [[Spanish Inquisition]] and at the [[Tower of London]].<ref name="Spanish">[http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/mass/torquemada/index.html Torquemada and the Spanish Inquisition:Chapter 3. The water cure. by Anthony Bruno. From Crime Library.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060708192018/http://www.crimelibrary.com/notorious_murders/mass/torquemada/index.html |date=8 July 2006 }}. Crimelibrary.com. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref><ref name="Tower of London">[http://www.mysteriousbritain.co.uk/england/greater-london/hauntings/the-tower-of-london.html ''The White Tower once held torture chambers within its crypt''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081108005928/http://www.mysteriousbritain.co.uk/england/greater-london/hauntings/the-tower-of-london.html |date=8 November 2008 }} From ''Mysterious Britain'' website. Retrieved 5 March 2007</ref><ref name="Tudor">[http://tudors.crispen.org/tower/state_prison.html ''There was no permanent torture-chamber. The basement of the White Tower was used. But prisoners could also be tortured in their cells''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070420005117/http://tudors.crispen.org/tower/state_prison.html |date=20 April 2007 }} From ''Tudor'' website. Retrieved 5 March 2007</ref>
Another example of a torture chamber, not known by many, is "The Thieves Tower" in the [[Alsace, France|Alsace]] region of France. Once a tower used for torture, it is now a small museum displaying instruments used upon the prisoners to get them to confess crimes.<ref name="alsace-route-des-vins.com">[http://www.oconus.com/Main/eArticle.asp?205 Overseas Military Portal website.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061104181353/http://www.oconus.com/Main/eArticle.asp?205 |date=4 November 2006 }} quote:''The Thieves Tower wasn’t a hideout for medieval criminals, but a place where they would pay for their crimes. This museum is home to an authentic torture chamber on the tower’s first floor, which highlights the different methods of punishing criminals, and the tools of the trade, which made this torture so agonizing such as the infamous Rack.'' (article by Michael J. Meese 1/26/2005), retrieved 6-07-2007</ref>
In [[Venice]], the [[Doge's Palace, Venice|Palazzo Ducale]] had its own torture chamber, which was deemed to be of such importance that renovations started in 1507 so that the chamber walls could be kept strong and secure: "''considerata la grandissima importantia de j cameroti di la Camera del tormento che siano forti e securi''".<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard John Goy|title=Building Renaissance Venice: patrons, architects and builders, c. 1430–1500|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SCUkqUZOTc8C&pg=PA231|accessdate=30 August 2011|year=2006|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-11292-4|pages=231–}}</ref>
===Ashoka's Hell=== {{main article|Ashoka's Hell}} According to the narrations of [[Ashokavadana]], King [[Ashoka]], prior to his conversion to Buddhism, was a fierce and sadistic ruler, known as ''Ashoka the Fierce'', who built a palatial torture chamber known as ''Ashoka's Hell''. The legend of the torture palace is detailed in the writings of the Ashokavadana.
According to Ashokavadana, Ashoka asked Girika, who was the official executioner of his kingdom, to design an elaborate torture chamber disguised as a beautiful and "enticing" palace adorned with all kinds of decorations and full of amenities such as exclusive baths decorated with flowers, fruit trees and many ornaments. It was artfully designed to make people long to just look at it.<ref name="A History Of Ancient India"/>
According to legend, beneath the veneer of beauty deep inside the exclusive mansion, torture chambers were constructed which were full of the most sadistic and cruel instruments of torture including furnaces producing molten metal.<ref name="SaranMishi2012">{{cite book|author1=Mishi Saran|author2=Mishi|title=Chasing the Monk's Shadow|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2hkOBNbnOGYC&pg=PA274|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=1 July 2012|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-306439-8|page=274|quote=By Xuanzang's account, King Ashoka was at first a horrid man. He had custom-built torture chambers that he enclosed in high walls. There were furnaces of molten metal, ugly sharp instruments. Every criminal in the land was consigned to this compound, all who crossed its threshold had to die.}}</ref>
According to the accounts contained in the Ashokavadana, Girika, the architect of the chamber, was inspired by descriptions of the five tortures of the [[Buddhist hell]] for the design of the torture chamber and of the torture methods he inflicted upon his victims.<ref name="Scharfstein1995">{{cite book|author=Ben-Ami Scharfstein|title=Amoral Politics: The Persistent Truth of Machiavellism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ibkxwtmP7_UC&pg=PA61|accessdate=18 April 2013|year=1995|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-1-4384-1886-5|pages=61–62|quote=The executioner persuades Ashoka to build a prison in which the tortures imitate those suffered in Buddhist hell [...] In response the executioner wants to kill Ashoka-on the grounds that the king has promised that no one who has entered the prison will leave it alive-...}}</ref><ref name="Obeyesekere2002">{{cite book|author=Gananath Obeyesekere|title=Imagining Karma: Ethical Transformation in Amerindian, Buddhist, and Greek Rebirth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yllblMkRgMMC&pg=PA172|accessdate=18 April 2013|year=2002|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-23243-3|pages=172–173}}</ref> The torture chamber was so terrifying, that King Ashoka himself was thought to have visited [[hell]] so that he could perfect its evil design.<ref name="Vittachi2007">{{cite book|author=Nury Vittachi|title=The Kama Sutra of Business: Management Principles from Indian Classics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xK5CBu0UBygC&pg=PT162|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=13 April 2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-82223-4|page=162|quote=He apparently built a torture chamber that was so horrible that people said he had descended to Hell itself to pick up design ideas. This room was a ...}}</ref>
Ashoka made Girika promise that he would never allow anyone who entered the palace to exit alive, including Ashoka himself.<ref name="A History Of Ancient India"/><ref name="Rich2010"/> In the ''Biographical Sutra of King Ashoka'' the palace is described by the sentence: 'King Ashoka constructed a hell'.<ref name="Brazier2002">{{cite book|author=David Brazier|title=The New Buddhism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v-zNSbmOjVIC&pg=PA59|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=1 June 2002|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-312-29518-9|page=59|quote=There is, for instance, the account in the Biographical Sutra of King Ashoka of how the king, like any good tyrant, had a secret police force and this was backed up by a singularly sinister torture chamber. In the text, it simply refers to this place by saying that 'King Ashoka constructed a hell'}}</ref>
Sometime later a Buddhist monk by the name of [[Samudra]] happened to visit the palace and upon entering he was informed by Girika that he would be tortured to death,<ref name="ConferenceSharma2008">{{cite book|author1=Indian Society for Buddhist Studies. Conference|author2=Satya Prakash Sharma|author3=Baidyanath Labh |author4=Vijay Kumar Singh |author5=Anita K. Billawaria|title=The ocean of Buddhist wisdom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KnYkAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=18 April 2013|year=2008|publisher=New Bharatiya Book Corporation|isbn=978-81-8315-104-7|volume=3|page=135|quote=One day he arrived at Pataliputra and entered the torture chamber built by Asoka which was beautiful from outside. As soon as he entered he was seized by Candagirika, the chief executive who told him that he would be executed by...}}</ref><ref name="The Legend of King Asoka">{{cite book|title=The Legend of King Asoka: A Study and Translation of the Asokavadana|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kp9uaQTQ8h8C&pg=PA73|accessdate=18 April 2013|year=1989|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ.|isbn=978-81-208-0616-0|pages=73–74|quote=Asoka is impressed by this, and enquires as to Samudra's identity. The monk tells him he is a disciple of the Buddha and a follower of Dharma, and reprimands him for having built the torture chamber. Instead, Asoka should guarantee the ...}}</ref> and was subsequently led into the torture chamber. His torturers however failed to injure him and he appeared able to neutralise their torture methods by performing miracles.<ref name="A History Of Ancient India"/><ref name="Rich2010"/><ref name="The Legend of King Asoka"/>
Ashoka converted to Buddhism when he witnessed Samudra's miracles inside the torture chamber.<ref name="A History Of Ancient India"/><ref name="Rich2010"/><ref name="The Legend of King Asoka"/> He also ordered Girika burnt alive and ordered the demolition of the torture palace. According to the Ashokavadana, "the beautiful jail was then torn down and a guarantee of security was extended to all beings".<ref name="A History Of Ancient India">{{cite book|title=A History Of Ancient And Early Medieval India: From The Stone Age To The 12Th Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H3lUIIYxWkEC&pg=PA332|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=1 September 2008|publisher=Pearson Education India|isbn=978-81-317-1120-0|page=332|quote=He was so given to sadistic pleasure that he built a hell on earth — an elaborate and horrific torture chamber, where he amused himself by watching the agony of his unfortunate victims.}}</ref><ref name="Rich2010">{{cite book|author=Bruce Rich|title=To Uphold the World: A Call for a New Global Ethic from Ancient India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c9ZoeR3r7ngC&pg=PT147|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=1 March 2010|publisher=Beacon Press|isbn=978-0-8070-9553-9|page=147|quote= When Ashoka offers him his new job and his parents hesitate to grant him permission to leave, Girika promptly murders them both. Faxian tells us that Ashoka instructed his state torturer to camouflage the torture chambers as an enticing ...}}</ref>
[[Xuanzang]] in his writings mentions that in the 7th century AD he had visited the place where Ashoka's Hell once was.<ref name="A History Of Ancient India"/> In [[India]] the palace is known as "Ashoka's Hell" and its location near [[Pataliputra]] became a popular destination for pilgrims. [[Faxian]] also reports visiting it and his account of the story of the palace differs slightly from that of Xuanzang's.<ref name="The Legend of King Asoka"/><ref name="SchlagerLauer2001">{{cite book|author1=Neil Schlager|author2=Josh Lauer|title=Science and its times: understanding the social significance of scientific discovery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OYU-AQAAIAAJ|accessdate=18 April 2013|year=2001|publisher=Gale Group|isbn=978-0-7876-3933-4|page=64|quote=It appears that Asoka maintained a prison, with an extensive network of torture chambers, for dealing with his enemies. Certainly it is clear that he fought a number of wars, and spilled plenty of blood, in the course of securing his empire ...}}</ref><ref name="Durant2011">{{cite book|author=Will Durant|title=Our Oriental Heritage: The Story of Civilization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ru4LPyMAxxkC&pg=PT707|accessdate=18 April 2013|date=7 June 2011|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-1-4516-4668-9|pages=707|quote=Yuan Chwang, a Chinese traveler who spent many years in India in the seventh century a.d., tells us that the prison maintained by Ashoka north of the capital was still remembered in Hindu tradition as "Ashoka's Hell." There, said his ...}}</ref>
===Inquisition===
==== Methods of coercion ==== [[File:Spisska Hrad 048.jpg|thumb|250px|Artist's depiction of the ''strappado'', including the weight hanging from the victim's ankles. On the left the [[Brazen bull]] is illustrated]] According to Frederick Howard Wines in his book ''Punishment and Reformation: A Study Of The Penitentiary System'' there were three main types of coercion employed in the torture chamber: Coercion by the cord, by water and by fire.<ref name="P and R">{{cite book|author=Frederick Howard Wines|title=Punishment and Reformation. A Study of the Penitentiary System. New Edition, Revised and Enlarged by Winthrop D. Lane|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqVaZKBEGMYC|accessdate=30 August 2011|publisher=Elibron.com|isbn=978-1-4212-3460-1|page=100|quote=In the torture chamber, the three principal forms of coercion were by the cord, by water, and by fire. In the second of these, which has not been described..}}</ref> There were five stages of torture that could have been applied to the accused: he could have been threatened with torture,<ref name="Nature">{{cite book|author=Sir Norman Lockyer|title=Nature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tlAEAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA299|accessdate=30 August 2011|year=1878|publisher=Macmillan Journals ltd.|page=299}}</ref> he could have been taken to the torture chamber and been shown the instruments, he could have been undressed as if in preparation to be tied to the instrument, without actually being tied, he could have been tied to the instrument of torture but not actually getting tortured and finally he could have been tied to the instrument and tortured.<ref name=Finocchiaro>{{cite book|author=Maurice A. Finocchiaro|title=Retrying Galileo, 1633–1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LVMy7yoGbdIC&pg=PA252|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=17 October 2007|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-25387-2|pages=252–}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ucpress.edu/books/pages/10252/10252.intro.php Retrying Galileo, 1633–1992] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513162036/http://www.ucpress.edu/books/pages/10252/10252.intro.php |date=13 May 2008 }}. Ucpress.edu. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref><ref name=Review/>
The process of being tied and led to the torture rack inside the torture chamber was a form of intimidation and was called ''territio realis'' as opposed to ''territio verbalis oder lexis'' which was the verbal threat of torture being made at the judgment hall. ''Territio realis'' as well as the actual torture session were called ''examen rigorosum''.<ref name=Review>{{cite book|title=The Contemporary Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AosFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA688|year=1880|publisher=A. Strahan ''[[The Contemporary Review]]''|pages=688–690}}</ref>
In the book ''Crime and criminal justice in Europe and Canada'' it is mentioned that fear was a factor in the process of torture and that there was a form of torture known as ''La présentation de la question'' or simply the "Question",<ref name="Maxwell"/> where the prisoner was led to the torture chamber and was shown the implements of torture. While at the chamber, sentence to full torture was pronounced but, immediately after, the prisoner was taken back to the prison cell, without actually having been tortured.<ref name="Criminal Justice">{{cite book|author1=John Hamilton Baker|author2=Louis A. Knafla|author3=Calgary Institute for the Humanities|title=Crime and criminal justice in Europe and Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YbdR23PqGkIC&pg=PA59|accessdate=30 August 2011|year=1981|publisher=Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press|isbn=978-0-88920-118-7|pages=59–}}</ref>
The torture chamber was specifically designed to evoke fear in the victims.<ref name="History of Torture Throughout the Ages">{{cite book|author=George Ryley Scott|title=History of Torture Throughout the Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tj7vbMmuvhYC&pg=PA66|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=10 March 2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-4063-9|pages=66–67}}</ref> It was usually built underground and only dimly lit. Inside the chamber waited the executioner, his face completely covered apart from two holes in the garment to enable him to peer through and wearing a black hood; his menacing appearance being described as "most diabolical" and "satanic".<ref name="History of Torture Throughout the Ages"/>
When during the Question, the view of the chamber, the torture implements and the executioner did not cause the victim to confess, a full-scale torture session was planned. To prepare for torture, the victim was stripped naked with hands tied. The penultimate step to torture included a repetition of the questions asked earlier of the victims. If the victims still proclaimed their innocence, full torture was initiated.<ref name="Maxwell"/><ref name="History of Torture Throughout the Ages"/>
The most common instrument of torture was the ''[[strappado]]'',<ref name="Inquisition from Its Establishment"/> which was a simple rope and [[pulley]] system. With the pulley attached to ceiling of the chamber, the lifting rope was tied to the wrist of the victim, whose hands were tied behind their back. Subsequently, the victim was raised to the ceiling and then lowered using a jerking motion causing dislocation of the [[shoulder joint]]s. To increase the suffering caused by the strappado, weights were attached to the feet of the victim.<ref name="Maxwell"/><ref name="Inquisition from Its Establishment"/>
Church doctrine protected human life so it was problematic if a victim were to die, especially before they confessed. In difficult cases, when a victim would not readily confess or was too weak to continue in an uninterrupted torture session, breaks were allowed between torture sessions because Inquisition regulations only allowed one torture session per victim. That way, a torture session could resume after a break to allow time for the victim to recover or reconsider their opposition to confessing, and it was considered to have been the continuation of the previous torture session and not a new one.<ref name="Maxwell"/>
Because confession under torture was not acceptable, the victim had to sign a written confession after they had made their oral confession under torture. Typically, during confession, the inquisitors demanded that the prisoner implicate as many people as possible and not only themselves. If the prisoner resisted signing, the inquisitors could always resume the torture by claiming that they had just halted the session, just for the signing, but did not really put an end to it.<ref name="Maxwell"/>
==== Construction ==== [[File:Torture Chamber of the Inquisition from Moore's Martyrology.png|thumb|300px|An artist's depiction of a Torture chamber of the Inquisition, ca. 1809 from Moore's Martyrology.<ref name="Ryley Scott">{{cite book|author=George Ryley Scott|title=History of Torture Throughout the Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tj7vbMmuvhYC&pg=PA66&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=13 December 2011|year=2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing<!--|ISBN=0-7661-4063-6 -->|isbn=9780766140639|page=67}}</ref>]]
The method of construction of the torture chamber of the [[Palais des Papes|papal palace]] at [[Avignon]], used during the Inquisition, has been described as ingenious.<ref name="Heckethorn2005">{{cite book|author=Charles William Heckethorn|title=The Secret Societies of All Ages & Countries - Volume 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yr-8FypJ7ekC&pg=PA179|date=November 2005|publisher=Cosimo, Inc.|isbn=978-1-59605-436-3|volume=1|pages=179–|quote=The next move of the prisoner was to the torture chamber. The torture chamber in the papal palace at Avignon was constructed with diabolical ingenuity. To cause the shrieks and groans of those tortured to remain confined within the hall, each wall projects and recedes in such a manner as to exhibit a face in a different direction to that of the wall on the opposite side, and in this way the solid mass of masonry of each wall is carried upwards, the result of which peculiar structure is that shrieks were thrown back from wall to wall, and thus never could reach the outside, nor disturb the pope, toying with his concubines in the adjoining palace.}}</ref> The construction of some of the torture chambers at Avignon was based on principles of [[Acoustics]], specifically designed to muffle the screams and cries of the tortured.<ref name="Crétineau-Joly1863"/> The walls of the torture chamber recessed and protruded in a complementary fashion to the walls on the opposite side so as to reflect the screams of the victims locally, ensuring that their shrieks would not be carried to the exterior.<ref name="Heckethorn2005"/><ref name="Crétineau-Joly1863">{{cite book|author=[[Jacques Crétineau-Joly|Jacques Augustin M. Crétineau-Joly]]|title=The poor gentlemen of Liège: the history of the Jesuits in England and Ireland for the last sixty years, tr., ed. by R.J.M'Ghee|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2dsCAAAAQAAJ&pg=PR127|year=1863|pages=127–128}}</ref> A chamber located above the main torture chamber had a dungeon with a hole near the middle of the floor through which, according to accounts, the tortured bodies of the prisoners were thrown into a cavity.<ref name="Crétineau-Joly1863"/> The chamber where the victims were being burnt was of circular construction and resembled the furnace of a glass-house with a funnel-like chimney at the top.<ref name="Heckethorn2005"/>
There were secret staircases and hidden spaces which were used to overhear the discussions in the prison cells. The ceiling of the torture chamber was especially designed to muffle the cries of the victims. Inside the torture chamber, furnaces and grates were also present.<ref name="WalshLittell1841">{{cite book|author1=Robert Walsh|author2=Eliakim Littell|author3=John Jay Smith|title=The Museum of Foreign Literature, Science, and Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8O5S6WBqNB0C&pg=PA202|year=1841|publisher=E. Littell & T. Holden|page=202}}</ref> Up to 1850 the chambers were shown to visitors after which time the ecclesiastical authorities of Avignon decided to shut them down.<ref name="Heckethorn2005"/> In a similar vein the torture chamber of the [[Spanish Inquisition]] in [[Lima]], [[Peru]] had one metre thick walls so that the screams of the victims could not penetrate them.<ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/ie/daily/19970501/12150763.html Spanish Inquisition: Preserving the dark chapter ASSOCIATED PRESS]{{dead link|date=March 2017 |bot=Dr.K. |fix-attempted=yes }}. Indianexpress.com (1997-05-01). Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref>
In [[Nuremberg]] and [[Salzburg]] the torture chambers featured [[trapdoors]] on their floors. In Nuremberg the room underneath the main torture chamber featured torture machinery while in Salzburg, the room under the trapdoor, functioned like a waiting room for prisoners. When the time came the prisoner was pulled up and into the upper torture chamber.<ref>{{cite book|title=Archaeologia: or miscellaneous tracts relating to antiquity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6V8VAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA243|accessdate=30 August 2011|year=1838|publisher=Society of Antiquaries of London|pages=243–}}</ref> Other times, deep water pits could be found under the trapdoor, where the victims of the torture chamber could be thrown, after a torture session, to drown.<ref name="Alger1889">{{cite book|author=William Rounseville Alger|title=The destiny of the soul: a critical history of the doctrine of a future life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qrd2xplA-S8C&pg=PA425|accessdate=9 June 2012|year=1889|publisher=Roberts|page=425}}</ref>
==== Palace of the Inquisition ==== [[File:Palácio da Inquisição no Rossio (cropped).png|thumb|300px|[[Estaus Palace|Palace of the Inquisition]] in Lisbon, Portugal]]
The torture chamber was the final destination in a progression of four cell types during incarceration at the Palace of the Inquisition. The palace contained the Judgement Hall, the offices of the employees, the private apartments of the [[Grand Inquisitor]] and the detention cells adjacent to the apartments.<ref name="Heckethorn2005"/> The detention cell gradations started with the ''cells of mercy'' reserved mainly for rich transgressors who upon bequeathing all their property to the Inquisition were normally let go after a time of detention in the cells.
For more difficult prisoners the next cell stage was the ''cell of penitence''. These were situated in small round towers of about 3 metres (ten feet) in diameter. They were painted white and included rudimentary furniture such as a stool and a bed. Very little light was allowed in. If the prisoner did not cooperate, the next step in the detention process was the [[dungeon]]. The dungeon had walls 1.5 metres (five feet) thick, double doors and was in complete darkness. No conversation of any type was allowed in the dungeon.<ref name="P and R"/><ref name="Heckethorn2005"/> The food allowance for prisoners was less than a penny a day including the profit of the warden while any human refuse was removed every four days. After a stay in the dungeon, uncooperative prisoners were moved to their final destination: the torture chamber.<ref name="Heckethorn2005"/>
====Palace of Inquisition in Cartagena==== [[File:Entrada Del Palacio de la Inquisición.JPG|thumb|180px|Entrance to the Palace of Inqusition at Cartagena]] {{main article|Palace of Inquisition}} The Palace of Inquisition was a torture chamber in [[Cartagena, Colombia]], built under orders of [[Philip III of Spain|Philip III]],<ref>{{cite book|volume=1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B2BZAAAAMAAJ |title=Baroque and Rococo in Latin America |year=1967 |publisher=Dover Publications |last=Kelemen |first=Kal |edition=2 }}</ref> which served as headquarters for the [[Spanish Inquisition]]. It was used to torture [[Jews]],<ref name="Jewish Nation">{{cite book|title=The Jewish Nation of the Caribbean: The Spanish-Portuguese Jewish Settlements in the Caribbean and the Guianas |first=Mordehay |last=Arbell |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T3t__sdb_SkC&pg=PA309 |page=309 |publisher=Gefen |year=2002 |isbn=9789652292797 }}</ref> and other non-Catholics.<ref>{{cite book|page=44 |title=Cruise Travel |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NDADAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA44 |date=August 1982 }}</ref> Approximately 800 individuals were put to death there.
== Modern times == <!---need more precise title per [[WP:DATED]]--->
===Nazi Germany and South America===
The traditional torture users of modern times have been [[dictatorship]] governments e.g. the [[Nazis]],<ref name="Nazi Camp">[https://web.archive.org/web/20080329135446/http://www.europebyphoto.com/tours/fortbreendonk/fortbreendonk.html Fort Breendonk (Nazi Camp): Pictorial essay. Mentions local torture chamber via Internet Archive]</ref><ref name="Nazis">[http://fcit.usf.edu/HOLOCAUST/resource/document/DocJac08.htm Nuremberg Trials Opening Address for the United States Robert Jackson statement: (Nazi) Germany became one vast torture chamber]. Fcit.usf.edu. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref> [[Argentine military junta]] (at the [[Navy School of Mechanics]]), and the Chilean dictatorship led by [[Augusto Pinochet]] as well as other South American regimes.<ref name="Chicago Tribune">{{cite news|author1=Paul Salopek, Tribune Foreign Correspondent.|title=Torture Victims Tremble At Idea Of Free Pinochet|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-02-08/news/0002080064_1_chilean-dictator-gen-augusto-pinochet-human-rights|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=8 February 2000|quote="They ran my torture chamber like an office, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.," said Padilla, who was a student activist at the University of Chile when the}}</ref><ref name="Lazzara2011">{{cite book|author=Michael J. Lazzara|title=Luz Arce and Pinochet's Chile: Testimony in the Aftermath of State Violence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bXHHAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA1|date=29 March 2011|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-230-11842-3|page=1|quote=Yet, traitorous and complicit subjects—both in the torture chamber and outside of it—are an undeniable part of the Pinochet regime's (1973–90) tumultuous history of state violence.}}</ref><ref name="Cypher">[http://web.mit.edu/comm-forum/mit5/papers/cypher.pdf "Détournement as Civil Disobedience: Mash-ups, Re-Mixes and the Recontextualization of Sound and Images as Political Statements"] A Parapolitical-Cultural Essay by James L. Cypher Presented to the MIT Media in Transition Conference “Disruptive Practices” Session April 28, 2007 quote: ''The Sexy Blindfold” based on the 1970s Chilean secret police torture chamber underneath a discotheque, where the loud dance music drowned out he screams of the sexual chamber of horrors below.''</ref><ref name="Pinochet">Kenneth P. Serbin [https://web.archive.org/web/20090530014447/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1058/is_1_122/ai_n8703035/ Torture chamber: behind Pinochet's reign of terror]. Christian Century, January 11, 2005</ref> The isolation felt inside the Nazi torture chambers was so strong that author, and victim, [[Yehiel Dinur|K. Zetnik]], during his testimony at the [[Eichmann]] trial in [[Jerusalem]] in 1961, has described them as ''[[Psychology of torture#Social effects|another galaxy]].''<ref name="Vaknin2009">{{cite book|author=[[Sam Vaknin]]|title=Abuse, Trauma, and Torture: Their Consequences and Effects|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tQszBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT86|date=14 January 2009|publisher=Narcissus Publishing|page=86|quote=The torture chambers are "another galaxy". This is how Auschwitz was described by the author K. Zetnik in his testimony in the Eichmann trial in Jerusalem in 1961.|id=GGKEY:NUWBB8W3KQW}}</ref>
In Chile, during the Pinochet dictatorship, the use of converted locker-rooms and [[luxury box|skybox]]es as torture chambers has been reported.<ref name="Kornbluh2013">{{cite book|author=Peter Kornbluh|title=The Pinochet File: A Declassified Dossier on Atrocity and Accountability|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fJNnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA42-IA2|date=13 December 2013|publisher=New Press|isbn=978-1-59558-995-8|page=42|quote=There are three sources of power in Chile: Pinochet, God, and DINA. ... in lockerrooms and luxury skyboxes that themilitaryhad transformed into torture chambers.}}</ref> The ''[[Esmeralda (BE-43)|Esmeralda]]'', a training ship of the Chilean Navy had also been used as a "floating torture chamber" during Pinochet's dictatorship.<ref name="O'Shaughnessy2000">{{cite book|author=Hugh O'Shaughnessy|title=Pinochet: The Politics of Torture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vU2U_7ur46kC&pg=PA122|date=1 March 2000|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=978-0-8147-6201-1|page=122|quote=... training ship which had been used as a floating torture chamber in the immediate aftermath of the 1973 coup.}}</ref> In 2011, protests erupted in [[Vancouver, BC|Vancouver]], [[Canada]], upon a visit by the ''Esmeralda''.<ref name="North Shore News">{{cite news|author1=Benjamin Alldritt|title=Chilean torture ship visit ignites protest in North Vancouver|url=http://www.nsnews.com/news/chilean-torture-ship-visit-ignites-protest-in-north-vancouver-1.360624|publisher=North Shore News|date=August 3, 2011|quote=Known as the White Lady, the four-masted barquentine is the second-largest sailing vessel in the world and an undeniably beautiful ship, but it carries with it a horrific past. Following the military coup in Chile in 1973, the Esmeralda was used as a floating prison and torture chamber by the dictatorship of General Augusto Pinochet.}}</ref> In [[Santiago, Chile]], ''Villa Grimaldi'', once a cultural center, was used as a torture centre which included torture chambers.<ref name="The Santiago Times">{{cite web|title=Chile’s Villa Grimaldi remembers horror of Pinochet years|url=http://santiagotimes.cl/chiles-villa-grimaldi-remembers-horror-of-pinochet-years/|publisher=The Santiago Times|quote=At Villa Grimaldi, remnants of the cells and torture chambers exist alongside the foundations of the cultural center the building once was.}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=Dr.K. |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> A tour of ''Villa Grimaldi'' has been described as a "tour of barbarity" featuring exhibits with descriptive signs such as "Place of hangings", "Torture chamber", "Annex torture chamber", "Women's cells 1x1 meter", "The Grill: Electric Beds" and others.<ref name="Cooper2002">{{cite book|author=Marc Cooper|title=Pinochet and Me: A Chilean Anti-memoir|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FaQCs8EAK-4C&pg=PA138|year=2002|publisher=Verso|isbn=978-1-85984-360-4|page=138|quote="The tower: place of solitary torture and extermination" . . . "Place of hangings" . . . "Torture chamber" . . . "Annex torture chamber" . . . "Women's cells 1x1 meter"}}</ref>
[[Michelle Bachelet]], who later became President of Chile, was tortured in a torture chamber during the Pinochet years.<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/bps/additionalcontent/18/20477050/From-Torture-Victim-to-President From Torture Victim to President] Britannica online Quote:"Lucrecia Brito shared the cramped cell with Bachelet. We could hear the screams from the torture chamber opposite our cell," Brito tells me.<br>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/From+torture+victim+to+president.-a0144665529 alternate from Freelibrary]<br></ref> After the fall of Pinochet, the torture chamber victims and the relatives of the ''[[desaparecidos]]'' refused to strike a deal with Pinochet or with the politicians that followed him.<ref name="Macedo2004">{{cite book|author=Stephen Macedo|title=Universal Jurisdiction: National Courts and the Prosecution of Serious Crimes Under International Law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a0WEKMuUYJMC&pg=PA229|year=2004|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=0-8122-3736-6|page=229|quote=Survivors of Pinochet's torture chambers and mothers of the disappeared did not make a deal with Pinochet, nor did they accept the bargain struck by politicians.}}</ref>
===Europe=== Use of torture chambers was also reported in Europe during the [[Greek military junta of 1967–1974|Greek military junta]] years (1967–1974).<ref name="ESA chambers">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090211184321/http://www.athensnews.gr/athweb/nathens.print_unique?e=C&f=13012&m=A13&aa=1&eidos=A "Past present"], ''Athens News'', 2 May 2003 quote: ''After weeks of gruesome interrogation in the infamous military police (ESA) torture chambers, Panagoulis was sentenced to death by a court martial on 17 November 1968.'' Article by Dimitris Yannopoulos ATHENS NEWS, 02/05/2003, page: A13 Article code: C13012A131 via the Internet archive</ref><ref name="Political prisoners">[https://web.archive.org/web/20090210171627/http://www.political-prisoners.net/home.php?id=9&lang=en&action=campaign V. International Symposium Against Isolation Greece / Athens, 15-18 December 2006 Political prisoners network] quote: 12.00 a.m. – 1.00 p.m.: Commemoration and press conference at the EAT-ESA (EAT-ESA is a museum today, and it was used as a torture center of the gendarmery during the military junta)</ref><ref name="Reportage">[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=el&u=http://www.rwf.gr/386/%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%B5%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B5%CF%8D%CE%BE%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82/%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B7%CF%84%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%AC%CE%B4%CE%B7%CF%82-%CE%BA%CF%89%CE%BD%CF%83%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AF%CE%BD%CE%BF%CF%82/ Reportage without frontiers from ET (Greek National TV)] Interview with Vice Admiral Konstantinos Dimitriadis Quote: ''The fai was filled with salt. Απειλές. Threats. Ορισμένοι μάλιστα υπέστησαν κι απειλές ηθικής τάξεως. Some even suffered threats and Ethic. Ότι οι γυναίκες τους και τα λοιπά και κάτι μονταρισμένες φωτογραφίες με σκάνδαλα να το πούμε έτσι. That women and the other something mounted photos with scandals to say. Με απειλές, με τέτοια πράγματα και υβρεολόγιο. With threats, with such things and profanity. Νυχθημερόν να παίζει κάποιο ραδιόφωνο. Nychthimeron to play a radio. Ένα ραδιόφωνο με διάφορα τραγούδια εκείνης της εποχής και τα λοιπά. A radio with various songs of the time and so on. Και μαγνητόφωνα με κραυγές για να σπάσει το ηθικό, ας πούμε. And tape with cries to break the morale, say. Αυτά και βέβαια ορισμένοι, δεν υπέστησαν όλοι με τον ίδιο τρόπο την μείωση αυτή. Those are certainly some, not all were in the same way to reduce this. Είχανε κάτι ζωστήρες. Eichane zostires something. Το κορύφωμα βέβαια ήταν του Μουστακλή ο οποίος χτυπήθηκε άσχημα και βγήκε εκτός ο άνθρωπος. The culmination of the course was Moustakli who severely beaten and got out of the man.''[''[[sic]]''] (Translation by Google)<br>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090211160841/http://www.rwf.gr/interviews_senaria-new.php?id=152&interview=1&interview_id=323 Original Greek interview through Internet Archive]<br>[http://www.rwf.gr/386/%CF%83%CF%85%CE%BD%CE%B5%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%B5%CF%8D%CE%BE%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%82/%CE%B4%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B7%CF%84%CF%81%CE%B9%CE%AC%CE%B4%CE%B7%CF%82-%CE%BA%CF%89%CE%BD%CF%83%CF%84%CE%B1%CE%BD%CF%84%CE%AF%CE%BD%CE%BF%CF%82/ Second link]</ref> [[Alexandros Panagoulis]] and Army Major [[Spyros Moustaklis]] are examples of persons tortured at the EAT/ESA ([[Greek Military Police]]) interrogation cell units.<ref name="ESA chambers"/>
===Middle East=== Under his reign (16 July 1979 until 9 April 2003), [[Saddam Hussein]] reportedly tortured those whom he deemed as a threat. After the invasion of Iraq by [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. forces]], pictures of dead Iraqis, with their necks slashed, their eyes gouged out and their genitals blackened, were located in many torture chambers.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/meast/04/02/sprj.irq.iraq.torture/index.html Report: Iraq torture chamber found]. CNN (2003-04-02). Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref> Jail cells, with dried blood on the floor and rusted shackles bolted to the walls, lined the corridors.<ref>Kelley, Jack. (2003-04-13) [https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/iraq/2003-04-13-saddam-secrets-usat_x.htm Iraqis pour out tales of Saddam's torture chambers]. Usatoday.Com. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref>
In November 2004, [[U.S. Marines]] found a number of torture rooms in [[Fallujah]] by following trails of dried blood, or the smell of dead bodies. Some rooms were hidden behind fake walls, or concealed in basements.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2004/11/22/eveningnews/main657134.shtml Fallujah's Houses Of Horror]. CBS News. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref> Libyans have entered abandoned torture chambers and found devices that have been used against opposition members in the past.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/03/20113122102545671.html Evidence of Libya torture emerges – Africa]. Al Jazeera English (2011-03-01). Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref>
==United States==
Since the 1970s, the Chicago Police Department has tortured prisoners at [[Homan Square]] to extract forced confessions<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/feb/24/chicago-police-detain-americans-black-site</ref>. In addition, the [[CIA]] tortures prisoners at [[Black Sites]] around the world <ref>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2017/oct/09/cia-torture-black-site-enhanced-interrogation</ref>
==In culture== Aside from its dictionary definition the term has great cultural resonance, because it transforms an [[abstract concept]] (torture) into a real place (torture chamber), and is an integral part of [[pop culture]]. Related exhibits can also be found in [[torture museum]]s and in exhibits in places such as [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]]{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} and [[Niagara Falls]],<ref>{{cite book|author=John Robert Colombo|title=Ghost Stories of Ontario|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nM9OvfDa3soC&pg=PA101|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=1 September 1995|publisher=Dundurn Press Ltd.|isbn=978-0-88882-176-8|pages=101–}}</ref> which attract millions of tourists each year.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}
=== In art, entertainment, and media===
====Film==== In film the torture chamber is also known as the '''chamber of horrors''', with the word ''horror'' implying ''torture'' as well as ''[[murder]]'', or a combination of both. Classic films focusing on the torture chamber include: *''[[The Pit and the Pendulum (1961 film)|The Pit and the Pendulum]]'' (1961). *''[[Chamber of Horrors (1966 film)|Chamber of Horrors]]'' (1966). * ''[[The Pendulum, the Pit and Hope]]'' (1983). Directed by [[Jan Švankmajer]] *''[[Hostel (2005 film)|Hostel]]'' (2005) * ''The Cell Zero'' ({{when|date=June 2016}}), a film about the [[Greek Military Police]] torture chambers{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} *''[[The Blood Demon|The Torture Chamber of Dr. Sadism]]'' (1967; Die Schlangengrube und das Pendel). A German adaptation of Edgar Allan Poe's novel "The Pit and the Pendulum".<ref>[http://www.dvddrive-in.com/reviews/t-z/torturechamberdeathsmiles6773.htm The Torture Chamber of Dr. Sadism (1967)]. Dvddrive-in.com. Retrieved on 2011-08-30.</ref>
====Literature==== *There is a torture chamber In [[George Orwell]]'s famous novel ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'' (1949), [[Room 101]]. *In [[Gaston Leroux]]'s novel ''[[The Phantom of the Opera]]'' (serialised in ''[[Le Gaulois]]'' from September 23, 1909, to January 8, 1910), [[Erik_(The_Phantom_of_the_Opera)|Erik]] (the Phantom's) chamber of torture consisted of a hexagonal room lined with [[mirror]]s on each wall. Temperatures vary inside the room, and soon, without food or water, people trapped in there begin having [[hallucination]]s. There is an iron tree in there with a [[lasso]] under it with which one can commit [[suicide]], which is the only way out. *Harold T. Wilkins' article in the September 1929 issue of ''[[Popular Mechanics]]'', titled "Secrets of Ancient Torture Chambers", describes the [fictitious] shrinking torture chamber at the Tolfi castle in [[Sicily]] as an example of an ancient torture chamber and proposes a mechanical model to account for the contracting action of the chamber.<ref name="Shrinking chamber">{{cite book|author=Hearst Magazines|title=Popular Mechanics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xt4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA402|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=September 1929|publisher=Hearst Magazines|pages=402–404|issn=0032-4558}}</ref> *[[William Mudford]]'s most famous tale{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} is the short story "[[The Iron Shroud]]", a classic predicament story, describes the plight of a noble Italian hero who is confined in a continuously and imperceptibly contracting iron torture chamber at Tolfi castle. The chamber walls and ceiling are slowly contracting, day by day, through mechanical means, to the point of eventually crushing and enveloping the victim, thus metaphorically becoming his iron shroud. *Mulford's story provided Edgar Allan Poe with the idea of the shrinking cell in his short story "[[The Pit and the Pendulum]]" (1842).
====Opera==== *In ''[[Bluebeard's Castle]]'' the torture chamber is introduced with its own music while there is a dramatic scene where Judith and Bluebeard make reference to the torture chamber and the red light of its interior that escapes through its open door. The torture chamber musical introduction possesses a circular form with the introduction repeating, in a shorter form, at the conclusion of the torture chamber scene. This is in contrast to the rest of the musical composition of the opera which is ''[[through-composed]]''.<ref name="Carolina1999">{{cite book|author=Greensboro Carl S. Leafstedt Assistant Professor of Music University of North Carolina|title=Inside Bluebeard's Castle : Music and Drama in Bela Bartok's Opera: Music and Drama in Bela Bartok's Opera|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oNVAmHBbULgC&pg=PA91|date=11 October 1999|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-535505-5|page=91}}</ref>
====Video games==== *The protagonist in [[Exidy]]'s [[light gun]] shooter ''[[Chiller (video game)|Chiller]]'' (1986) is a torturer who advances through dungeon levels, maiming and killing helpless enemies. When it was [[Porting|ported]] from arcades to the [[Nintendo Entertainment System]], the enemies were [[dehumanization|portrayed as]] undead monsters, risen by an evil force and threatening a village. Both versions sold poorly, due to their gratuitous [[graphic violence]], which was uncommon in [[Western world|Western]] mass media at the time.
=== Technology ===
*The [[McKinley Climatic Laboratory]] has been described as the world’s largest torture chamber for aircraft undergoing [[FAA]] or military certification.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/chamber.html|title=Torture Chamber|author=Regis, Ed|date=May 1, 2006|work=Air & Space Magazine|access-date=29 July 2009|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130101192115/http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/chamber.html|archive-date=1 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Quote: "Because airplanes must fly in the real world, the Air Force built a fake one." and "The reason that didn’t happen is just one of the technological marvels of the McKinley Climatic Laboratory, the world’s largest torture chamber for aircraft in search of FAA or military certification."</ref> *''[[Wired Magazine|Wired]]'' has referred to the laboratory [[NASA]] uses to test the next generation of spacecraft as a torture chamber.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/science/space/magazine/17-08/st_vacuumchamber |work=WIRED MAGAZINE|title= Torture Chamber: NASA Tests Next-Gen Craft for Space Blast}}</ref> *At [[Ryerson University]], the laboratory used for testing aircraft components has been described as a "high-tech torture chamber".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oit.on.ca/Pages/SStories61-80/StoryRyersonFawaz.html |website=Ryerson University |title=Torture Chamber |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017060812/http://www.oit.on.ca/pages/SStories61-80/StoryRyersonFawaz.html |archivedate=17 October 2010 |df= }} Quote: "Ryerson research engineer Zouheir Fawaz does bad things to aircraft components, so they won’t do bad things to us." and "If the cavernous room at Ryerson University looks a little scary…well, that’s because it is. This is a high-tech torture chamber, complete with loops of heavy chain, bone-crushing presses, fiery furnaces and thick electrical cables that snake ominously across the floor. The good news is that all of these cruel devices are used solely on…aircraft components."</ref>
== See also == {{col div|colwidth=30em}} *[[Black site]] *[[Extraordinary rendition]] *[[Medieval instruments of torture]] *[[Palace of Inquisition]] *[[Psychology of torture]] *[[Psychological warfare]] *[[The Box (torture)]] {{colend}}
== Books == *{{cite book|author1=Joseph Anthony Amato|author2=David Monge|title=Victims and values: a history and a theory of suffering|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hu4rJYx79ZwC|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=November 1990|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-313-25903-6}} *Guida Billingue all mostra di Strumenti di Tortura Chamber dal Medioeve all Epoca Industriale. By Roberto Held. Florence, Qua d' Arno 1983.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Joseph Anthony Amato|author2=David Monge|title=Victims and values: a history and a theory of suffering|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ONAjG_Rh2hEC&pg=PA21|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=30 November 1990|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-93690-7}}</ref> *"[[The Iron Shroud]]" by [[William Mudford]], a [[short story]], published also as a [[chapbook]], about an iron torture chamber which shrinks through mechanical action and eventually crushes the victim inside.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=aaVbAAAAQAAJ "The Iron Shroud"] at [[Google Books]]</ref> [[Edgar Allan Poe]] is considered to have been influenced by Mudford's story when he wrote ''[[The Pit and the Pendulum]]''.<ref name="BookRags p. 2">[http://www.bookrags.com/biography/william-mudford-dlb/2.html Online Biography of William Mudford from the Dictionary of Literary Biography hosted by BookRags] p. 2</ref><ref name="Critique of William Mudford">[http://nq.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pdf_extract/185/3/83-k Oxford Journals] Critique of William Mudford Notes and Queries July 31, 1943 p. 83</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Edgar Allan Poe|title=The Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym of Nantucket, and Related Tales|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a8kffvLCqgAC&pg=PA298+|accessdate=30 August 2011|date=1 May 1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-283771-4|page=298 (note)|quote= Poe apparently got the idea for his shrinking chamber from an 1830 Blackwood's story titled the 'Iron Shroud'}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080329135446/http://www.europebyphoto.com/tours/fortbreendonk/fortbreendonk.html Fort Breendonk (Nazi Camp): Pictorial essay. Mentions local torture chamber]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Torture Chamber}} [[Category:Torture]] [[Category:Rooms]]
